Claim_set.text: Our processing protocol involving Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ delivers outstanding hydrogen production performance, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) value of up to 240.9 mol$_{H2}$ mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$ at 298 K. During the stability test, the mSiO$_{2}$ shell prevented the loss of the nanoalloy, demonstrating impressive durability with a negligible decline of less than 0.8% for 30 cycles. The high activity and exceptional stability demonstrated by our catalyst notably surpass those of other noble-metal-free catalysts reported to date. These results reported here may open new avenues for designing stable catalysts using earth-abundant raw materials for hydrogen evolution reactions.
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalyst achieves a turnover frequency (TOF) of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$ mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$min$^{-1}$ at 298 K with a negligible decline of less than 0.8% for 30 cycles.
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrogen production performance of a catalyst

Claim_set.text:
## Conclusion

In summary, we introduced a straightforward and facile method for fabricating magnetically recyclable Co-Cu@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalysts by utilizing mSiO$_{2}$-encapsulated Co-Cu-ZIF as a precursor through a thermal pyrolysis process. The optimized Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2 }$ catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance with a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$, surpassing the majority of noble-metal-free catalysts. More importantly, it exhibited remarkable stability, with a negligible decrease of less than 0.8% over 30 cycles. This enhanced performance originated primarily from the synergistic effects of the bimetallic alloy and silica confinement.
Claim_set.Claim: The Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance with a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$ and remarkable stability, with a negligible decrease of less than 0.8% over 30 cycles.
Claim_set.Topic: Magnetically recyclable catalysts for hydrogen production

Thus, the excellent performance of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ may be attributed to a highly accessible surface area through the porous confinement layers, facilitating the transfer and diffusion of reactants and products.
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$-N exhibits a lower catalytic performance with a TOF of 196.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$ compared to Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$, which has a TOF of 240.9 mol$_{H2}$·mol$_{metal}$$^{-1}$·min$^{-1}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic performance and surface area in hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts

In addition, the introduced RuP$_{2}$ and Ti$_{4}$P$_{6}$O$_{23}$ can broaden the visible light response range, provide abundant edge active sites for hydrogen evolution, and significantly accelerate the migration of photo-generated carriers by forming a heterojunction.
Claim_set.Claim: RuP$_{2}$/Ti$_{4}$P$_{6}$O$_{23}$@TiO$_{2}$-7, prepared via an evaporation-calcination strategy, exhibits uniformly arranged nanospheres on its surface, increasing active sites and promoting photogenerated electron diffusion, while also broadening the visible light response range and accelerating the migration of photo-generated carriers through a heterojunction.

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts are a promising alternative to platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). However, attaining efficient ORR activity and superior stability in Fe-N-C catalysts is still crucial yet challenging. Herein, we report a rational SiO$_{2}$-mediated two-step pyrolysis strategy for stabilizing densely exposed Fe-N$_{4 }$active sites on hierarchically porous carbon (HP-Fe-N-C/2). Benefiting from the high density of accessible Fe-N$_{4 }$sites and the high graphitization degree of carbon support, the obtained HPFe-N-C/2 catalyst demonstrates outstanding activity and stability for ORR in both alkaline and acidic media.
Claim_set.Claim: Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts demonstrate outstanding activity and stability for ORR in both alkaline and acidic media due to the high density of accessible Fe-N₄ sites and the high graphitization degree of carbon support.
Claim_set.Topic: Stabilization of Fe-N₄ active sites for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)

Claim_set.text:
Up to now, PGM catalysts have been regarded as generally efficient catalysts to accelerate ORR [8,9]. However, the high price and scarcity of PGM catalysts greatly limit their large-scale commercialization [10 -13]. Therefore, for the widespread application of ZABs and PEMFCs, exploring high-performance and earth-abundant PGM-free catalysts has become a key research direction [14 -20].

To date, atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts possess the highest ORR performance among the various PGM-free catalysts [18,21,22]. Atomic Fe-N$_{4 }$ sites have been confirmed as active sites for ORR by theoretical and experimental studies [23 -26]. Thus, increasing the density of Fe-N$_{4 }$sites is an effective strategy to boost ORR activity.
Claim_set.Claim: Atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts possess the highest ORR performance among the various PGM-free catalysts, with atomic Fe-N₄ sites confirmed as active sites for ORR.
Claim_set.Topic: ORR performance of PGM-free catalysts

Claim_set.text: The subsequent adsorption and pyrolysis process further promote the creation of abundant Fe-N$_{4 }$active sites. Due to the synergistically advantageous features of densely exposed Fe-N$_{4 }$ sites, enhanced intrinsic activity of Fe-N$_{4 }$sites by pyridinic N and graphitic N dopants, and highly graphitized carbon matrix, the HP-Fe-N-C/2 exhibits outstanding ORR activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic media. The assembled ZAB displays a high peak power density of 217 mW cm GLYPH<0> 2 and long-life cycling stability for 1342 h. Moreover, the maximum output power in a PEMFC reaches 0.66 W cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$.
Claim_set.Claim: The HP-Fe-N-C/2 catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR activity and stability due to the synergistically advantageous features of densely exposed Fe-N$_{4}$ sites, enhanced intrinsic activity of Fe-N$_{4}$ sites by pyridinic N and graphitic N dopants, and highly graphitized carbon matrix.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst performance in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)

Meanwhile, the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) results also demonstrated a significantly enhanced selectivity of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC towards the conversion of benzene into CO$_{2 }$(Fig. S16).

Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic performance of MnOx/Co3O4@ACC in benzene conversion

Conversely, no significant signal corresponding to ZSH was detected in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte during a cycle from 5 to 50 ( Figure 4 f). In conclusion, the aforementioned evidence and analysis demonstrate that the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exerts a significant inhibitory effect on byproduct formation at the Zn surface, thereby effectively preventing uncontrolled dendrite growth and facilitating uniform deposition of Zn. Consequently, this leads to the development of a stable SEI film.

Claim_set.text: The perspective can be further supported by cross-sectional SEM analysis ( Figure 4 c,d). As illustrated in Figure 4 c, the electrode surface in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte is covered with abundant clusters of loosely disordered flake-like and hexagonal byproducts of Zn dendrites, resulting in an extremely rough surface. This indicates the uncontrolled deposition of Zn and continuous side reactions between the Zn anode and ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes. In contrast, a flat and homogeneous surface morphology is achieved in the Gln/ ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte, suggesting that the addition of Gln facilitates the formation of stable SEI films ( Figure 4 d). Furthermore, the chemical phase transition at the anode interface was monitored by ex situ XRD analysis in different cyclic states.
Claim_set.Claim: The addition of Gln to ZnSO₄ electrolytes facilitates the formation of stable SEI films, leading to a flat and homogeneous surface morphology on the electrode.
Claim_set.Topic: Formation of Stable SEI Films in ZnSO₄ Electrolytes

Claim_set.text: The consequences demonstrate that the chloride binding capacity in cement modified by CDs with average sizes of 1.73, 5.79, and 12.37 nm increases by 41%, 20%, and 14% respectively, compared with that of the blank group after 28-d immersion in 3 mol/L NaCl solution. This testifies that the chloride binding capacity of CDs-incorporated cement is negatively correlative with CDs sizes. The related mechanism is that CDs with smaller sizes can provide more nucleation sites to promote cement hydration, further advancing the production of C -S -H gels and monosulfate (Ms), thus more markedly enhancing the physical adsorption and chemical binding of chloride ions in cement pastes.
Claim_set.Claim: The chloride binding capacity of cement modified by carbon dots (CDs) increases with decreasing CDs size, enhancing chloride binding in cement pastes.
Claim_set.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement modified by CDs

Claim_set.text:
And the chloride binding capacity in diverse CDs-modified paste specimens is determined through the equilibrium tests. Crucially, the relevant mechanism is reasonably revealed based on the phase alteration. The main conclusions are shown as follows:

(2) The relationship between chloride binding ability of cement and the sizes of CDs is determined. The specimen containing 0.5 H CDs (24.6 mg/g), 1.0 H CDs (25.7 mg/g) or 2.0 H (30.4 mg/g) increases the C$_{b }$ value by 14%. 19% or 41% than the blank group respectively, after 28-d exposure to the 3 mol/L NaCl solution. Thus, the smaller the sizes of CDs, the more effective the enhancement of chloride binding.
Claim_set.Claim: The chloride binding capacity of cement is enhanced by the addition of CDs, with smaller CD sizes leading to more effective chloride binding.
Claim_set.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement modification

Claim_set.text:
More importantly, our latest studies evidenced that CDs owned an excellent dispersion stability in saturated Ca(OH)$_{2 }$ solution, and could significantly augment the chloride binding capacity of cement [29,30]. In detail, the deliberately designed CDs, with rich oxygen-containing surface functional groups and a highly crystalline graphene structure, led to a substantial enhancement of 109% in chloride binding content compared to the blank group [29]. Furthermore, N-doped CDs resulted in a significant improvement of 134% in the content of chloride binding for cement pastes [30]. Hence, CDs have demonstrated an enormous potential for boosting the chloride binding behaviors of cement.

This work controllably synthesizes green CDs with three kinds of sizes, comprehensively investigates their effect on chloride binding ability of cement, and deeply discloses the underlying mechanism.
Claim_set.Claim: CDs significantly enhance chloride binding capacity of cement, with N-doped CDs showing a 134% improvement.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of chloride binding in cement.

Claim_set.text: The phenothiazine (PTZ) based PTZ-CPA, carrying a cyanovinyl phosphonic acid (CPA) group, forms a superwetting hole-selective underlayer that enables facile deposition of highquality FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films. Compared to a previously established carbazole-based hole-selective material (2-(3,6-dimethoxy-9 H -carbazol-9-yl)ethyl)phosphonic acid (MeO-2PACz), the crystallinity of FAPbI$_{3}$ is enhanced and the electronic defects are passivated by the PTZ-CPA more effectively, resulting in remarkable increases in photoluminescence quantum yield (four-fold) and Shockley-ReadHall lifetime (eight-fold).
Claim_set.Claim: PTZ-CPA, a phenothiazine derivative, enhances the crystallinity and passivates defects in FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films more effectively than MeO-2PACz, leading to significant improvements in photoluminescence quantum yield and Shockley-Read-Hall lifetime.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced Crystallinity and Defect Passivation in FAPbI$_{3}$ Thin Films

Claim_set.text: The PTZ based PTZ-CPA, carrying a cyanovinyl phosphonic acid (CPA) group, forms a superwetting holeselective underlayer that enables facile deposition of high-quality FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films. Compared to MeO-2PACz, the crystallinity of FAPbI$_{3}$ is enhanced and the electronic defects are more efficiently passivated by the PTZ-CPA, resulting in remarkable increases in photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY, four-fold) and Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) lifetime (eight-fold). Moreover, the PTZ-CPA shows a larger molecular dipole moment and improved energy level alignment with FAPbI$_{3}$, benefiting the interfacial hole-collection.
Claim_set.Claim: PTZ-CPA enhances crystallinity and passivates defects in FAPbI$_{3}$ thin films, leading to increased PLQY and SRH lifetime.
Claim_set.Topic: Perovskite thin film enhancement

Claim_set.text:
Three possible reasons are proposed for the suppressed non-radiative recombination by PTZ-CPA: first, the higher wetting character of PTZ-CPA improves perovskite crystallinity and interfacial contact; second, the PTZ-CPA with multiple functional groups (phosphonic acid, cyano group and sulfur atom) passivates the defects at the buried interface and the bulk of FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite more effectively; and third, the optimized energy level alignment between PTZ-CPA and FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite.

Proton nuclear magnetic resonance ($^{1}$H NMR) and XPS measurements were performed to identify the molecular interactions.
Claim_set.Claim: PTZ-CPA suppresses non-radiative recombination in FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite through improved crystallinity, effective defect passivation, and optimized energy level alignment.
Claim_set.Topic: Suppressed non-radiative recombination in perovskite materials

Claim_set.text:
## 4. CONCLUSIONS

The ternary composite Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 was designed and fabricated, and its photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates under UV, simulated sunlight, and visible illumination were improved by 2.1-, 99.8-, and ∞ -fold, respectively, relative to unmodified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$. This is a huge enhancement compared to other Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalysts of similar composition reported in the literature, which is mainly attributed to the spatial separation of photogenerated charges by Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ acting as a bridge between modified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and Au particles, the multifunctional property of Au.
Claim_set.Claim: The ternary composite Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 demonstrates significantly enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates under various light conditions, outperforming unmodified g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and other similar Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalysts, due to the effective spatial separation of photogenerated charges by Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ acting as a bridge and the multifunctional property of Au.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution Rates

Claim_set.text: The role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in assisting electron transfer in the composites and the role of Au in enhancing photocatalytic performance and photocatalytic stability are highlighted here. Such new synergistic effects in the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite photocatalyst are supported by photoelectrochemical tests, DFT calculations, and photocatalytic control experiments. Moreover, this ternary composite photocatalyst exhibits excellent sustained hydrogen evolution performance. Our work provides a practical strategy to enhance the visible light photocatalytic activity and improve the photostability of the MXene-containing photocatalyst. However, the complexity of the preparation process of this composite photocatalyst and the need for further simplification of the synthesis as well as its photostability still have room for improvement, and subsequent work can be devoted to solving these problems.
Claim_set.Claim: The Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite photocatalyst exhibits excellent sustained hydrogen evolution performance due to the synergistic effects of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in assisting electron transfer and Au in enhancing photocatalytic performance and stability, supported by various tests and calculations.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing visible light photocatalytic activity and photostability of MXene-containing photocatalyst

Claim_set.text:
Based on the results of the high enhancement multiplier of Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 relative to the photocatalytic performance of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$, we can conclude that the strategy of integrating Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$, Au, and CN-150 into a composite photocatalyst is successful and excellent. It should also be noted that the absolute values of the hydrogen evolution rates and the AQY@ 420 nm of the photocatalysts in this paper are still moderate compared with those of similar composites, which indicates that subsequent studies can be deepened in the preparation of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ to further enhance the photocatalytic activity.

3.5. Photocatalytic Mechanism.
Claim_set.Claim: The strategy of integrating Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$, Au, and CN-150 into a composite photocatalyst is successful and excellent, leading to a high enhancement multiplier of Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 relative to the photocatalytic performance of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of photocatalytic performance

The prepared PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel exhibited superhydrophobic and superoleophilic features, making it suitable for selective oil absorption in oil/water separation, as demonstrated in Fig. 6. The selective oil absorption capacity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel was evaluated using a low-density oil model (n-hexane dyed with Sudan III) and a high-density oil model (dichloromethane dyed with Sudan III). As shown in Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: The PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel exhibits superhydrophobic and superoleophilic features, making it suitable for selective oil absorption in oil/water separation.
Claim_set.Topic: Selective oil absorption in oil/water separation

Claim_set.text:
Not only does this aerogel exhibit outstanding oil/water separation

Fig. 10. (a) Adsorption efficiency of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel on other multi-class emerging pollutants. (b) The comparison of comprehensive performance of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel with the superhydrophobic materials reported.

capabilities, but it also demonstrates a host of other functionalities, such as the adsorption of MPs, antibiotics, microplastic derivatives, anionic dyes, and cationic dyes. In addition, it displays photothermal conversion performance and magnetism, as illustrated in Fig. 10(b).

## 4.
Claim_set.Claim: PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel exhibits outstanding oil/water separation capabilities and a host of other functionalities, including the adsorption of MPs, antibiotics, microplastic derivatives, anionic dyes, cationic dyes, photothermal conversion performance, and magnetism.
Claim_set.Topic: Advanced materials for oil/water separation and pollutant adsorption

Claim_set.text:
Due to its magnetic-responsive properties and photothermal conversion capabilities, the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel autonomously absorbs oil under magnetic control, enabling its effective deployment in the treatment of high-viscosity oils and facilitating separation and recovery process. Meanwhile, continuous oil/water separation was achieved through gravity or with the assistance of a peristaltic pump. In addition, various kinds of emerging pollutants, especially MPs, were efficiently captured from the aqueous solution using the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel. As a result, the sustainable PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel is considered an appealing option for large-scale purification of wastewater.

Claim_set.text:
The introduction of Mn clusters broke the planar structure of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$through axial traction, further altering the electron configuration around the active sites and effectively decreasing the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and reaction energy barriers, leading to increased intrinsic activity, which greatly improved the ORR performance (E$_{1/2 }$ = 0.91 V). This work presented a novel way of regulating the electronic structure of homonuclear double single-atom sites by clusters.

## 1.
Claim_set.Claim: The introduction of Mn clusters alters the electron configuration around active sites, decreasing adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and reaction energy barriers, thereby increasing intrinsic activity and improving ORR performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Regulation of electronic structure in homonuclear double single-atom sites

Claim_set.text: After Mn clusters were introduced, due to the decrease in the adsorption of OH*, the reaction energy barrier in this step decreased, thereby accelerating the ORR. Schematic diagrams (Fig. 1g and Fig. S6 -9) of the dynamic changes in the bond lengths of OOH*, O*, and OH* in the ORR pathway for Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, Mn$_{DAC}$N-C, and Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C were calculated separately, and the change in free energy in each step of the ORR at 0 V was recorded.
Claim_set.Claim: Introduction of Mn clusters decreases adsorption of OH*, reducing reaction energy barrier and accelerating the ORR.
Claim_set.Topic: Acceleration of ORR through decreased OH* adsorption

Claim_set.text: The DFT calculations showed that Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$axially pulled by Mn clusters was the main active site, which presented a strong adsorption capacity for O$_{2}$, and could rapidly capture O$_{2 }$during the ORR process. The Mn clusters can further modify the electronic distribution and geometric structure of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6}$. This process reduced the adsorption strength of the oxygencontaining intermediate at the active site and lowered the reaction energy barrier of the determining-rate step, thus enhancing the ORR performance. The Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst exhibited excellent ORR performance under alkaline conditions (E$_{1/2 }$ = 0.91 V), which was greater than that of commercial Pt/C (0.86 V).
Claim_set.Claim: Mn clusters enhance the ORR performance of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6}$ by modifying its electronic distribution and geometric structure, reducing the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and lowering the reaction energy barrier.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of ORR performance by Mn clusters

Claim_set.text: Notably, the CZO piezocatalyst maintains its H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ generation capability even after multiple cycles, showing continuous improvement (from 1.3 mM to 1.8 mM). This is attributed to the piezoelectric electrons promoting the generation of dynamic defects under US conditions, which in turn promotes the adsorption and activation of oxygen, thereby facilitating efficient H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production, as confirmed by EPR spectrometry, XPS analysis, and DFT calculations. Moreover, the CZO piezocatalysts maintain outstanding performance in pollutant degradation and H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production even after long periods of inactivity, and the deactivated catalyst due to metal ion dissolution could be rejuvenated by pH adjustment, offering a sustainable solution for wastewater purification.
Claim_set.Claim: CZO piezocatalysts exhibit continuous improvement in H2O2 generation over multiple cycles, attributed to dynamic defect generation facilitated by piezoelectric electrons under ultrasonic conditions, leading to enhanced oxygen adsorption and activation for efficient H2O2 production.
Claim_set.Topic: Piezocatalytic H2O2 generation and pollutant degradation.

Claim_set.text:
More importantly, the catalysts placed for longer periods (over 2 mo) continue to perform superior H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production ( ~ 1.2 mM) and contaminant removal capabilities. This observation not only underscores the substantial potential of CZO piezocatalysts in practical wastewater treatment applications but also serves as a reference for future studies on improving H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production by facilitating the generation of dynamic vacancies through metal deposition.

Fig. 6. ( A ) Removal efficiencies and the corresponding k$_{obs}$ value of phenol oxidation (US for 3 h) in the presence of different water quality constituents [(anion) = 10 mg L$^{-1}$, (DOM) = 10 mg L$^{-1}$]; ( B ) under US irradiation,
Claim_set.Claim: CZO piezocatalysts demonstrate superior H2O2 production and contaminant removal capabilities over extended periods, highlighting their potential in wastewater treatment and serving as a reference for future studies on enhancing H2O2 production through dynamic vacancy generation via metal deposition.
Claim_set.Topic: H2O2 production and contaminant removal in wastewater treatment

Claim_set.text: This catalyst exhibited excel­ lent capability for refractory pollutants removal and notable non -sacrificial H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production (pure water). After 3 h of US treatment, the removal rate of phenol reached 99% and H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production yield reached 1.3 mM. Experiments and characteri­ zation technique were both employed to explore the mechanism. It was found that CZO piezocatalyst could be used as an excellent heterogeneous catalyst for H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ generation and activation attrib­ uted to the dynamic defects in the process of US. Moreover, the generation of dynamic defects contributed to the stability and long -term degradation performance of the catalyst.
Claim_set.Claim: CZO piezocatalyst exhibits excellent capability for refractory pollutants removal and notable non-sacrificial H2O2 production in pure water, achieving a phenol removal rate of 99% and H2O2 production yield of 1.3 mM after 3 hours of ultrasound treatment.
Claim_set.Topic: Non-sacrificial H2O2 production and pollutant removal by CZO piezocatalyst under ultrasound treatment

Claim_set.text: The MPs adsorption capacity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel for MPs increases with increasing MPs concentration until the adsorption sites on PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel are completely occupied to reach adsorption saturation (Fig. S6(a)). Langmuir and Freundlich sorption isotherm models were implemented to describe the adsorption process of MPs (Fig. S6(b-d)). The data of Table S2 indicates that the Langmuir model has significantly higher correlation coefficient R 2 values than the Freundlich model. Consequently, the Langmuir model is more appropriate for describing this adsorption process. The analysis result indicate that MPs adsorption is a homogeneous process involving a single-molecule layer adsorption [21].
Claim_set.Claim: The MPs adsorption capacity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel increases with MPs concentration until adsorption sites are fully occupied, reaching saturation. The Langmuir model, with higher R² values than the Freundlich model, best describes the adsorption process, indicating a homogeneous, single-molecule layer adsorption.
Claim_set.Topic: MPs adsorption capacity and saturation in PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel

## 3.7.2. Adsorption kinetics

The evaluation of adsorbent performance and understanding of the adsorption process is highly dependent on the measurement of adsorption rate. The aim of this study was to investigate the rate and mechanism of MPs adsorption by PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel. Multiple experimental results were obtained at different time points. The experimental data was fitted using three kinetic models, including pseudofirst-order, pseudo-second-order kinetics, and intra-particle diffusion models. The necessary parameter values were then calculated using equations [21]:

A continuous device for separating oil and water was established, utilizing a peristaltic pump to evaluate its efficiency.

Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption kinetics of microplastics (MPs)

## 3.3. Performance of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3-based ZABs

ZABs using Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 as an air cathode catalyst were assembled to investigate the performance of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 in practical applications. The aqueous ZABs based on Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@NC-0.3 produced a high open circuit potential (OCP) of 1.45 V and a peak power density of 191 mW cm - 2 (Fig. 5a and b), exceeding those of Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$-based ZABs (1.42 V, 99 mW cm - $^{2}$).
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 demonstrates superior performance in ZABs, achieving higher OCP and power density than Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Performance of air cathode catalysts in Zinc-Air Batteries (ZABs)

Claim_set.text:
|

voltage gap of 0.70 V is shown for Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3-based ZABs, while the initial voltage gap of ZABs based on Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$ is 0.83 V. A  er 345 h of cycling test, the voltage gap of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@NC-0.3-based ZABs becomes 0.73 V, and the voltage loss in the test is only 0.03 V, indicating that the battery has high energy efficiency. However, the voltage gap of Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$-based ZABs increased by 0.66 V a  er the cycling test for 260 h, suggesting serious performance degradation.
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3-based ZABs exhibit a lower voltage gap and higher energy efficiency compared to Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$-based ZABs, withstanding cycling tests better.
Claim_set.Topic: Performance and Energy Efficiency of ZABs (Zinc-Air Batteries)

Claim_set.text: At 5 mA cm - $^{2}$, the  exible ZABs based on Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 achieve an outstanding cycle stability of 50 h (Fig. 5g). However, the  exible ZABs based on Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$ have a sharp increase in the voltage gap within ∼ 18 h. This stark contrast demonstrates that Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 has more prominent long-term stability and reversibility than Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$.
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 exhibits superior cycle stability and reversibility compared to Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$ in flexible ZABs at 5 mA cm$^{-2}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced performance of flexible Zinc-Air Batteries (ZABs)

Claim_set.text: Furthermore, the Zn//Zn cells employing Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte demonstrate exceptional long-term cycling stability exceeding 4000 h at a current density of 1 mA cm - 2 and capacity of 1 mA h cm - $^{2}$, as depicted in Figure 5 d and Figure S15 . As can be seen, the cyclic performance of the symmetric battery was improved to varying degrees in the presence of Gln. However, when the amount of Gln added is less than 300 mM, it is insufficient to effectively promote stable SEI generation and achieve a sustained and effective protective effect. When the addition amount reaches 300 mM, the performance observed is approximately 40 times higher than that observed in symmetric cells utilizing ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte.
Claim_set.Claim: Zn//Zn cells with Gln/ZnSO₄ electrolyte exhibit outstanding long-term cycling stability, achieving over 4000 hours at 1 mA cm⁻² and 1 mAh cm⁻².

Claim_set.text:
Importantly,

the Zn//Zn pouch symmetric cells (3 × 5 cm - 2 Zn foils) employing Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibited cycling stability over 1200 h and cumulative capacity exceeding 18,000 mA h at both current densities of 1 mA cm - 2 and 1 mA h cm - 2 ( Figure 5 g), surpassing those with ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte. The above analysis evaluates the potential practical applicability of the current system in challenging environments. To further emphasize the efficacy of Gln additives, we also conducted a performance comparison of Zn//Zn symmetric cells with other reported strategies.
Claim_set.Claim: The Zn//Zn pouch symmetric cells using Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte demonstrated superior cycling stability and cumulative capacity compared to cells with ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte, cycling for over 1200 hours and achieving a capacity exceeding 18,000 mA h at current densities of 1 mA cm - 2 and 1 mA h cm - 2.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced performance of Zn//Zn pouch symmetric cells with Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte

Claim_set.text: The initial CV curves of the Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells in different electrolytes exhibited a similar shape ( Figure S17 ), indicating that Gln was unreactive during the electrochemical process. The durability of the full cells was evaluated by conducting self-discharge performance tests in different electrolytes, as shown in Figure 6 a,b. Impressively, after a 48 h rest period, the full cell utilizing Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte demonstrated a capacity retention of 96%, surpassing that of the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte (81% capacity retention).
Claim_set.Claim: The full cells utilizing Gln/ZnSO₄ electrolyte demonstrated superior capacity retention of 96% after a 48 h rest period, outperforming the ZnSO₄ electrolyte with 81% capacity retention.

Claim_set.text: The defect level of the samples was revealed by Raman spectroscopy. Peaks located near 1350 and 1574 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$in the carbon material can be assigned to the D band of disordered carbon and the G band of graphitic carbon. In general, the higher the intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (I$_{D}$/I$_{G}$), the higher the defect level of the sample. As shown in Fig. 1c, with increasing temperature, the I$_{D}$/I$_{G }$ of samples initially increased and then decreased. FSBC-800 has the highest I$_{D}$/I$_{G }$ ratio, which is 1.11, indicating that FSBC-800 has the most defect sites.

Claim_set.text:
According to our previous work, the morphology of the perovskite near the bottom interface plays an important role in affecting optoelectronic properties of perovskite and device performance.$^{[14]}$ We peeled off the perovskite films with an epoxy

encapsulant and carefully characterized the morphology of the exposed bottom surface. Both of the two bottom surfaces showed compact and homogeneous morphology without observable voids or pinholes (Figure 2f). The bottom surface of PTZ-CPA based FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite films exhibited enlarged grain size. These results suggest that the use of PTZ-CPA as HTL substantially improves the FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite film quality, which could benefit solar cell performance through minimized interfacial non-radiative recombination.
Claim_set.Claim: The use of PTZ-CPA as HTL substantially improves the FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite film quality, which could benefit solar cell performance through minimized interfacial non-radiative recombination.
Claim_set.Topic: The role of perovskite morphology in optoelectronic properties and device performance

Claim_set.text: We also employed PTZ-CPA as HTL for other perovskite compositions, including a triple-cation perovskite (1.56 eV) of Cs$_{0.05}$(FA$_{0.95}$MA$_{0.05}$)$_{0.95}$Pb(I$_{0.95}$Br$_{0.05}$)$_{3}$ and a wide-bandgap perovskite (1.68 eV) of Cs$_{0.05}$(FA$_{0.77}$MA$_{0.23}$)$_{0.95}$Pb(I$_{0.77}$Br$_{0.23}$)$_{3}$. These devices show decent photovoltaic performance (Figure S28 and Table S6), suggesting a broad application potential of this new molecular hole-transporter.
Claim_set.Claim: PTZ-CPA as HTL enhances photovoltaic performance in various perovskite compositions.
Claim_set.Topic: Molecular hole-transporter for perovskite solar cells

Claim_set.text:
The PTZ-CPA based HTL shows a smaller contact angle than that of MeO-2PACz (5.5$^{o}$ versus 9.3$^{o}$, Figure S13). This can be attributed to the enhanced

## RESEARCH ARTICLE

amphiphilicity of the CPA-based PTZ-CPA and its bilayer stacking on the ITO substrates, i.e. a chemically anchored monolayer plus an unadsorbed overlayer as revealed in our previous work. [14] During the perovskite film-forming, the unadsorbed PTZ-CPA molecules could be dissolved into the perovskite precursor solution, and the chemically anchored monolayer will be preserved as an ultrathin hole-selective contact.
Claim_set.Claim: PTZ-CPA based HTL demonstrates enhanced amphiphilicity and bilayer stacking on ITO substrates, facilitating efficient perovskite film formation.
Claim_set.Topic: Hole Transport Layer (HTL) Material for Perovskite Films

Claim_set.text:
## 3. Conclusion

In conclusion, based on DFT calculations, we designed a method for the in situ fabrication of NiCo-Sv-x nanosheets on flexible carbon cloth using NiCo-MOF as a precursor. Benefiting from the layered porous structure and sulfur vacancies, NiCo-Sv-4.2% nanosheets show high electronic conductivity and excellent electrochemical performance (With a high specific capacitance of 511.1 mA h g - 1 at 1 A g - 1 and a low overpotential of 317 mV at 50 mA cm - $^{2}$). The vacancy modulation of NiCo-Sv-4.2% resulted in a stable operation at 1.567 V for 32 h without significant decay in the i -t curve.
Claim_set.Claim: NiCo-Sv-4.2% nanosheets exhibit high electronic conductivity and excellent electrochemical performance, with a specific capacitance of 511.1 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 and an overpotential of 317 mV at 50 mA cm^-2.
Claim_set.Topic: In situ fabrication of NiCo-Sv-x nanosheets for electrochemical performance.

On the other hand, the NiCo-Sv-4.2%

electrode showed excellent electrocatalytic activity with the lowest overpotential of 317 mV at a current density of 50 mA cm - $^{2}$.

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

A series of Tb 3 + substituted layered perovskite Sr(La$_{1-}$$_{x}$Tb$_{x}$)AlO$_{4 }$ ( x = 0 -1) was synthesized via solid-state reaction. The influence of Tb 3 + on the phase, structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties of the SrLaAlO$_{4 }$product was investigated. The fully substituted product SrTbAlO$_{4 }$was found to be isostructural with its SrLaAlO$_{4 }$counterpart, and the crystal structure parameters were first reported in this work.
Claim_set.Claim: Tb^3+ substitution in SrLaAlO4 influences its phase, structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties.
Claim_set.Topic: Tb^3+ substitution in layered perovskite SrLaAlO4

Claim_set.text:
Aluminates have excellent chemical and thermal stability, and layered perovskites aluminates SrLaAlO$_{4 }$ have extra advantages of environmental friendliness and cheap raw materials. Therefore, in this work, SrLaAlO$_{4 }$ was selected as the host for the design of photoluminescence and long afterglow material. A series of Tb 3 + substituted SrLaAlO$_{4 }$materials were prepared by solid-state reaction. The influence of Tb 3 + substitution on the phase, crystal structure, photoluminescence, and long afterglow properties of SrLaAlO$_{4 }$were systematically investigated. The luminescence mechanism was proposed. We believe this work is important for studying the long afterglow luminescence of layered perovskites.

## 2.
Claim_set.Claim: Tb3+ substituted SrLaAlO4 materials exhibit excellent photoluminescence and long afterglow properties, making them environmentally friendly and cost-effective for luminescent material applications.
Claim_set.Topic: Photoluminescence and long afterglow properties of layered perovskite aluminates

Claim_set.text: Photoluminescence investigation found that benefiting from the unique layered crystal structure, the activator Tb 3 + was well separated and the optimal doping concentration was found to be as high as 20 at%. Except for photoluminescence, the products simultaneously show long afterglow properties due to disorder cations distribution in the local structure and thus induced defect condition. When the UV light source is turned off, the afterglow luminescence of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: 0.03 Tb 3 + can last over 1 h. The trap distribution of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: Tb 3 + was analyzed in detail by thermoluminescence. The trap depth is calculated to be around 0.7 -0.81 eV, the value of which highly coincides with the ideal energy level for trapping and releasing electrons at room temperature.
Claim_set.Claim: The unique layered crystal structure of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: Tb$^{3+}$ allows for high doping concentrations of Tb$^{3+}$, leading to both photoluminescence and long afterglow properties.
Claim_set.Topic: Photoluminescence and Afterglow Properties of Layered Crystal Structure

Additionally, in the face of acidic, saline, and alkaline environments and harsh separation objects, it can still maintain remarkable stability and separation performance.
Claim_set.Claim: The MCOOH-CaTS/CO$_{3 }$ membrane, with a robust hydrogel coating, exhibits excellent wettability and anti-oil adhesion properties, enabling it to separate surfactant-stabilized emulsions with high permeability and efficiency, and maintain remarkable stability and separation performance in various harsh environments.

Excellent wettability properties are a precursor condition for emulsion separation, and are also a direct reflection of the firmness of the hydration layer on the membrane surface under the hydrogel coating build. Therefore, the wettability performance of the membrane was evaluated by measuring underwater oil contact angles (CAs), sliding angles (SAs), and anti-oil adhesion tests. Firstly, the underwater CAs and SAs of the membrane were measured with different viscosity oil phases. As illustrated in Fig.

## 2. Results and Discussion

## 2.1. DFT Calculations of Sulfur Vacancies

We designed and predicted a novel structural model of NiCo-Sv-x using DFT calculations. The potential effect of different concentrations of sulfur vacancies on the electrochemical properties of NiCo-S was verified by DFT calculations.

[51] It was observed that the NiCo-Sv-4.2% electrode had the highest OER activity at lower starting overpotential values compared to all other electrodes. The Tafel slopes for all electrodes were derived from the Tafel equation ( 𝜂 = b log j + a , where j is the current density and b is the Tafel slope) for exploring the kinetics of catalytic reactions.
Claim_set.Claim: The NiCo-Sv-4.2% electrode demonstrated superior OER activity at lower overpotentials compared to other electrodes, attributed to the oxidation of Ni and/or Co species.

The LSV curve of NiCo-Sv-4.2% after the i--t test was consistent with that before the i -t test (inset of Figure 6e), which also illustrated the catalytic stability.

Claim_set.text: In this assembly, a strong internal electric field is created in highly coupled MnO$_{2}$/Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$on ACC surface, which can greatly facilitate the separation and transmission of photogenerated carriers. Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced photocatalytic efficiency through internal electric field and material coupling.

As a result, the constructed A-NiMoO-P shows excellent HER performance featuring an ultra-low overpotential of 340 mV to reach 1500 mA cm - 2 and outstanding durability for at least 1000 h at an industrial-applicable current density of ≈ 900 mA cm - $^{2}$.The result of quasi in situ Raman spectroscopy confirms the changes of MoO$_{x}$ phase structure on the catalyst surface and the appearance of Ni(PO$_{3}$)$_{2}$, consolidating the surface reconstruction of the

Claim_set.text: Among all the prepared samples, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 had the lowest Tafel slope (88.1 mV dec - $^{1}$), followed by Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.1 (90.9 mV dec - $^{1}$) and Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.5 (94.3 mV dec - $^{1}$) (Fig. 4b and Table S1 † ). These data con  rm that the FeCo alloy and M-N$_{x}$ sites (FeCo/M-N$_{x}$) synergically improve the reaction kinetics of the ORR.
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 had the lowest Tafel slope (88.1 mV dec - $^{1}$), indicating improved ORR reaction kinetics due to the synergy between FeCo alloy and M-N$_{x}$ sites.
Claim_set.Topic: ORR reaction kinetics improvement

Claim_set.text: Notably, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 has the highest OER activity, meaning that the balance between the alloy and SSA is useful for improving the OER performance. Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 has the smallest Tafel slope (87.7 mV dec - $^{1}$) among all samples, which con  rms that the OER of the catalyst is optimized when the amount of FeCo alloy in the Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 sample is in equilibrium with the speci  c surface area (Fig. 4f).
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 exhibits the highest OER activity due to the optimized balance between FeCo alloy content and specific surface area, resulting in the smallest Tafel slope of 87.7 mV dec$^{-1}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Optimization of OER performance in FeCo alloy-based catalysts

Claim_set.text: It is expected that the Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst has excellent ORR and OER activities for the following reasons: (1) the FeCo alloy has high structural activity, especially for the OER; (2) the FeCo alloy has a strong synergistic effect with the carbon skeleton, which can optimize the electronic structure; (3) the balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material can increase the density and exposure of the active sites. In fact, Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 displays extraordinary bifunctional electrocatalytic performance with a small D E of 0.686 V, which was better than the value reported in lots of studies.
Claim_set.Claim: The Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst exhibits excellent ORR and OER activities due to the structural activity and synergistic effect of the FeCo alloy with the carbon skeleton, and the optimized balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material.
Claim_set.Topic: Bifunctional electrocatalytic performance for ORR and OER

Claim_set.text: Table S2 compares FeCo/PCNs catalysts with recently reported non-precious metal catalysts. FeCo/PCNs catalyst shows comparable or even better performance. In addition, the OER activity of individual PCNs was very low, but the OER activity was significantly improved with the cooperation of FeCo alloy. As previously reported, FeCo alloy embedded in PCNs skeleton can adjust the electronic structure of the host, promote charge transfer between Fe and Co components, and form hydroxide on the alloy surface to enhance OER activity. As shown in Fig. 5d and Fig. S9, FeCo/PCNs has the smallest semicircular diameter, indicating that it has the smallest impedance, which further proves that FeCo alloy can effectually promote charge transfer after incorporation into PCNs skeleton. Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: FeCo/PCNs catalysts show comparable or even better performance than recently reported non-precious metal catalysts, with significantly improved OER activity due to the cooperation of FeCo alloy.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst performance and OER activity enhancement

Claim_set.text: In addition, the total voltage gap between the oxygen evolution reaction and oxygen reduction reaction ( Δ E = E$_{j }$ = $_{10 }$- E$_{1/2}$) was used to estimate the ORR/OER bifunctional activity of the catalyst. As depicted in Fig. 5f, Δ E of FeCo/PCNs is 0.669 V, lower than precious metal catalyst (0.717 V), indicating that FeCo/ PCNs have excellent bifunctional activity [43]. The FeCo/PCNs catalysts show excellent electrocatalytic activity for catalyzing ORR and OER.
Claim_set.Claim: FeCo/PCNs exhibit superior bifunctional activity for ORR and OER, outperforming precious metal catalysts with a lower total voltage gap.
Claim_set.Topic: ORR/OER bifunctional activity

Claim_set.text: The synthesized catalyst demonstrated exceptional bifunctional activity. In the ORR test, the E$_{1/2 }$was 0.905 V, while the overpotential at 10 mA cm GLYPH<0> $^{2 }$current density (E$_{j }$ = $_{10}$) in the OER test was 344 mV. The results were improved as compared to commercial Pt/C (E$_{1/2 }$ = 0.864 V) and RuO$_{2 }$ (E$_{j }$ = 10 = 351 mV). Furthermore, when being assembled as a zinc-air battery, FeCo/PCNs outperformed Pt/C + RuO$_{2}$, with more stable cycle performance.
Claim_set.Claim: The synthesized catalyst, FeCo/PCNs, demonstrated exceptional bifunctional activity with improved performance in both ORR and OER tests compared to commercial Pt/C and RuO$_2$.
Claim_set.Topic: Bifunctional Catalyst Performance in Electrochemical Reactions

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Herein, a novel dual-mode probe for organophosphorus pesticides (OPs) colorimetric and photothermal detection was developed based on manganese modified porphyrin metal -organic framework (PCN-224-Mn). PCN-224Mn had excellent oxidase-like activity and oxidized colorless 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) to blue -green oxidation state TMB (oxTMB), which exhibited high temperature under near-infrared irradiation. L-ascorbate-2phosphate was hydrolyzed by acid phosphatase to produce ascorbic acid, which weakened colorimetric and photothermal signals by impacting oxTMB generation.
Claim_set.Claim: PCN-224-Mn MOF exhibits oxidase-like activity and generates a photothermal effect, enabling its use as a dual-mode probe for detecting organophosphorus pesticides.
Claim_set.Topic: Dual-mode detection of organophosphorus pesticides

Claim_set.text:
Inspired by this, the development of an integrated platform for colorimetric and

photothermal reading is expected to achieve visual, portable, and highly sensitive multimode detection of OPs.

Enlightened by the aforementioned work, this study prepared a novel MOF-based nanozyme (PCN-224-Mn) with excellent oxidase-like catalytic activity by coordinating Mn (II) to the porphyrin cavity of PCN-224 composed of zirconium (Zr) clusters and porphyrin ligands. A dual-mode probe for OPs colorimetric and photothermal detection was developed based on the catalytic activity, the competition effect between enzymatic reaction products and substrates, the inhibition of OPs on enzyme activity, and photothermal effect of oxidation products.
Claim_set.Claim: PCN-224-Mn MOF-based nanozyme enables dual-mode probe for OPs colorimetric and photothermal detection.
Claim_set.Topic: Multimode detection of organophosphates (OPs)

Claim_set.text:
## 3.2. Evaluation of oxidase-like activity

As shown in Fig. 2A, neither the TMB solution nor the PCN-224-Mn solution exhibited characteristic absorption peaks in the range of 500 ~ 700 nm. However, when PCN-224-Mn coexisted with TMB, an obvious absorption peak appeared at 652 nm, which was because oxTMB was produced by the catalytic oxidation of PCN-224-Mn to TMB. In addition to TMB, PCN-224-Mn can also catalyze other substrates including OPD and ABTS. As shown in Fig. 2B, in the presence of PCN-224-Mn, the OPD solution and the ABTS solution exhibited obvious absorption peaks at 450 nm and 400 nm. The solutions appeared yellow and blue in daylight, respectively.
Claim_set.Claim: PCN-224-Mn exhibits oxidase-like activity by catalyzing the oxidation of substrates such as TMB, OPD, and ABTS, resulting in characteristic absorption peaks at specific wavelengths.
Claim_set.Topic: Oxidase-like activity of PCN-224-Mn

Claim_set.text: The theoretical calculations and experiments reveal that Gln molecules can effectively regulate the surface absorption environment of the EDL, resulting in a SEI composed of organic Gln and inorganic ZnS components. The SEI exhibits low modulus and hardness properties, which contribute to its exceptional topological adaptability and compatibility with the zinc anode. This allows it to maintain co-type contact with the zinc anode while inhibiting side reactions, thereby providing lasting protection for the zinc anode ( Figure 1 b).
Claim_set.Claim: Gln molecules regulate the surface absorption environment of the EDL, forming a SEI with organic Gln and inorganic ZnS components, which exhibits low modulus and hardness properties, contributing to its exceptional topological adaptability and compatibility with the zinc anode, maintaining co-type contact while inhibiting side reactions, providing lasting protection for the zinc anode.
Claim_set.Topic: Gln-regulated SEI for Zinc Anode Protection

Claim_set.text:
11 , 20 Moreover, the peaks observed in the high-resolution N 1s and Zn 2p XPS spectra ( Figure 2 f,g) provide evidence for the formation of N  Zn/O  Zn bonds between Gln and the Zn surface through amino and carbonyl groups containing nitrogen and oxygen. 11 , 20 , 21 These facts further prove that Gln tightly adsorbs onto the Zn surface through strong coordination and electrostatic interactions between the zinc surface and amino or carbonyl groups. The above analysis shows that the additive can tightly adsorb onto the zinc surface, regulating the EDL structure and creating an optimal environment for stable SEI generation.

We further employed the ion conductivity to investigate the impact of Gln additives on the fundamental properties of electrolytes ( Figure S6 ).
Claim_set.Claim: Gln tightly adsorbs onto the Zn surface through strong coordination and electrostatic interactions between the zinc surface and amino or carbonyl groups, regulating the EDL structure and creating an optimal environment for stable SEI generation.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption of Gln onto Zinc Surface for Stable SEI Generation

Claim_set.text:
Consequently, this leads to the development of a stable SEI film.

To further validate the impact of Gln on SEI formation, XPS depth profiles of Zn anodes were acquired after 20 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm - 2 and a capacity of 1 mA h cm - 2 in a Zn//Zn symmetric cell. The C 1s spectrum ( Figure 4 g) reveals that there is no significant presence of a C  O signal in the pristine state of the zinc anode, as observed when compared to the signal from pristine Gln. However, a

noticeable increase in the C  O signal is observed, indicating the conversion of a fraction of the C  O group into a C  O bond upon interaction with the Zn surface.
Claim_set.Claim: Gln facilitates the formation of a stable Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) film on Zn anodes.
Claim_set.Topic: Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) Formation on Zn Anodes

Claim_set.text:
## 1. Introduction

The development of highly efficient and durable electrocatalysts for accelerated urea kinetics and a reduced energy barrier is deemed imperative, urgently desired to facilitate widespread adoption.[1] An energetic advantage is exhibited by the urea oxidation reaction (UOR), boasting a low thermodynamic equilibrium potential (0.37 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)), notably lower than the conventional oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at 1.23 V. This results in a remarkable 70% theoretical energy saving, positioning it as a promising alternative to the OER for sustainable hydrogen generation.
Claim_set.Claim: The urea oxidation reaction (UOR) exhibits an energetic advantage over the conventional oxygen evolution reaction (OER), offering a remarkable 70% theoretical energy saving, making it a promising alternative for sustainable hydrogen generation.
Claim_set.Topic: Efficient and Durable Electrocatalysts for Accelerated Urea Kinetics

Claim_set.text: Renewable hydrogen energy has been widely concerned and applied in practical production, and water splitting for H$_{2 }$generation is one of the greenest, high-yield and most promising hydrogen production methods among various hydrogen production methods [11 -14]. What is noteworthy is that the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as the half-reaction of water electrolysis, requires complex four-electron transfer and is a slow step in the entire electrochemical process [15 -17]. Considering the low availability of pure water, it is found that the urea oxidation reaction (UOR) requires only the small theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs RHE), which is much lower than the 1.23 V of OER (vs RHE) [18 -20].
Claim_set.Claim: The urea oxidation reaction (UOR) requires only a small theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs RHE), which is much lower than the 1.23 V of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER).
Claim_set.Topic: Renewable Hydrogen Energy Production

Claim_set.text:
## 3.3. Urea oxidation catalysis

At the end of the OER and HER tests, an additional urea oxidation test (UOR) was performed with a complete electrochemical test in 1 M KOH + 0.5 M urea solution. As can be seen in the LSV plot (Fig. 5a), the target catalyst clearly outperforms the remaining catalysts throughout the operating voltage. At a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$, the working potential is only 1.28 V, in which it can be observed that the performance of the CoCOH@NF precursor is not much different from the trend of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@NF.
Claim_set.Claim: The target catalyst demonstrates superior performance in urea oxidation, achieving a low working potential of 1.28 V at a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$ in 1 M KOH + 0.5 M urea solution.
Claim_set.Topic: Urea Oxidation Catalysis

Claim_set.text: As the samples were exposed to the O$_{2}$ atmosphere for 3, 6, 12, and 24 h, the first-charge specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreased rapidly from 681.5 to 271.4, 187.5, 170.0, and 163.9 mAh g - $^{1}$, which correspond to the attenuation rate of 60.2%, 72.5%, and 75.1% and 75.9%, respectively. The decay of the first-charge capacity approached the limit by increasing the exposure time, indicating that there is a time threshold for oxygen influence.
Claim_set.Claim: The first-charge specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreases rapidly when exposed to O$_{2}$ atmosphere, with the decay approaching a limit, indicating a time threshold for oxygen influence.
Claim_set.Topic: Influence of Oxygen Exposure on the First-Charge Specific Capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

Claim_set.text: Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ was then subjected to the CO$_{2}$ atmosphere for 3, 6, 12, and 24 h as seen in Figure 4b. The first chargespecific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreased from 681.5 to 204.6, 129.8, 82.3, and 50.3 mAh g - $^{1}$, corresponding to decay ratios of 69.9%, 80.9%, 87.9% and 92.6%, respectively. The first charge capacity of the material gradually decays with increasing exposure time.
Claim_set.Claim: The first charge-specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ decreases with increasing exposure time to CO$_{2}$, leading to decay ratios of 69.9%, 80.9%, 87.9%, and 92.6% after 3, 6, 12, and 24 hours, respectively.
Claim_set.Topic: Effect of CO$_{2}$ exposure on the charge-specific capacity of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

Claim_set.text: The first charge capacity of the material gradually decays with increasing exposure time. In Figure S7 (Supporting Information), the first charge-specific capacities of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ after 3, 6, 12, and 24 h in the N$_{2}$ atmosphere were nearly the same. It supports that N$_{2}$ has almost no effect on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$. However, LFO exposure to air for 24 h produced significant slurry gelation compared to those not exposed to air, as shown in Figure S8 (Supporting Information). Hence, the electrochemical properties of LFO exposed to air were not performed.
Claim_set.Claim: The first charge-specific capacities of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ after 3, 6, 12, and 24 h in the N$_{2}$ atmosphere were nearly the same, supporting that N$_{2}$ has almost no effect on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Effect of N$_{2}$ atmosphere on the performance of Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Urea electrolysis is an effective way to replace water splitting for H$_{2 }$generation, which is expected to achieve carbon neutralization. However, problems such as high energy consumption and slow urea oxidation kinetics have hindered its rapid development. In this study, a series of foreign element modified NiCoP-based catalysts were in-situ grown on Ni foam through hydrothermal process, solvothermal method and low temperature phosphating method. The morphology of the electrode was regulated by changing the impregnation elements. It was found that Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF has rich active sites and small impedance, which makes it have excellent urea oxidation reaction (UOR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) property.
Claim_set.Claim: Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF exhibits excellent urea oxidation reaction (UOR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) properties due to its rich active sites and small impedance.
Claim_set.Topic: Urea electrolysis for hydrogen generation

Claim_set.text:
## 3.3. Overall urea electrolysis of Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF // Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF

In order to investigate the potential of the prepared catalysts in practical production, we assembled a small electrolyser for urea electrolysis by using Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF catalysts with excellent UOR and HER activities as anode and cathode, respectively. The overall urea electrolysis activity was researched by a two-electrode device in the above electrolyte, which exhibited highly efficient H$_{2 }$generation from urea splitting (Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF catalysts exhibit excellent UOR and HER activities, making them highly efficient for H$_{2}$ generation from urea splitting in a small electrolyser.
Claim_set.Topic: Overall urea electrolysis for H$_{2}$ generation

Claim_set.text: Comparing the hybrid structure with the single structure, Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP exhibits excellent multifunctional catalytic activity in alkaline seawater and urea. In the oxygen evolution reaction, the working potential is only 1.60 V and 1.70 V at a current density of 50 mA/cm$^{2 }$and 100 mA/cm$^{2}$. And in the hydrogen evolution reaction, the working potential was only GLYPH<0> 0.16 V at a current density of GLYPH<0> 10 mA/cm$^{2}$, demonstrating excellent bifunctional activity. On this basis, the catalyst also demonstrated excellent activity for urea oxidation reaction in alkaline environment, with an operating potential of only 1.28 V at a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$.
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP exhibits excellent multifunctional catalytic activity in alkaline seawater and urea, with low working potentials for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and urea oxidation reactions.
Claim_set.Topic: Multifunctional catalytic activity in alkaline seawater and urea.

Claim_set.text:
In this study, we introduce L-glutamine (Gln) as an additive to regulate the adsorbed environment of the EDL and in situ produce a hybrid SEI consisting of ZnS and Gln-related species. The results of the nanoindentation test indicate that the hybrid SEI exhibits

Supporting Information

a low modulus and low hardness, alongside exceptional shape recovery capability, which effectively limits side reactions and enables topological adaptation to volume fluctuations in zinc anodes during zinc ion plating/stripping, thereby enabling Zn// Zn symmetric cells to exhibit an ultralong cycle life of 4000 h in coin cells and a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h in pouch cells.
Claim_set.Claim: The hybrid SEI consisting of ZnS and Gln-related species effectively limits side reactions and enables topological adaptation to volume fluctuations in zinc anodes during zinc ion plating/stripping, thereby enabling Zn// Zn symmetric cells to exhibit an ultralong cycle life of 4000 h in coin cells and a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h in pouch cells.
Claim_set.Topic: Regulation of the adsorbed environment of the EDL (Electrical Double Layer) in zinc-ion batteries with L-glutamine (Gln) as an additive.

Claim_set.text: The topologically adaptable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) effectively suppresses side reactions and accommodates volume changes in the zinc anode during zinc ion plating/ stripping, enabling Zn//Zn symmetric cells to demonstrate an exceptionally long cycle life of 4000/1600/1200/300 h at a current density of 1/5/10/20 mA cm - 2 using a coin cell. Additionally, it achieves a high cumulative capacity of 18,000 mA h with a pouch cell. More importantly, the Gln additives have also been demonstrated in Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells at low N/P ratios of 5.2, 4.9, 3.5, and 2.4, which further proves the effectiveness of Gln additive for Zn anode protection.
Claim_set.Claim: The topologically adaptable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) effectively suppresses side reactions and accommodates volume changes in the zinc anode during zinc ion plating/stripping, enabling Zn//Zn symmetric cells to demonstrate an exceptionally long cycle life and high cumulative capacity.
Claim_set.Topic: Zinc Anode Protection in Zinc-Ion Batteries

Claim_set.text: This observation suggests that the SEI formed in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits limited resistance to deformation and fails to maintain intimate contact with the zinc anode during plating/stripping cycles, rendering it susceptible to rupture. In contrast, the SEI formed in Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ demonstrates flexibility, enabling it to accommodate volume changes and consistently establish co-type contact with the zinc anode for continuous and stable protection. In addition, hardness is also an indicator to prove the mechanical properties of materials. 30 As depicted in Figure S14b and Figure 4 l, the hardness of the SEI in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits a significantly higher value compared to that formed in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte.
Claim_set.Claim: The SEI formed in Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte demonstrates flexibility, enabling it to accommodate volume changes and consistently establish co-type contact with the zinc anode for continuous and stable protection.
Claim_set.Topic: Mechanical Properties of SEI in Zinc-based Electrolytes

Claim_set.text: Electrochemical Measurements. All testing CR2032-type coin cells were assembled in an open-air environment by using a glass fiber filter (GF/D, Whatman) as the separator. The electrolyte amount used in coin cells was 100 μ L. Zn//Zn symmetric cells were fabricated by using two identical Zn foils (100 μ m). Zn//Cu asymmetric cells were assembled with Cu foil (30 μ m) as the working electrode and Zn foil (100 μ m) as the reference and counter electrode. Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells were assembled using Zn foil (20 μ m) as the anode and NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ as the cathode.
Claim_set.Claim: Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells were assembled using Zn foil as the anode and NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ as the cathode.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical measurements in coin cell configurations

Claim_set.text: To assemble Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ pouch cells, NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ cathodes (area = 4.5 × 2.5 cm$^{2}$) were coupled with the Zn foil (area = 5 × 3 cm$^{2}$, thickness = 20 μ m) and a glass fiber filter was used as the separator (area = 6 × 4 cm$^{2}$). The discharge/charge measurements of cells were conducted using a LAND Cell Test System. CV curves of the Zn plating/stripping were measured using the Zn//Cu coin cell at a scan rate of 1 mV s - $^{1}$. EIS were recorded with a frequency ranging from 0.1 to 10 6 Hz.

To further enhance zinc utilization and minimize unnecessary zinc loss, we used a thin Zn anode (20 μ m) to investigate Zn//NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells with a low negative/ positive capacity ratio (N/P) ( Figure 6 c - f and Figures S18 and S19 ). The cycling performance of the full cells with a N/P ratio of 4.9 is shown in Figure 6 c. The cell in the ZnSO$_{4}$

electrolyte survives for 1640 cycles at 5 A g - 1 before failure, while the cell in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits stable cycling over 4500 cycles with a high capacity retention of up to 87% (after 100 cycles of activation).
Claim_set.Claim: The use of a thin Zn anode (20 μm) and Gln/ZnSO₄ electrolyte enhances zinc utilization and minimizes loss, enabling stable cycling of Zn//NH₄V₄O₁₀ full cells over 4500 cycles with a high capacity retention of up to 87%.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced zinc utilization and minimized loss in Zn-based batteries

Similarly, after the introduction Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$into MnO$_{x}$, the DMOP-· OH signal of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC was significantly stronger than that of MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.5 under the irradiation for 10 min, indicating MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC generated more electrons and exhibited stronger oxidizing capacity.

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Carbon-based supercapacitors have shown great promise for miniaturized electronics and electric vehicles, but are usually limited by their low volumetric performance, which is largely due to the inefficient utilization of carbon pores in charge storage. Herein, we develop a reliable and scalable boric acid templating technique to prepare boron and oxygen co-modified highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons (BUMCs).
Claim_set.Claim: Boron and oxygen co-modified highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons (BUMCs) prepared using a boric acid templating technique show promise for enhancing the volumetric performance of carbon-based supercapacitors.
Claim_set.Entity: BUMCs (Boron and Oxygen Co-Modified Highly-Dense Yet Ultramicroporous Carbons)
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing Volumetric Performance of Carbon-Based Supercapacitors

Claim_set.text:
## 4. Conclusions

In summary, we prepared highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons with boron/oxygen-enriched surface functionalities by using a unique boric acid templating technique, where the boric acid not only acts as molecular-scale template for the formation of ultramicropores but also serves as in-situ modifier for implantation of profitable functional groups. The addition of ammonia is crucial for the esterification reaction between boric acid and glucose, which lays the foundation for homogeneously implanting of borate ester species into the crosslinked precursor of borated glucose. Our results demonstrated that an unprecedented high volumetric supercapacitive performance can be realized in such compact ultramicroporous carbons. Theoretical and experimental efforts reveal that B-containing groups ( -BC$_{2}$O and -BCO$_{2 }$ etc.)
Claim_set.Claim: Highly-dense yet ultramicroporous carbons with boron/oxygen-enriched surface functionalities were prepared using a unique boric acid templating technique, where boric acid acts as a molecular-scale template for the formation of ultramicropores and serves as an in-situ modifier for implanting profitable functional groups. The addition of ammonia is crucial for the esterification reaction between boric acid and glucose, which lays the foundation for homogeneously implanting borate ester species into the crosslinked precursor of borated glucose. The materials demonstrated an unprecedented high volumetric supercapacitive performance, and theoretical and experimental efforts reveal that B-containing groups play a significant role in this performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Boric acid templating technique for high-performance supercapacitors

Claim_set.text: The carbons are featured with high density (up to 1.62 g cm GLYPH<0> $^{3}$), large specific surface area (up to 1050 m$^{2 }$g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$), narrow pore distribution (0.4 -0.6 nm) and exquisite pore surface functionalities (mainly -BC$_{2}$O, GLYPH<0> BCO$_{2}$, and -COH groups). Consequently, the carbons show exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage. The optimal BUMC-0.5 delivers an outstanding volumetric capacitance of 431 F cm GLYPH<0> 3 and a high-rate capability in 1 M H$_{2}$SO$_{4}$.
Claim_set.Claim: The carbons exhibit exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage due to their high density, large specific surface area, narrow pore distribution, and exquisite pore surface functionalities, resulting in an outstanding volumetric capacitance of 431 F cm^-3 for the optimal BUMC-0.5 in 1 M H2SO4.
Claim_set.Topic: Compact Capacitive Energy Storage

The C-coupled hydroxylated g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ fabricated in this work exhibited superior photo-energy conversion efficiency in photocatalytic H$_{2}$ evolution compared with the reported functional g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$. In photocatalytic systems, pristine BCN still possessed a poor H$_{2}$ evolution efficiency under the dual effects of sacri  cial agents and co-catalysts, indicating that the introduction of the hydroxyl group is the key to improve the photocatalytic activity of samples.

Claim_set.text: Furthermore, according to the comparative experiments, no hydrogen production was found with catalyst-free and visible-light-free systems (Fig. S9 † ), suggesting that the above conditions were necessary to affect the H$_{2}$ evolution rate in the photocatalytic system. Moreover, the H$_{2}$ evolution activity was signi  cantly improved when hydroxyl groups were anchored on the frameworks of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$, proving that the modi  cation of the hydroxyl unit on the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ structure has a positive effect. The stability of the photocatalysts is also an important factor for photocatalytic performance.
Claim_set.Claim: Hydroxyl-modified g-C3N4 significantly improves hydrogen evolution in photocatalytic systems.

Claim_set.text: Fig. 4B exhibited the TRPL curves of the as-fabricated samples. The results demonstrated that the modi  cation of hydroxyl groups retarded the photoinduced charge recombination and enhanced the possibility of carriers participating in the hydrogen production process. EIS and TPR analysis also veri  ed the above speculations. From the water contact angle test, it is noticeable that CN-85-2 exhibited a smaller water contact angle compared to pristine BCN (Fig. 4C), proving that the introduction of hydroxyl groups increased the hydrophilicity of the samples.

4g). In addition, the value of E$_{j}$$_{=}$$_{10}$ for Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 slightly changed a  er 1000 cycles of CV tests (Fig. S7 † ). Claim_set.text:
The reasons for the enhancement of the bifunctional activity of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 include: (1) the FeCo alloy has high structural activity; (2) the strong synergistic effect between the FeCo alloy and carbon skeleton can optimize the electronic structure; (3) the balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material can increase the density and exposure of the active sites.

## 4. Conclusions

In summary, a bifunctional alloy catalyst has been fabricated by encapsulating FeCo alloy nanoparticles into porous hollow carbon cages (Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3).
Claim_set.Claim: The enhancement of the bifunctional activity of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 is attributed to the high structural activity of the FeCo alloy, the synergistic effect between the alloy and carbon skeleton, and the optimized balance between the number of FeCo alloy nanoparticles and the pore volume of the material.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of bifunctional activity in alloy catalysts

Claim_set.text: The synthesized Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C0.3 catalyst exhibits excellent bifunctional catalytic performance activity with a minimal D E value of 0.686 V. The enhancement of catalytic activity and stability of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C0.3 is due to the balance between the content of the FeCo alloy and the porosity of the catalyst. This balance not only helps to improve the density of the FeCo alloy, but also solves the problem of agglomeration and low accessibility of active sites owing to the too small speci  c surface area, consequently improving the activity of the catalyst.
Claim_set.Claim: The synthesized Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C0.3 catalyst exhibits excellent bifunctional catalytic performance activity with a minimal D E value of 0.686 V, attributed to the balance between the content of the FeCo alloy and the porosity of the catalyst.
Claim_set.Topic: Bifunctional catalytic performance of Fe-Co alloy catalysts

## 2. Material and methods

## 2.1. Synthesis of ionic liquids

4-Amino-1-butyl-1,2,4-triazolium bromide (AC$_{4}$trimBr) was obtained by using a slightly modified the literature procedure [36]. A mixture of 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (10 mmol, 840.4 mg) and 1-bromobutane (10 mmol, 1370.2 mg) was refluxed in acetonitrile (20 mL) for 3 days. The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization.
Claim_set.Claim: 4-Amino-1-butyl-1,2,4-triazolium bromide (AC$_{4}$trimBr) was synthesized by a slightly modified literature procedure, involving the reflux of 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole with 1-bromobutane in acetonitrile followed by recrystallization in ethyl acetate.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis of ionic liquids

Claim_set.text:
1-Butyl-4-methyl-1,2,4-triazolium bromide (MC$_{4}$trimBr) was synthesized according to the literature procedure with a slight modification [36]. 4-Methyl-1,2,4-triazole (10 mmol, 830.9 mg) and 1-bromobutane (10 mmol, 1370.1 mg) were dissolved and refluxed in acetonitrile (20 mL) for 3 days. The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization. After filtering the solvent, remove any residual solvent under vacuum to obtain colorless powders (2091 mg, 95 % of yield).

## 2.2.

After filtering the solvent, remove any residual solvent under vacuum to obtain pale-yellow powders (2123 mg, 96 % of yield).

1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BmimBr) was synthesized according to the literature procedure with modifications. To a solution of 1-methylimidazole (10 mmol, 821.1 mg) in acetonitrile (20 mL), 1bromobutane (10 mmol, 1370.1 mg) was added. The solution was stirred and refluxed for 3 days. The solution was concentrated and added to excess cold ethyl acetate (3 -5 times the volume of solution) for recrystallization. After filtering the solvent, remove any residual solvent under vacuum to obtain colorless powders (2126 mg, 97 % of yield).

## 4. Conclusion

In conclusion, Mn-NiFePi nanoparticles with P, N codoped carbon anchored on the surface of P-doped carbonized bacterial cellulose were prepared by pyrolysis of a Mn-NiFe-PBA/BC precursor via in a one-step carbonization-phosphorylation process. The surface electronic structure of MNFP-PNC/PCBC was synergistically optimized by using Mn as a dopant in combination with defects induced by the P-doped carbon. In addition, the PCBC improved the electrical conductivity and provided anchoring sites that enhanced the active sites of the electrocatalyst. This synergistic effect resulted in excellent HER, OER and GCR electrocatalytic activities and stability for MNFP-PNC/PCBC.
Claim_set.Claim: Mn-NiFePi nanoparticles with P, N codoped carbon anchored on the surface of P-doped carbonized bacterial cellulose were prepared by pyrolysis of a Mn-NiFe-PBA/BC precursor via a one-step carbonization-phosphorylation process. The surface electronic structure of MNFP-PNC/PCBC was synergistically optimized by using Mn as a dopant in combination with defects induced by the P-doped carbon. In addition, the PCBC improved the electrical conductivity and provided anchoring sites that enhanced the active sites of the electrocatalyst. This synergistic effect resulted in excellent HER, OER, and GCR electrocatalytic activities and stability for MNFP-PNC/PCBC.
Claim_set.Topic: Synergistic optimization of electrocatalysts for HER, OER, and GCR.

Herein, PBA-derived Mn-doped nickel -iron phosphate embedded in a P, N co doped carbon substrate and grown directly on the surface of Pdoped CBC (MNFP-PNC/PCBC) was prepared for electrocatalytic glucose conversion coupled with hydrogen production by a one-step carbonization-phosphorylation method using bacterial cellulose as the substrate in situ loaded with Mn-doped NiFe-PBA as the precursor (Scheme 1). The precise electronic modulation and structural design of the MNFP-PNC/PCBC enhanced the intrinsic activity and the number of exposed active sites of the catalyst, and provided excellent electrical conductivity and stability by anchoring the nanoactive materials.
Claim_set.Claim: PBA-derived Mn-doped nickel-iron phosphate embedded in a P, N co-doped carbon substrate grown directly on the surface of P-doped CBC (MNFP-PNC/PCBC) was prepared for electrocatalytic glucose conversion coupled with hydrogen production.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing electrocatalytic glucose conversion coupled with hydrogen production
