Claim_set.text:
Specifically, 2.0 H group owns the highest C Fs b of 21.27 mg/g and C CSH b of 6.76 mg/g, increasing by 41.8% and 132.0% separately than C group. This evidences that CDs with the smallest size confer the strongest chloride binding capacity on cement matrices, owing to more production of C -S -H and Ms.

Furthermore, the mass loss peaks within the range of 130 -190 · C and 260 -360 · C are ascribed to the disintegration of Ms and Fs separately [58,59]. Compared to the C group, CDs-modified groups exhibit higher contents of Ms and Fs which increase as the sizes of CDs decrease. This reflects that the smaller sizes of CDs can generate more Ms to react with free chloride ions, thus improving the chemical binding of chloride ions in cement pastes.
Claim_set.Claim: CDs with the smallest size confer the strongest chloride binding capacity on cement matrices, owing to more production of C-S-H and Ms.
Claim_set.Topic: Chloride binding capacity in cement matrices

Claim_set.text:
8). Namely, CDs with smaller sizes can more significantly stimulate the production of C -S -H gels and Ms by their nucleation effect, thus greatly promoting the physical adsorption and chemical binding of cement pastes. On the one hand, according to the previous nucleation mechanism [61], the nucleation effect of CDs can be ascribed to the fact that the hydration products preferentially attach to CDs surface [30], since the nucleation energy on CDs surface is smaller than that in pore solution of cement. This facilitates the crystallization of hydrates. Therefore, CDs can significantly accelerate the hydration of cement. On the other hand, CDs with larger sizes possess a smaller quantity of particles under

the same dosage, consequently causing a decrease of nucleation sites.
Claim_set.Claim: CDs with smaller sizes significantly stimulate the production of C-S-H gels and Ms by their nucleation effect, promoting physical adsorption and chemical binding of cement pastes.
Claim_set.Topic: Nucleation effect in cement hydration

Claim_set.text:
To sum up, the investigation of XRD, DTG, and SEM from diverse specimens prior to and following 14-d immersion demonstrate that CDs with various sizes ranging from 1.73 to 12.37 nm are able to advance the cement hydration to produce more C -S -H gels and Ms, thus enhancing the physical adsorption and chemical binding of chloride ions. Crucially, the relationship between sizes of CDs and phase compositions of cement is disclosed. That is CDs with smaller sizes tend to accelerate cement hydration more strongly, thereby more remarkably enhancing chloride binding of cement system.

## 3.4. Influence mechanism of CDs sizes on chloride binding

According to the systematic analyses above, the effect mechanism of CDs sizes on chloride binding in cement is reasonably proposed (Fig. 8).
Claim_set.Claim: CDs with sizes ranging from 1.73 to 12.37 nm can enhance cement hydration, producing more C-S-H gels and Ms, thus improving chloride ion binding.
Claim_set.Topic: Influence of CDs size on cement hydration and chloride binding

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

The research on the adsorption and conversion of non-polar gases (carbon dioxide, hydrogen, iodine, etc.) has attracted global attention. Extensive work has revealed the intuitive impact of the heteroatom effect on the adsorption performance of covalent organic framework (COF) adsorbents for non-polar gases. However, more influencing factors must be studied to more precisely design and construct target-specific COF adsorbents. In this work, an underlying influencing factor, local polarity, is discovered, which is defined as the polarity of the functional moiety. Due to the substitution of strong electrophile, the electron cloud distribution of the COF framework is regulated, and the local polarity that better matches the adsorption of target electrophilic gas (iodine) has been observed.
Claim_set.Claim: The local polarity of functional moieties in covalent organic frameworks (COFs) can be regulated by the substitution of strong electrophiles, leading to a better match for adsorbing target electrophilic gases such as iodine.
Claim_set.Topic: Influence of Local Polarity on COF Adsorbents

Claim_set.text:
The classic COFs with benzene ring as the main building block has strong aromaticity and conjugation, resulting in uniform electron cloud distribution and no electron-rich moiety. Therefore, its affinity for electrophilic targets (such as iodine molecules) is very weak, indicating poor adsorption performance. Modifying the aromatic frameworks by strong electrophiles and changing its electron cloud distribution to enhance its local electron-rich properties should significantly improve the performance. However, for the precise construction of target-specific COFs, more influencing factors need to be identified.

In this work, we proposed an ionic liquid solution process (ILSP) strategy to post-modify the neutral covalent organic framework TpPaSO$_{3}$H (COF-H) to improve its iodine capture performance (Fig. 1).
Claim_set.Claim: Modifying the aromatic frameworks of COFs with strong electrophiles can enhance their local electron-rich properties, improving their performance for capturing electrophilic targets like iodine molecules.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing COF Performance for Iodine Capture

Claim_set.text: Through in-depth research on the COF structure, it unexpectedly discovered an underlying contribution, local polarity. The increase in local polarity led to stronger interaction between the electro-rich site and iodine, and it was observed that there was a positive correlation between local polarity and adsorption performance. The introduction of electrophile can regulate the local polarity of COF, significantly improving its adsorption performance. The saturated adsorption capacity increased from 1.5 to 5.2 g · g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, and the adsorption kinetics index k$_{80% }$value increased from 0.51 to 2.69 g · g GLYPH<0> $^{1$_{·}$}$h GLYPH<0> $^{1}$. The discovery of contribution of local polarity will provide important fundamental guidance for the precise synthesis of COFs.
Claim_set.Claim: The introduction of electrophile can regulate the local polarity of COF, significantly improving its adsorption performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Contribution of local polarity in COF adsorption performance

Claim_set.text: Additionally, the favorable photo thermal conversion performance played a pivotal role in creating a self-heating adsorbent that facilitated the flow of viscous oil and expedited oil absorption. Fig. 6(d) illustrated the infiltration of viscous peanut oil on the surface of the PDMS@CZIF67/CS aerogel, under varying levels of simulated sunlight irradiation. When there was no simulated sunlight irradiation, it took around 10 s for the oil droplet to become fully absorbed. However, with just one simulated sunlight radiation, the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel was able to fully absorb the same oil droplet within just 3 s (Fig. 6(d) & Video S8), indicating an increase in the penetration rate by nearly 3 times.
Claim_set.Claim: PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel exhibits enhanced oil absorption rate under simulated sunlight irradiation.
Claim_set.Topic: Photo thermal conversion performance in oil absorption.

Claim_set.text: To assess the absorption capacity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel, various typical organic solvents and oils, including engine oil, peanut oil, olive oil, n-hexane, N,N-dimethylformamide, dichloromethane, chloroform, ethyl acetate were tested. The aerogel exhibited an absorption capacity of between 4,000 and 10,000 mg g GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$for the specified oils and solvents, with peanut oil absorption reaching ten times of its own weight. The difference in oil absorption capacity depended on the density and viscosity of the absorbed organic solvent and oil, as shown in Fig. 6(c)[37].
Claim_set.Claim: PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel exhibits an absorption capacity of between 4,000 and 10,000 mg g^-1 for various oils and solvents, with peanut oil absorption reaching ten times its own weight.
Claim_set.Topic: Absorption capacity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel for oils and solvents

Following 12 cycles of absorption and desorption, the absorption capacity remained substantially unchanged. This exceptional recyclability can be attributed to the PDMS ' s chemical durability, porous structure, and robust hierarchical roughness.

The degradation performances of gaseous benzene on MnO$_{x}$/ Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC were tested at different temperatures without light illumination. In addition, the photocatalytic degradation ability of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC towards various concentrations of benzene was tested. Furthermore, with its high stability after 60 cycles (30 h), the approximate treatment scales of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC photocatalyst (4 m$^{2}$) were estimated to be 31.2 -40.8 m$^{3}$/d, 34.7 -45.3 m$^{3}$/d, 52.0 -68.0 m$^{3}$/d and 62.4 -81.6 m$^{3}$/d for benzene, toluene, acetaldehyde and formaldehyde, respectively, according to conversion factor (0.65 -0.85) [38,39].
Claim_set.Claim: The MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC photocatalyst demonstrates high degradation efficiency above 99% for various compounds and maintains stability over 60 cycles, with treatment scales estimated based on conversion factors.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic degradation efficiency and treatment scales

Claim_set.text: 1g) showed the coexistence of the crystal plane of MnO$_{x }$ and Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$. EDS mapping images demonstrated that Mn, Co, O and C elements were evenly dispersed throughout MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC photocatalyst (Fig. 1h). To better understand the structure of MnO$_{x}$/ Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC in this work, the mole ratios of MnO$_{2}$, Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$and Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$ were approximately estimated as 0.37:0.51:0.35 using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectromete (ICP-OES) analysis and the XRD integral area (Table S2).
Claim_set.Claim: MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC photocatalyst exhibits a composite structure with evenly dispersed elements and a specific mole ratio of its components.
Claim_set.Topic: Composite structure and elemental dispersion in a photocatalyst

Claim_set.text: 2.4. Substrate Extension. In addition, we further evaluated the Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalyst in hydrosilylation for a wide range of both olefin and silane substrates ( Table 1 ). Under the catalysis of Pt$_{1}$ - N - C, the typical alkene, 1-octene, can react with different kinds of silanes, such as PhMe$_{2}$SiH and (CH$_{3}$O)$_{3}$SiH. Meanwhile, the hydrosilylation reaction can also be carried out between silanes and the functionalized terminal alkenes, such as allylbenzene, allyl glycidyl ether, 1hexadecene, allyl phenyl ether, and vinyltrimethylsilane, with ultrahigh TOF and high selectivity.
Claim_set.Claim: Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalyst demonstrates high efficiency and selectivity in hydrosilylation reactions across a broad spectrum of olefin and silane substrates.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic efficiency and selectivity in hydrosilylation reactions

Claim_set.text:
After being reacted for 2 h at 50 ° C, no Si - H signal was detected by $^{1}$H NMR ( Figure S30 ), indicating that the H atoms included in every monomeric unit were completely substituted by 1-octene, and the Pt$_{1}$ - N - C

catalytic hydrosilylation was high-efficiency. These results further demonstrate the high catalytic activity and substrate compatibility of the catalyst, which make it more promising for applications.

## 3. CONCLUSIONS

In conclusion, the "interfacial spontaneous reduction" strategy was developed to construct a Pt single-atom catalyst by reducing the Pt species at the solid - liquid interface without an external reducing agent. By the ISR strategy, a highly catalytic efficiency Pt$_{1}$ - N - C was prepared with industrial materials under mild conditions.
Claim_set.Claim: The Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalyst demonstrated high-efficiency catalytic hydrosilylation, with complete substitution of H atoms in the monomeric units by 1-octene after 2 hours at 50°C, as indicated by the absence of Si-H signals in $^{1}$H NMR.
Claim_set.Topic: High-efficiency catalytic hydrosilylation with Pt single-atom catalyst

Claim_set.text: As shown in Figure 3 b, the reaction between 1-octene and silane proceeds at a fast and steady rate when catalyzed by Pt$_{1}$ - N - C, and the complete conversion of 1-octene was achieved in about 12 min with a high selectivity (>99%) of anti-Markovnikov addition product detected by $^{1}$H NMR. The development of the product was linear throughout without an obvious induction period at the early stage, providing a zeroorder kinetic curve that matches well with the hydrosilylation reaction catalyzed by the actual activity center. 22 It implies that the Pt species of Pt$_{1}$ - N - C are the actual catalytic active centers.
Claim_set.Claim: Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalyzes the reaction between 1-octene and silane with high selectivity and fast conversion.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic activity in hydrosilylation reaction

Moreover, the general stability issue of MXenes against oxidation due to their high number of defects caused by the preparation process 23 is also a major concern for the photostability of the MXene-containing composites, which need verification through the cycling experiments ideally in ultralong periods.
Claim_set.Claim: Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$/black phosphorus heterojunction exhibits a H$_{2}$ evolution rate 47.2 times higher than that of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ under visible light irradiation.

Claim_set.text: Table 1 summarizes the photocatalytic performances of the previously studied composites containing Ti-Mxene and gC$_{3}$N$_{4}$ in the HER, for which the sacrificial agents used in the photocatalytic reactions are TEOA solutions with different concentrations. Here, the ratio of the hydrogen evolution rate of the composites to that of intrinsic g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ was used to evaluate the effect of the composite strategy. Under the simulated solar illumination, the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 sample enhanced the hydrogen evolution rate by 99.8 times relative to g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$, which is higher than the enhanced times of any other composites under the same photocatalytic conditions.
Claim_set.Claim: The Au/Ti3C2/CN-150 composite demonstrated a 99.8-fold enhancement in hydrogen evolution rate (HER) compared to intrinsic g-C3N4 under simulated solar illumination, outperforming other composites under similar conditions.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced photocatalytic performance in hydrogen evolution rate (HER)

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

The study examined the transport behavior of the 2-aryl propionic acid (2-APA) chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers by means of a laboratory-scale saturated quartz sand column experiment. Four typical of 2-APA and their enantiomers were selected for the study under different types of chiral organic acids (COAs)-mediated effects. Differences in the transport of the 2-APA enantiomeric pairs have been identified in response to various pH, types of COAs, and enantiomeric structures of COAs. Redundancy analysis identified the factors responsible for the largest differences in transport of 2-APA enantiomeric pairs, while spectroscopic characterization and density function theory (DFT) studies elucidated the underlying mechanisms contributing to the differences in transport of enantiomeric pairs.
Claim_set.Claim: The transport behavior of 2-APA chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers in saturated quartz sand columns is influenced by pH, types of chiral organic acids (COAs), and the enantiomeric structures of COAs.
Claim_set.Topic: Transport behavior of chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers

Claim_set.text:
predominant cause of the difference in affinity of 2-APA enantiomeric pairs for sand, which leads to different transport behaviour of 2-APA enantiomers. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the transport behavior of chiral compounds distinguishing different enantiomers in future studies. A more in-depth study focusing on the transport behavior of enantiomeric pairs under different physicochemical conditions would contribute to reveal the important chiral role of enantiomeric transport under complex environmental conditions and provide a more efficient way for the removal of chiral compounds.

## Environmental implication

Release of PhACs into natural eco-environment creates significant hazards, leading to long-term exposure of non-target organisms. Assessing the transport and fate of PhACs in environment requires consideration of the stereoselective interactions effects.
Claim_set.Claim: The transport behavior of chiral compounds, particularly the 2-APA enantiomers, is influenced by their affinity differences for sand, necessitating separate evaluations for each enantiomer in future studies.
Claim_set.Topic: Stereoselective interactions in environmental transport of chiral compounds

Claim_set.text:
Fig. 5. Differences in the recovery of transport of 2-aryl propionic acid chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers under different environmental conditions (a), redundancy analysis on the differences in the recovery of enantiomers by different environmental conditions (b), and graphical representation of the effect of COAs on the sorption of 2-APA enantiomers on the surface of quartz sand (c).

The difference in enrichment of 2-APA on the surface of the sand was significantly reduced when the pH was more than three. When pH is three however, COAs molecules are subjected to double electric layer (EDL) repulsion during their proximity to 2-APA enantiomer molecules, which exhibit a mutual repulsion effect.
Claim_set.Claim: The recovery of 2-aryl propionic acid (2-APA) chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers is significantly affected by environmental conditions, particularly pH levels, which influence the sorption behavior of these enantiomers on the surface of quartz sand.
Claim_set.Topic: Environmental influence on the sorption of chiral pharmaceutical enantiomers

Claim_set.text: Overall, the intrinsic HER activity was higher than that of the other electrocatalysts. In addition, the stability of the electrocatalyst is one of the essential parameters. The cycling durability and long-term stability of the electrocatalysts were obtained by testing the CV and chronoamperometry of the electrocatalysts in 1 M KOH. As shown in Fig. 4e, after 3000 CV-accelerated cycling measurements, the polarization curves of MNFP-PNC/PCBC exhibited only a very weak negative HER shift. In addition, the long-term stability of MNFP-PNC/ PCBC is shown in the inset of Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: The intrinsic HER activity of MNFP-PNC/PCBC is higher than that of other electrocatalysts, and it exhibits excellent cycling durability and long-term stability in 1 M KOH.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrocatalysts for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER)

Claim_set.text: 4e, which confirms that there was no significant degradation after 100 h tests in 1 M KOH at a current of 100 mA cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$, demonstrating the electrocatalyst ' s excellent stability and durability. Structural characterization after HER tests further confirmed that the crystal structure and electronic structure of MNFP-PNC/PCBC remained almost unaltered, implying that MNFP-PNC/PCBC has a strong structural robustness (Fig. S16 and S17). In particular, owing to the synergistic effect of the precisely tuned electronic structure, defect induction by the P, N codoped carbon and PCBC anchoring, the asprepared MNFP-PNC/PCBC electrocatalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance and stability and outperformed reported non precious metal electrocatalysts (Fig. 4f).
Claim_set.Claim: MNFP-PNC/PCBC electrocatalyst demonstrated excellent stability and durability after 100 hours of testing in 1 M KOH at a current of 100 mA cm^-2, and retained its structural and electronic integrity, showcasing its strong structural robustness.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrocatalyst stability and durability in alkaline media

Claim_set.text:
The results indicate that MNFP-PNC/PCBC has excellent HER and OER performance. Therefore, a two-electrode electrolyzer was fabricated to evaluate its performance as

a bifunctional electrocatalyst for electrolysis of water to produce hydrogen in alkaline media using MNFP-PNC/PCBC as both cathode and anode. As a comparison, two commercial catalysts, Pt/C and RuO$_{2}$, were used to construct a two-electrode electrolyzer and tested under the same conditions. Notably, MNFP-PNC/PCBC displayed impressive electrochemical activity with a voltage of 1.783 V reaching current of 50 mA cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$, which was similar to that of commercial Pt/C and RuO$_{2 }$(1.788 V) (Fig. 5).
Claim_set.Claim: MNFP-PNC/PCBC demonstrated excellent HER and OER performance, acting as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for water electrolysis, displaying comparable electrochemical activity to commercial Pt/C and RuO$_{2}$ catalysts.
Claim_set.Topic: Bifunctional electrocatalyst performance for water electrolysis

The maximum C$_{dl }$value of Mo$_{3}$P@NiCoP/NF electrocatalyst is 30.38 mF cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$, which is larger than that of Cr-NiCoP / NF (3.77 mF cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$), W-NiCoP / NF (17.15 mF cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$) and NiCoP / NF (15.73 mF GLYPH<0> $^{2}$). Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical active surface area of electrocatalysts

Claim_set.text: The electrocatalytic activities were further analyzed with an electrochemical double layer capacitor (C$_{dl}$), as shown in Fig. 5d and S20. The C$_{dl }$values of MNFP-PNC/PCBC, MNFP-NC/CBC, MNF-NC/CBC, NFP-PNC/PCBC, MNFP-PNC, and RuO$_{2 }$were 13.0, 4.9, 4.2, 9.1, 6.5, and 6.1 mF cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$, respectively, implying that the bacterial cellulose-derived carbon fibers provide a more active surface for the Mn- NFP-PNC/PCBC, providing a three-dimensional network structure with an enlarged electrochemically active surface, exposing more active sites.
Claim_set.Claim: The electrocatalytic activities of various materials were analyzed using an electrochemical double layer capacitor (C$_{dl}$), with the MNFP-PNC/PCBC exhibiting a C$_{dl}$ value of 13.0 mF cm$^{-2}$, indicating a more active surface compared to other materials.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrocatalytic Activities and Surface Activity of Materials

Claim_set.text: It was reported that most pristine g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ modi  cation studies are concerned with the heterojunction engineering of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ photocatalytic systems for H$_{2}$ production. 24,25 Few research studies have considered the functionalization of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ including hydroxylation and carboxylation on a triazine structure. The effective adsorption and activation of H$_{2}$O molecules on the gC$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface is a prerequisite for the evolution of H$_{2}$OtoH$_{2}$.
Claim_set.Claim: Functionalization of g-C3N4 through hydroxylation and carboxylation enhances the adsorption and activation of H2O molecules on its surface, thereby improving the evolution of H2O to H2.
Claim_set.Topic: Functionalization of g-C3N4 for enhanced photocatalytic H2 production

Claim_set.text:
Although the introduction of -OH on the surface of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ did not destroy the morphology, photo-response activity, and triazine ring structure, the band position, carrier migration properties, and H$_{2}$ evolution markedly improved. Therefore, the C-coupled hydroxyl-g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface is more favorable for H$_{2}$O adsorption and H$_{2}$ escape. This work provides new insights into fabricating highly efficient and stable functionalized photocatalysts from a structural optimization perspective.

## 4. Experiment

## 4.1 Sample preparation

Pristine g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ was fabricated via the traditional thermalcondensation treatment.
Claim_set.Claim: The introduction of -OH on the surface of g-C3N4 improves band position, carrier migration properties, and H2 evolution, making it more favorable for H2O adsorption and H2 escape.
Claim_set.Topic: Surface modification of g-C3N4 for enhanced photocatalytic H2 evolution

Claim_set.text: Speci  cally, the lower electronegativity of the formaldehyde-treated samples was closely related to the surface gra  ed -OH. It could be inferred that the temperature and reaction time have a profound effect on the number of -OH groups on the catalyst surface, which promoted the rearrangement of the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ surface charge and thus in  uenced the electronegativity of the samples. According to the previous analysis, the -OH groups introduced on the formaldehydetreated g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ frameworks had excellent effects on the generation, separation, and migration of the photoinduced carriers and photocatalytic performance, and further enhanced the activity of photocatalytic decomposition of water via increased H$_{2}$O adsorption capacity.
Claim_set.Claim: The surface-grafted -OH groups on formaldehyde-treated g-C3N4 samples significantly influence their electronegativity, promoting the rearrangement of surface charge and enhancing photocatalytic performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Influence of surface-grafted -OH groups on the electronegativity and photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4.

Claim_set.text: As a comparison, the low-valent Pt atoms dispersed on Pt$_{1}$ - N - C can directly catalyze the hydrosilylation between 1-octene and triethoxysilane without a long preactivation period, resulting in the high TOF of 4.5 × 10 5 h - 1 in the whole process, which surpassed all reported Pt heterogeneous catalysts ( Figure S25 ). The reaction even takes place at room temperature ( Figure S26 ) with a TOF of 7472 h - $^{1}$. These results suggest that the atomically dispersed and low-valent Pt provides high activity, which guarantees success in the hydrosilylation reaction under rather mild conditions.
Claim_set.Claim: The atomically dispersed and low-valent Pt on Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalysts provides high activity, allowing for the efficient hydrosilylation of 1-octene and triethoxysilane with a TOF of 4.5 × 10^5 h^-1, surpassing all reported Pt heterogeneous catalysts, and can operate at room temperature with a TOF of 7472 h^-1.
Claim_set.Topic: High activity of low-valent Pt in hydrosilylation reactions

Claim_set.text: The TOF of Pt$_{1}$ - N - C reached 9.3 × 10 6 h - 1 in the reaction between 1-octene and PhMe$_{2}$SiH, combined with a TON of >4.5 × 10 6 in the subkilogram scale reaction, both of which are state-of-theart, 11 , 63 , 64 proving their potential for large-scale application. Furthermore, the reaction using poly(methylhydrosiloxane) as a silane substrate was explored, in which each monomer unit contains a reactive H atom.
Claim_set.Claim: Pt$_{1}$ - N - C catalyst exhibits a turnover frequency (TOF) of 9.3 × 10^6 h^-1 and a turnover number (TON) of >4.5 × 10^6 in the hydrosilylation of 1-octene with PhMe$_{2}$SiH, demonstrating its potential for large-scale application.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic performance of Pt$_{1}$ - N - C in hydrosilylation reactions

Claim_set.text:
## 2. Experiments section

## 2.1. Chemicals and materials

Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ · 6H$_{2}$O)), ammonium fluoride (NH$_{4}$F), urea (CO(NH$_{2}$)$_{2}$). All of them were purchased from Aladdin Company, and the vials were of analytical grade without further purification. The seawater was taken from Qingdao City, Shandong Province, and used after suction filtration.

## 2.2. Synthesis of materials

## 2.2.1. Synthesis of CoCOH@NF precursor

A one-step hydrothermal method was used to grow CoCOH@NF precursors on the NF surface.
Claim_set.Claim: Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, ammonium fluoride, and urea are used as precursors for synthesizing CoCOH@NF materials through a hydrothermal method.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis of materials via hydrothermal method

Claim_set.text:
Nickel foam (3 cm*6 cm) was first cleaned by ultrasonication in ethanol and deionized water for 15 mins sequentially. 0.66 g Co(NO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ · 6H$_{2}$O, 0.178 g NH$_{4}$F and 0.72 g Co(NH$_{2}$)$_{2 }$were dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water. The cleaned NF and the mixture were added to a 100 mL Teflon high-pressure reactor and hydrothermalized at 120 · C for 10 h. After the heating was completed and waiting for cooling, the sample was removed, washed it with deionized water to flush the surface of uneven precipitation, and finally placed in a drying oven to dry the CoCOH@NF precursor.

## 2.2.2.
Claim_set.Claim: Hydrothermal synthesis of CoCOH@NF precursor involves dissolving specific amounts of cobalt nitrate, ammonium fluoride, and urea in deionized water, followed by the addition of cleaned nickel foam and hydrothermal treatment.
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrothermal synthesis of cobalt-based materials on nickel foam

Claim_set.text: Separately, 2 mmol Ni(NO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ · 6H$_{2}$O, 0.25 mmol (NH$_{4}$)$_{6}$Mo$_{7}$O$_{24}$ · 4H$_{2}$O (the Ni:Mo ratio is 8:7 here), and 3 mmol urea were dissolved homogeneously in 20 mL DI water in a glass bottle. The washed NF was then immersed into the solution, and the glass bottle was transferred to a water bath oven maintained at 90 ° C for 8 h. After rinsing several times with DI water and drying in air, the light green NiMoO$_{4}$ · xH$_{2}$O precursor was obtained.
Claim_set.Claim: NiMoO$_{4}$ · xH$_{2}$O precursor was synthesized by immersing nickel foam in a solution containing nickel nitrate, ammonium molybdate, and urea, then heating at 90°C for 8 hours.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis of NiMoO$_{4}$ · xH$_{2}$O precursor on nickel foam.

Claim_set.text:
Cyclic voltammograms (Fig. S1a online) of these lithiation reagents, at identical Li + concentration, indicate a redox potential sequence: Bp > Nap > P-Ter > Pyr > An > Per.

Referring to the redox reaction equation (Eq. (1)) governing lithiation reagents formation, PAHs with higher oxidative potential are theoretically prone to acquire delocalized electrons, thereby enhancing their binding with Li + and facilitating the extraction process. Subsequently, we conducted a comparative analysis of various PAHs' lithium extraction capabilities from lithiated graphite under identical conditions, detailed in the Supplementary materials (online). As expected, higher redox potential in lithiation reagents corresponds to greater extraction of lithium content (Fig. S1b online), indicating a positive correlation between these variables.
Claim_set.Claim: Higher oxidative potential in PAHs enhances their binding with Li+ and facilitates lithium extraction.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithiation reagents and their redox potential for lithium extraction

Claim_set.text:
Fig. 2a illustrates that in THF, the differing Li + binding affinities of Bp, Nap, and Pyr, based on their distinct redox potentials, lead to varied extraction capacities (Pyr > Nap > Bp). This order confirms that PAHs with higher redox potentials yield higher lithium concentrations.

Fig. 2b elucidates the effects of THF, 2-MeTHF, and DME. The extraction capacity increases as the solvating power decreases (DME > THF > 2-MeTHF, Fig. S3 online) [32]. Weakly solvated solvents facilitate desolvation, enhancing the coordination ability of

Fig. 1. Screening of PAHs for lithium extraction systems. (a) Molecular structures of various PAHs.
Claim_set.Claim: PAHs with higher redox potentials yield higher lithium concentrations.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithium Extraction Efficiency

Claim_set.text:
## 3.1. Screening principle of PAHs for lithium extraction systems

We selected a range of representative PAHs, including biphenyl (Bp), naphthalene (Nap), p -terphenyl (P-Ter), pyrene (Pyr), anthracene (An), and perylene (Per) (structures shown in Fig. 1a). The selection was guided by several factors: (1) These reagent molecules contain only benzene ring structures, excluding interference from other factors. (2) The chosen PAHs have distinct redox potentials, allowing for investigation into the relationship between their redox potentials and the reversible lithium content. (3) These reagents are cost-effective, offering practical applicability.
Claim_set.Claim: PAHs with distinct redox potentials are selected for lithium extraction based on their benzene ring structures, redox properties, and cost-effectiveness.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithium Extraction Systems

Claim_set.text: Further benefiting from the macro-confinement effect in the pressuretight tube sealing system to adjust the partial pressure of carbon and nitrogen, the nitrogen-rich Mo$_{2}$C, verified by multi fine techniques, was successfully established on the carbon substrate. The superior HER performance with the low overpotentials of - 72 and - 78 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm - 2 in alkaline and acid solution, respectively, is competitive to most progressive molybdenum-based electrocatalysts.
Claim_set.Claim: Nitrogen-rich Mo2C, established on a carbon substrate via a pressure-tight tube sealing system, exhibits superior HER performance with low overpotentials in both alkaline and acid solutions, competing with advanced molybdenum-based electrocatalysts.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution Performance

Claim_set.text: Specifically, the high nitrogen concentration triggers the redistribution of the coordination environment around the Mo atoms, leading to the expanded distance between valence band and Fermi level. Accordingly, the d band center is pushed down to the lower energy level, thus weaking the binding energy of produce H$_{2}$. Simultaneously, on account of the adequate and stronger N 2 p - Mo 4 d hybridization, the Mo atoms display the emptier 4 d orbital, enhancing the H$_{2}$O dissociation. Benefiting from the synergy above, the N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C reveals comparable catalytic activity and stability of HER in both the alkaline and acid solution. This work presents valuable method to adjust the electronic configuration of carbide, and inspires the development of new electrocatalysts via multiscale modulation strategy.
Claim_set.Claim: High nitrogen concentration in Mo2C catalysts leads to enhanced HER activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic solutions through electronic configuration modulation.
Claim_set.Topic: Electronic Configuration Modulation for Improved HER Catalysts

Claim_set.text: Apparently, the N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C exhibits the superior HER performance with smallest overpotential of - 78 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm - 2 ( ƞ$_{10}$ ), much smaller than that of N$_{l}$-Mo$_{2}$C( - 155 mV) and N$_{0}$-Mo$_{2}$C ( - 229 mV). The Tafel plots are linear fitted from the LSV curves. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the Tafel slope of N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C is calculated as 81.1 mV dec - $^{1}$, superior to other catalysts, highlighting its fast reaction kinetics.
Claim_set.Claim: N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C exhibits superior HER performance with the smallest overpotential of -78 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm$^{-2}$, and a Tafel slope of 81.1 mV dec$^{-1}$, highlighting its fast reaction kinetics.
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) Performance

Claim_set.text: Figure 7 c shows the results of the photocatalytic performance of the H$_{2}$ evolution of the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite compared with the other samples. From the observation of the variation of hydrogen evolution rates of different photocatalysts under visible illumination, it can be concluded that Au particles are the key component contributing to the visible photocatalytic performance of the composite, and the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ has a weak function in enhancing the generalizable light response of the parent material but improves the overall performance, particularly under visible light for the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite. Moreover, a bridging role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in enhancement of the photocatalytic performance can also be deduced.
Claim_set.Claim: Au particles are the key component contributing to the visible photocatalytic performance of the composite, and the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ has a weak function in enhancing the generalizable light response of the parent material but improves the overall performance, particularly under visible light for the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 ternary composite.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic performance under visible light

Claim_set.text: At first, the basic roles of Au, CN-150, and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ should be clarified. There are two basic roles of Au, one is Au$_{C}$ to generate hot electrons, and the other is Au$_{T}$ to act as a photocatalytic active site. CN-150 also has two basic roles: one is that CN-150 is the main component and therefore plays the role of the carrier of the composite material, and the other role is to generate photogenerated electrons and holes by light excitation. The basic role of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ is to favor charge transfer due to its high electrical conductivity. When the above three components form a composite material, based on their basic roles, new roles are created, leading to the enhancement of photocatalytic performance, which is the so-called synergistic effect.
Claim_set.Claim: The synergistic effect of Au, CN-150, and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ in composite materials enhances photocatalytic performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Synergistic Effect in Photocatalysis

Claim_set.text: Compared with CN-150, the absorption capacity of Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 increased significantly, while the binary and ternary composites containing Au had stronger absorption performance within the visible light range. This is ascribed to the Au particles with a representative characteristic absorption peak in the range of 500 - 650 nm, which has been observed in many literatures.
Claim_set.Claim: Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite exhibits significantly increased absorption capacity compared to CN-150, and the addition of Au further enhances visible light absorption performance due to Au's characteristic absorption peak between 500 - 650 nm.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced absorption performance within visible light range

Claim_set.text: Combining the bandgap of BTNO and BiOBr, their conduction band minimum (CBM) are located at GLYPH<0> 0.73 eV and GLYPH<0> 0.20 eV respectively. To further study the energy band structure of BTNO and BiOBr, Mott-Schottky curves have also be employed to infer the band positions[31]. As shown in Fig. S10, the flat band potentials (E$_{fb}$) of BTNO and BiOBr were ascertained to be GLYPH<0> 0.70 and GLYPH<0> 0.17 V vs. Ag/AgCl, respectively.
Claim_set.Claim: The bandgap of BTNO and BiOBr, combined with their conduction band minimum (CBM) positions, suggests a potential difference of 0.73 eV and 0.20 eV, respectively. This difference has been further studied through Mott-Schottky curves, which inferred the band positions and determined the flat band potentials (Efb) of BTNO and BiOBr to be -0.70 and -0.17 V vs. Ag/AgCl, respectively.
Claim_set.Topic: Energy Band Structure of BTNO and BiOBr

Claim_set.text:
Herein, the work function of BiOBr was calculated to be and 5.82 eV, and then the Fermi level (E$_{f}$) of BTNO and BiOBr are then inferred to be at 0.44 V and 1.32 V [24]. Based on the obtained CBM, VBM and Fermi levels, the schematic diagram of the band configuration at the interface of BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction is shown in Fig. 6g [37,41]. When BTNO and BiOBr are in

contact, due to the difference between their E$_{f}$, electrons of BTNO will move to BiOBr until an equilibrium is reached [37].

Claim_set.text: The flow direction of photogenerated carriers is shown by the arrows. The holes on the VB of BTNO recombine with electrons on the CB of BiOBr, leaving behind electrons with stronger reduction ability on the CB of BTNO and holes with stronger oxidation ability on the VB of BiOBr [31]. Because the CB of BTNO ( GLYPH<0> 0.73 eV vs. NHE) is more negative than the O$_{2}$/ · O$_{2}$ -potential ( GLYPH<0> 0.046 eV vs. NHE) [42], the electrons in BTNO can convert the adsorbed O$_{2 }$ into · O$_{2}$$^{-}$, thereby participating in the degradation.
Claim_set.Claim: The photogenerated holes on the valence band of BTNO recombine with electrons on the conduction band of BiOBr, leading to enhanced redox abilities of the remaining charge carriers.
Claim_set.Topic: Photogenerated carrier flow and redox abilities in BTNO/BiOBr system

Claim_set.text: Moreover, the employment of the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte in the asymmetric cell consistently showcases stable voltage performance, achieving an average Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 99.65% over a prolonged cycling period of 1000 cycles ( Figure 5 c). In stark contrast, the utilization of the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte leads to premature failure after only 65 cycles due to fluctuating voltage. When the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte was used, a significant enhancement of CE was observed due to Gln regulation of the EDL structure to inhibit side reactions and the formation of a topologically adaptable SEI to ensure long-term stable protection of the zinc anode.
Claim_set.Claim: Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte enhances Coulombic efficiency and prolongs cycle life in asymmetric cells.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrolyte performance in asymmetric cells

Claim_set.text: And the superior performance of Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes in harsh environments was demonstrated, leading to further enhancements in both current density and plating capacity. Figure 5 e,f and Figure S16 depict the stable cycle life of Zn//Zn symmetric cells with Gln/ ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte at 5, 10, and 20 mA cm - $^{2}$, which are recorded as 1600, 1200, and 300 h, respectively. These exceptional properties still significantly surpass those observed in symmetrical batteries using ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes.
Claim_set.Claim: Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes demonstrate superior performance in harsh environments, enhancing current density and plating capacity.
Claim_set.Topic: Performance of electrolytes in harsh environments

Claim_set.text: Zn ( Figure S8 ). Conversely, in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte ( Figure 3 f), the surface of the zinc sheet exhibits a relatively smooth and uniform appearance. This further substantiates the corrosion inhibiting effect of Gln. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of Zn/Cu half cells in Figure 3 g illustrate the nucleation process of Zn 2+ in both ZnSO$_{4}$ and Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes during the initial cycle. It is evident that the Gln/ ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits a higher nucleation overpotential compared to the pure ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte.
Claim_set.Claim: Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits a corrosion inhibiting effect on zinc surfaces, leading to a smoother and more uniform appearance compared to pure ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte.
Claim_set.Topic: Corrosion inhibition on zinc surfaces

Claim_set.text:
Moreover, the PTZ-CPA shows a larger molecular dipole moment and improved energy level alignment with FAPbI$_{3}$, benefiting the interfacial hole-collection. Consequently, FAPbI$_{3}$-based inverted PSCs achieve an unprecedented efficiency of 25.35% under simulated air mass 1.5 (AM1.5) sunlight. The PTZCPA based device shows commendable long-term stability, maintaining over 90% of its initial efficiency after continuous operation at 40$^{o}$C for 2000 hours.

## Introduction

Inverted (p-i-n) perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have attracted significant attention due to their low-temperature processability, enhanced operational stability, and impressive power conversion efficiencies (PCE) exceeding 25%.$^{[1-4]}$ Generally,
Claim_set.Claim: "PTZ-CPA shows a larger molecular dipole moment and improved energy level alignment with FAPbI$_{3}$, benefiting the interfacial hole-collection."
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced Interfacial Hole-Collection in Inverted PSCs

Claim_set.text: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggest that the molecular dipole moment of PTZ-CPA (~2.3 D) is much larger than that of MeO-2PACz (~0.2 D, Figure 1a), which is advantageous for hole transfer at the indium tin oxide (ITO)/HTL/perovskite interface (Figure 1a). [4,26] The usage of structurally simple and sulfur-containing PTZ in the molecular hole-transporter is expected to not only reduce the synthetic costs but also increase passivation sites.$^{[27]}$ As HTMs in inverted PSCs, their intrinsic thermal-, photo- and electrochemicalstabilities are of paramount importance.
Claim_set.Claim: The molecular dipole moment of PTZ-CPA is much larger than that of MeO-2PACz, facilitating hole transfer at the ITO/HTL/perovskite interface.
Claim_set.Topic: Molecular dipole moment and its effect on hole transfer in perovskite solar cells

Claim_set.text:
The potential of Bp-Li (0.11 V vs Li/Li$^{+}$), which is just lower than the potential of stage-2 lithium intercalation (0.125 V), enables the precise lithiation of graphite to stage-2 Li-GICs (LiC$_{12}$). Intriguingly, the exfoliation of LiC$_{12}$ leads to the bilayer-favored production of graphene, giving a high

Supporting Information

selectivity of 78%. Furthermore, the mild intercalation - exfoliation procedure yields high-quality graphene with negligible structural deterioration. The obtained graphene exhibits ultralow defect density ( I$_{D}$ / I$_{G}$ ∼ 0.14) and a considerably high C/O ratio ( ∼ 29.7), superior to most current state-of-the-art techniques.
Claim_set.Claim: The potential of Bp-Li enables the precise lithiation of graphite to stage-2 Li-GICs (LiC$_{12}$), leading to the bilayer-favored production of graphene with high selectivity and negligible structural deterioration.
Claim_set.Topic: Precise lithiation of graphite for high-quality graphene production

Claim_set.text:
(h) $^{7}$Li NMR spectra and (i) ICP-AES result for lithiated graphite.

reagent (biphenyl lithium), to realize the facile preparation of high-quality bilayer graphene under ambient temperature and pressure, as illustrated in Scheme 1 c. The Li-intercalation process occurs through the spontaneous reaction between graphite and the biphenyl lithium (Bp-Li) reagent at room temperature, benefiting from the strong reducing ability of BpLi. Notably, given that the redox potential of Bp-Li (0.11 V) is lower than that of stage-2 Li-GICs (0.125 V), it is capable of achieving a precise second-order lithiation of graphite, resulting in the formation of stage-2 Li-GICs (LiC$_{12}$).
Claim_set.Claim: The biphenyl lithium (Bp-Li) reagent enables the precise preparation of high-quality bilayer graphene through a spontaneous reaction with graphite at room temperature, forming stage-2 Li-GICs (LiC$_{12}$).
Claim_set.Topic: Lithiation of graphite for bilayer graphene synthesis

Claim_set.text: Feasibility of the chemical lithiation reaction enabled by the Bp-Li reagent. (a) GITT curves of the Li/graphite half-cell and corresponding open circuit potential. (The inset is the schematic diagram of differently staged Li-GICs.) (b) In situ XRD patterns of graphite during the lithiation process. (c) EPR spectra of the pristine Bp and Bp-Li reagent. (The insets are optical photographs of Bp solution before and after adding lithium metal.) (d) $^{7}$Li NMR spectrum of Bp-Li solution. (e) Cyclic voltammograms of the Bp-Li reagent at a scan rate of 200 mV s - $^{1}$. (f) XRD patterns of lithiated graphite synthesized by the reaction of Bp-Li and graphite with different molar ratios.
Claim_set.Claim: The Bp-Li reagent facilitates the chemical lithiation reaction, as evidenced by the GITT curves, in situ XRD patterns, and the successful synthesis of lithiated graphite.
Claim_set.Topic: Feasibility of chemical lithiation reaction

Claim_set.text:
In the designed Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ ternary composites, g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ was modified by copolymerization of malonamide and melamine, which is a derivative of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ and together with Au particles led to the stronger visible light absorption; meanwhile, both the Au particles and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ enhanced charge separation and provided more active sites

for redox reactions. The resultant ternary composites showed an H$_{2}$ evolution rate of ∼ 120 μ mol/h/g with remarkable photocatalytic stability in a 120-h-long cycling experiment, demonstrating the potential application in HER.
Claim_set.Claim: g-C3N4 modified with malonamide and melamine, combined with Au particles and Ti3C2, enhances visible light absorption and charge separation, providing more active sites for redox reactions, leading to a significant improvement in H2 evolution rate with excellent photocatalytic stability.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced photocatalytic performance for hydrogen evolution.

Claim_set.text:
Although a similar photocatalytic mechanism was proposed in the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ - Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ - Pt composite, 20 a notable difference in our work is that the Au particles, in addition to contributing to the spatial segregation of charges, also enhance the visible light-absorbing properties and photocatalytic activity of the composite through providing hot electrons by the surface plasmon resonance effect. 60 , 61 Moreover, the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ MXene acts as a bridging electron trap to collect photogenerated electrons, which could avoid the oxidation of MXene, being the important reason for realizing the long-time stable hydrogen evolution here.

Finally, the synergistic effect of Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 is summarized here.
Claim_set.Claim: The Au particles in the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ - Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ - Pt composite enhance visible light-absorbing properties and photocatalytic activity through the surface plasmon resonance effect, and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ MXene acts as a bridging electron trap to collect photogenerated electrons, avoiding its oxidation and enabling long-time stable hydrogen evolution.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic mechanism and performance of the Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite

Claim_set.text: After the Au nanoparticles are loaded on the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ heterojunction surface, the electrons further transfer to Au particles, which could provide more active reaction sites for the H$_{2}$ evolution process.
Claim_set.Claim: Electrons transfer to Au particles on the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ heterojunction surface, providing more active sites for H$_{2}$ evolution.
Claim_set.Topic: Electron transfer for H$_{2}$ evolution on heterojunction surfaces

Claim_set.text: This analysis revealed an extended electron overlap (-2.6 to -0.8 eV) between the p -orbitals of water and d -orbitals of Co at the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$, compared to the water molecules adsorbed at the first layer of Co layer, demonstrating a higher interaction strength for the first case. These interactions can be directly interpreted according to the difference in charge density, as shown in Figure S8 .
Claim_set.Claim: "The extended electron overlap between the p-orbitals of water and d-orbitals of Co at the first layer of Co0.8Cu0.2 demonstrates a higher interaction strength compared to adsorption at the first layer of Co layer."
Claim_set.Topic: Electron overlap in water-Co interaction

Claim_set.text: In addition, the d -orbital peak of Co at the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ was significantly higher than that of Co at the first layer of Co, indicating that the electronic state in the d -orbitals of Co at the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ was more localized and closer to the Fermi level. In Figure 3d , the d -band center of Co at the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ (-1.07 eV) approached zero at a higher degree than that of Co at the first layer of Co (-1.16 eV), also indicating stronger water adsorption on the Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2 }$surface.
Claim_set.Claim: The electronic state in the d-orbitals of Co at the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ was more localized and closer to the Fermi level, indicating stronger water adsorption on the Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ surface.
Claim_set.Topic: Electronic state and water adsorption on alloy surfaces

Claim_set.text: Therefore, as illustrated in Figure 3a , the adsorption energy of water at the Co site of the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ (-0.25 eV) was below that at the Co site of the first layer of Co (-0.07 eV), implying that the [1 1 1] surface of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ was more favorable for capturing water molecules.
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption energy of water at the Co site of the first layer of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$ is more favorable for capturing water molecules compared to the Co site of the first layer of pure Co.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption energy of water on alloy surfaces

Claim_set.text: Notably, the adsorption uptake calculated from pseudo-second-order model was 5.76 mg/g, which was closer to the experimental value (5.79 mg/g) than that of pseudo-firstorder model (5.72 mg/g). The results indicated that pseudo-secondorder model was more suitable for describing the kinetic profiles, implying that chemisorption was the rate-limiting step for the adsorption of Pb 2 + towards MKPP. When it comes to KPP, it was more obvious that pseudo-second-order model could describe the adsorption behavior better due to the higher R $^{2}$. Besides, the second order rate constant ( k$_{2}$ ) of MKPP was much larger than that of KPP, suggesting the faster adsorption kinetics for MKPP.
Claim_set.Claim: Pseudo-second-order model more accurately describes the adsorption kinetics of Pb^2+ onto MKPP and KPP, indicating chemisorption as the rate-limiting step.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption kinetics of Pb^2+ onto MKPP and KPP

Claim_set.text:
2

To explore the adsorption capacity and further understand the adsorption behavior of adsorbent for Pb 2 + , adsorption isotherm experiments were carried out with the initial Pb 2 + concentrations ranging from 50 to 600 mg/L at 298.15K. The experimental data were fitted and predicted with Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models, respectively (Fig. 3G). From the correlative fitting parameters listed in Table S3, the adsorption processes of both MKPP and KPP can be better described by Langmuir model than Freundlich model due to the relatively larger correlation coefficients ( R $^{2}$). Therefore, adsorption of Pb2 + onto MKPP or KPP can be considered as monolayer adsorption ascribed to the homogenous distribution of active adsorption sites on the surface of materials.
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption of Pb2+ onto MKPP or KPP is better described by the Langmuir model due to the relatively larger correlation coefficients, indicating a monolayer adsorption behavior.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption behavior of adsorbent for Pb2+

Claim_set.text: (G) Adsorption isotherm for the adsorption of Pb 2 + by MKPP and KPP (pH = 3, V = 10 mL, m$_{adsorbent }$ = 1.0 mg, T = 298.15K). (H) Effect of temperature on Pb adsorption by MKPP (pH = 3, adsorbent content = 0.075 g/L, c$_{0 }$ = 1 ppm), and (I) Van ' t Hoff plot of ln K$_{c }$ vs 1/T × 10 GLYPH<0> $^{3}$.
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption of Pb^2+ by MKPP and KPP follows a specific isotherm pattern, and the effect of temperature on this process can be analyzed using the Van 't Hoff plot.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption Isotherm and Thermodynamics

Claim_set.text: The electrochemical oxidation of urea was initially studied using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in a conventional three-electrode system containing 1 M KOH with a scanning rate of 10 mV s⁻¹ (Figure 3a). The redox peaks corresponding to Ni²⁺/Ni³⁺ redox pairs can be observed by all the catalysts, within which the NiO@NiS displayed the most significant current density, indicating most abundant active catalytic sites. Subsequently, the catalytic performance of NiO@NiS toward urea oxidation was verified by a sharp increase of anode current with the addition of 0.33 M urea (Figure 3b).
Claim_set.Claim: The NiO@NiS catalyst demonstrated superior performance in the electrochemical oxidation of urea, as evidenced by the most significant current density observed during cyclic voltammetry, indicating an abundance of active catalytic sites.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical Oxidation of Urea

Claim_set.text:
Notably, the nanorod composite exhibits outstanding electrocatalytic performance in the urea oxidation reaction, achieving a notable current density of 10 mA cm -2 at a voltage of 1.44 V (vs. RHE). This performance surpasses that of individual NiO and NiS. The catalyst developed in this work introduces a novel perspective for the treatment of urea-rich domestic wastewater and promising green hydrogen supply.

Claim_set.text: Comparative analysis in Figure 3c demonstrated the superior UOR activity of NiO@NiS over individual NiO and NiS, suggesting that the heterogeneous interface formed post-composite facilitated the transformation of Ni 2+ to Ni 3+ , thus enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, the lower Tafel slope of NiO@NiS (31.78 mV dec⁻¹) than that of NiO (35.28 mV dec⁻¹) and NiS (42.42 mV dec⁻¹) also confirmed accelerated reaction kinetics in urea oxidation (Figure 3d).
Claim_set.Claim: The heterogeneous interface formed in the NiO@NiS composite facilitates the transformation of Ni^2+ to Ni^3+, enhancing catalytic activity and accelerating reaction kinetics in urea oxidation.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic Activity and Reaction Kinetics in Urea Oxidation

Claim_set.text: FSBC-800 showed the best activation performance for PMS, with a TC removal rate of ~ 94 % within 10 min. Mechanism research shows that FSBC-800 activates PMS through singlet oxygen ($^{1}$O$_{2}$) and electron transfer, so the reaction system is extremely selective and can almost avoid interference from various inorganic ions. The FSBC-800/PMS system can operate efficiently in the coexistence of 8 common anions/cations (0 -250 mM), and salinity of 0.1 -5.0 wt% has almost no negative impact on the system. In addition, possible degradation pathways of tetracycline were proposed, and the toxicity of intermediate products during the degradation process was evaluated. This study provides a PMS oxidation system with strong selectivity that can cope with various complex saline environments.
Claim_set.Claim: FSBC-800 efficiently activates PMS for TC removal, primarily through singlet oxygen and electron transfer, exhibiting high selectivity and resistance to inorganic ion interference.
Claim_set.Topic: PMS activation for tetracycline removal in saline environments

Claim_set.text:
## 4. Conclusion

Using sesame cake as a precursor, iron -nitrogen-doped twodimensional biochar flakes were successfully synthesized via a molten salt strategy. The optimized FSBC-800 exhibited excellent catalytic performance in activating PMS, with a degradation efficiency of ~ 94 % for TC within 10 min. Characterization and analysis results indicated that defects and C = O groups were the primary active sites on FSBC-800.

FSBC-800 activated PMS through both singlet oxygen and electron transfer mechanisms, enabling the oxidation system based on FSBC-800 to exhibit high selectivity. This selectivity allows the FSBC-800/PMS process to greatly avoid the adverse effects of various common inorganic salts in water. This work provides a new perspective on low-cost and efficient treatment of pollutants in saline environments.
Claim_set.Claim: FSBC-800 exhibits excellent catalytic performance in activating PMS, achieving a degradation efficiency of ~94% for TC within 10 minutes.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalytic performance of biochar in activating PMS for pollutant degradation

Claim_set.text: As shown in Fig. S12, the supernatant after reaction revealed concentrations of 437.8 μ g/L of iron, 80.1 μ g/L of silicon, and 3807.9 μ g/L of magnesium. The leached iron originated from the iron species formed during the preparation of FSBC-800, while leached silicon and magnesium were derived from the precursor, sesame meal. It should be noted that the leached concentrations of these elements were well below the related environmental protection standards, affirming that FSBC-800 is a sustainable catalyst. The activation effect of leached iron on PMS was also examined, as illustrated in Fig. S13. It can be observed that leached iron at the leaching level has a weak activation effect on PMS, degrading approximately 45 % of TC within 10 min.
Claim_set.Claim: Leached iron from FSBC-800 has a weak activation effect on PMS, degrading approximately 45% of TC within 10 min.
Claim_set.Topic: Activation Effect on PMS

Claim_set.text: 5d). In addition, we studied the effect of mixed metal ions on the selectivity of TD-TPTA. As shown in Fig. S23, in the mixed metal ion solution, TD-TPTA can remove more than 99 % of gold within 18 min. As demonstrated, TD-TPTA possesses fast kinetics, high capacity, selectivity and excellent stability, rendering it ideal for gold capture in e-waste. Notably, TD-TPTA exhibits a higher capacity for adsorption and faster kinetics than most materials reported in the literature, including other materials used for photochemical recovery of gold [37 -55] (Fig. 5e and Supplementary Table S3).
Claim_set.Claim: TD-TPTA can remove more than 99% of gold within 18 minutes in a mixed metal ion solution, showcasing its fast kinetics, high capacity, selectivity, and excellent stability, making it ideal for gold capture in e-waste.Entity: TD-TPTATopic: Gold recovery from e-waste using TD-TPTA
Claim_set.Entity: TD-TPTATopic: Gold recovery from e-waste using TD-TPTA
Claim_set.Topic: Gold recovery from e-waste using TD-TPTA

Claim_set.text: The obtained leachate contains metal compositions of Au 3 + , Ni 2 + and Cu 2 + , with concentrations of 10.1, 1313.2 and 1784.4 ppm respectively. Using 10 mg TD-TPTA, 99.45 % of gold could be removed within 20 min under photocatalytic conditions, this suggests that ultrafast adsorption of gold can be achieved in e-waste leachate (Fig. 9b). Importantly, although the concentrations of Ni 2 + and Cu 2 + are much higher than that of Au 3 + , only 1.13 % and 1.44 % of Ni 2 + 2 + are adsorbed.
Claim_set.Claim: 99.45% of gold could be removed from e-waste leachate within 20 min using 10 mg TD-TPTA under photocatalytic conditions.
Claim_set.Topic: Ultrafast adsorption of gold in e-waste leachate

Claim_set.text: The findings demonstrate that both adsorption kinetics conform well with the model (Fig. 5c and S21). In addition, TDTPTA also showed faster adsorption kinetics and higher removal efficiency than DBA-TPTA, achieving > 99 % removal within 30 min under light irradiation conditions (Fig. 5c and S22). The excellent removal efficiency of TD-TPTA can be attributed to the strong affinity of the soft alkali sulfur contained in it to soft acid gold, as well as its excellent hydrophilicity, which improves the accessibility of TD-TPTA and enhances gold binding. The parameters of their adsorption kinetic models were computed in detail and documented in Supplementary Table S2.
Claim_set.Claim: TDTPTA exhibits faster adsorption kinetics and higher removal efficiency compared to DBA-TPTA, achieving > 99% removal of gold within 30 minutes under light irradiation.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption kinetics and removal efficiency of TDTPTA versus DBA-TPTA for gold.

Claim_set.text: CV curves of the Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalysts under N$_{2 }$saturation and O$_{2 }$saturation in 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M HClO$_{4 }$ are shown in Fig. S26a-b, respectively. We found a prominent reduction peak at 0.86 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M KOH, whereas, in 0.1 M HClO$_{4}$, the position of the reduction peak was at 0.68 V, which indicated that the Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst had ORR activity under alkaline and acidic conditions.
Claim_set.Claim: The Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalysts exhibit ORR activity under both alkaline and acidic conditions, with a reduction peak at 0.86 V in 0.1 M KOH and at 0.68 V in 0.1 M HClO$_{4}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrocatalytic Activity in Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) Under Varying pH Conditions

Claim_set.text: S29 and Fig. S30). Higher C$_{dl }$ values indicate a greater density of active sites on the surface of the Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst and faster ORR kinetics [46,47,51]. In addition, Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C had the best kinetic current density normalized by the ECSA (Fig. S31) and the highest kinetic current density at 0.85 V (Table S7) compared to those of Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C, and Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C, suggesting that Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C has the highest intrinsic activity [50].
Claim_set.Claim: Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst exhibits higher C$_{dl}$ values, indicating greater density of active sites and faster ORR kinetics, with the best kinetic current density normalized by the ECSA and the highest intrinsic activity.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced ORR activity and intrinsic properties of Mn-based catalysts

Claim_set.text: S33). After six months, the half-wave potential of Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C decayed by only 7 mV, and the limiting current density only slightly decreased. These results indicate that the Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst material is relatively stable and suitable for practical applications. Additionally, we conducted a chronoamperometry test for the Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst at a constant potential of 0.6 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 6f) and found that the Mn$_{cluster}$/ Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst retained 92.6% of the initial current density after 25,000 s, while the commercial Pt/C catalyst only retained 85.4% of the initial current density.
Claim_set.Claim: Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C catalyst material is relatively stable and suitable for practical applications, retaining 92.6% of the initial current density after 25,000 s.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst stability and performance for practical applications

Claim_set.text: MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.5 photocatalyst showed a weaker SPV signal intensity, indicating a smaller number of holes being transmitted to the surface. The SPV signal intensity of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC photocatalyst distinctly increased upon the incorporation of Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$ for holes extraction from MnO$_{x}$, indicating that holes transfer by Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$ was the main driving force for the extraction of photogenerated holes in MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC, thereby contributing to the improvement of photocatalytic stability.
Claim_set.Claim: The incorporation of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ into MnO$_{x}$@ACC photocatalyst significantly enhances the extraction of photogenerated holes, improving photocatalytic stability.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced photocatalytic stability through hole extraction

Claim_set.text: Once Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$ was introduced into MnO$_{2}$/Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$ heterojunction, the photocurrent of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC was remarkedly enhanced under full spectrum irradiation, with an increase of approximately 1.1 times compared to that of MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.5 and 2.1 times compared to that of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC (Fig. 3c). This result demonstrated that Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$ co-catalyst effectively improved the separation and migration of carriers. Furthermore, the electron transfer efficiency was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS).
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ introduction into MnO$_{2}$/Mn$_{5}$O$_{8}$ heterojunction remarkably enhances photocurrent of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC under full spectrum irradiation, demonstrating effective carrier separation and migration improvement.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocurrent enhancement in MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC composite.

Claim_set.text: It can be seen from Fig. S23b that MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.5 photocatalyst presented a higher stable photocurrent value in several light on-off cycles, indicating that the MnO$_{2}$/ Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$ heterojunction promoted the rapid transfer of the photogenerated electrons at the interface.
Claim_set.Claim: MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.5 photocatalyst exhibits higher stable photocurrent due to the MnO$_{2}$/Mn$_{5}$O$_{8}$ heterojunction facilitating rapid transfer of photogenerated electrons.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocurrent stability and electron transfer in photocatalysts

Claim_set.text: By finely regulating the number of intercalated lithium ions and the intercalation rate, this method can theoretically achieve controllable and efficient exfoliation of graphene. 39 Similarly, Loh et al. obtained fewlayer graphene in high yield (>70%) by intercalating lithium ions into graphite electrodes in lithium salt and propylene carbonate electrolytes (30 mg/mL LiClO$_{4}$ in PC). 40 However, as pointed out in Zhang's research group, 11 this electrochemical lithium intercalation method necessitates a tedious battery assembly and disassembly process. Moreover, the addition of conductive additives (acetylene black) and binders (PVDF) inevitably leads to difficulties in product purification and separation, which hinder large-scale production.
Claim_set.Claim: Electrochemical lithium intercalation can achieve controllable and efficient exfoliation of graphene but necessitates a tedious battery assembly and disassembly process and leads to difficulties in product purification and separation.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical Exfoliation of Graphene

Claim_set.text:
methods require either harsh temperature conditions (< - 33 ° C for Li/NH$_{3}$) or a hydrothermal environment (220 ° C in an autoclave for LiOH). Consequently, while the lithium intercalation method is prevalent for the exfoliation of transition-metal dichalcogenide nanosheets (such as MoS$_{2}$, WS$_{2}$, and TiS$_{2}$), 39 , 46 - 49 its potential in graphene preparation has yet to be fully realized and exploited. Moreover, ion insertion holds the potential of staging intercalation, which will preferentially yield the corresponding monolayer or bilayer

graphene. 36 , 50 Owing to the unique electronic band structures, the physiochemical properties of graphene are sensitive to its layer numbers.
Claim_set.Claim: Lithium intercalation method, prevalent for exfoliation of transition-metal dichalcogenide nanosheets, has yet to be fully realized and exploited for graphene preparation.
Claim_set.Topic: Exfoliation and preparation of graphene

Claim_set.text:
Alternatively, ion intercalation-assisted exfoliation has emerged as a representative method for the scalable preparation of graphene due to its controllability and high efficiency. 33 - 35 This method involves the fabrication of graphite intercalation compounds (GICs) by inserting guest ions into carbon layers, thereby increasing the interlayer spacing and weakening van der Waals forces between layers. The ion-intercalated sample reacts with water to produce hydrogen, which further promotes the delamination of graphite

layers. 36 , 37 Typically, Zeng et al. pioneered the electrochemical lithium-ion intercalation method ( Scheme 1 b). 38 Lithium ions are driven into the graphite layer by electrochemical force during the battery discharge process, forming lithium graphite intercalation compounds (Li-GICs).
Claim_set.Claim: Ion intercalation-assisted exfoliation is a scalable method for graphene preparation due to its controllability and high efficiency.
Claim_set.Topic: Scalable graphene preparation via ion intercalation-assisted exfoliation

Claim_set.text: The BUMCs are characterized with high density (up to 1.62 g cm GLYPH<0> $^{3}$), large specific surface area (up to 1050 m$^{2 }$g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$), narrow ultramicropore distribution (0.4 -0.6 nm) and favourable pore surface functionalities (mainly -BC$_{2}$O, -BCO$_{2}$, and -COH groups). As a result, the carbon electrodes exhibit exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage, wherein the optimal one delivers an ultrahigh volumetric capacitance of up to 431 F cm GLYPH<0> $^{3}$, and an ever-reported high volumetric energy density of 32.6 Wh L GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$in aqueous electrolyte.
Claim_set.Claim: The BUMCs exhibit exceptionally compact capacitive energy storage, with an optimal electrode delivering an ultrahigh volumetric capacitance of up to 431 F cm^-3 and a high volumetric energy density of 32.6 Wh L^-1 in aqueous electrolyte.
Claim_set.Topic: Compact Capacitive Energy Storage in Binder-free Ultramicroporous Carbon

Claim_set.text: Thanks to the high packing density (1.62 g cm GLYPH<0> $^{3}$) of BUMC0.5, an ultrahigh C$_{vol }$ of 431 F cm GLYPH<0> $^{3 }$is achieved in it, significantly higher than that in representative carbon materials such as activated carbons (AC), templated carbons (TC), biomass-derived carbons (Bio-C), graphene-based carbons (GR), and polymer-derived carbons (PC) reported in literatures (Fig. 3d and Table S3, Supporting Information). Despite of its high density and extremely-confined ultramicroporous channels, the BUMC-0.5 exhibits an exceptional high capacitance retention of 77% as the current density increasing from 1 to 20 A g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$.
Claim_set.Claim: BUMC0.5 achieves an ultrahigh volumetric capacitance of 431 F cm^-3, significantly higher than representative carbon materials.
Claim_set.Topic: High volumetric capacitance in carbon materials

Claim_set.text: [7] Electrochemical performance and cyclic stability of nickel-cobalt sulfides, however, demand further enhancement for their practical application. [5d,8] To tackle this issue, researchers have employed a series of novel designs to enhance the electron/ion transport kinetics of various electrode materials, such as the development of heterogeneous interfaces, design of unique structures, modification of multi-components, and application of vacancy defect engineering. Vacancy defect engineering has been demonstrated as an effective strategy to regulate the electronic structure of various materials, achieving enhanced electrochemical performance. [4g,9] Various approaches to vacancy defect modulation include bottom-up techniques such as target ablation, solvothermal synthesis, and doping induction, whereas top-down methods include intercalation-exfoliation, ion irradiation, electrochemical etching, liquid chemical etching, and thermal annealing.
Claim_set.Claim: Vacancy defect engineering is an effective strategy to enhance the electrochemical performance of nickel-cobalt sulfides by regulating their electronic structure.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical performance enhancement

Claim_set.text: Typically, internal micropores in materials bolster capillarity [45]. Thanks to the abundant porosity of PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogels, MPs and different oils are attracted to the inner pores. Moreover, the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel can effectively adsorb MPs, as non-covalent bonding forces between the MPs and aerogel exist. MPs contains an abundance of non-polar benzene rings and methyl groups, which confer high surface tension and low surface energy, endowing MPs with hydrophobic characteristics [46].
Claim_set.Claim: PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogels effectively adsorb microplastics (MPs) due to their abundant porosity and the non-covalent bonding forces between the MPs and the aerogel.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption of microplastics by aerogels

Claim_set.text: The PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel and MPs exhibit pronounced hydrophobicity, facilitating the adsorption of MPs onto the aerogel through hydrophobic interactions, in accordance with the " like dissolves like " principle. Additionally, the methyl groups of MPs and PDMS chains have grasping forces, enhancing adsorption [29,46]. The zeta potential analysis (Fig. 8(b)) reveals that the MPs possess a negative charge, while the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel is positively charged, suggesting that electrostatic interaction plays a role in adsorption. Moreover, the MPs ' abundant benzene rings engage in π -π stacking with aromatic components of the aerogel [25,27]. The subtle Van der Waals forces also contribute to the adsorption process [26].
Claim_set.Claim: The PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel and MPs exhibit pronounced hydrophobicity, facilitating the adsorption of MPs onto the aerogel through hydrophobic interactions, in accordance with the " like dissolves like " principle. Additionally, the methyl groups of MPs and PDMS chains have grasping forces, enhancing adsorption. The zeta potential analysis reveals that the MPs possess a negative charge, while the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel is positively charged, suggesting that electrostatic interaction plays a role in adsorption. Moreover, the MPs' abundant benzene rings engage in π -π stacking with aromatic components of the aerogel. The subtle Van der Waals forces also contribute to the adsorption process.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption mechanisms of MPs onto the aerogel

Claim_set.text:
Due to the high concentration of MPs in the solution and the considerable number of adsorption sites on the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel, Table S1 displays that the aerogel ' s adsorption rates on MPs followed the order of K$_{i1 }$ > K$_{i2}$ . The MPs adsorption by the aerogel was swift during the first stage. However, the intra-particle diffusion rate was significantly reduced during the later stage due to the simultaneous decrease in the MPs concentration and the adsorption sites [44].

As depicted in Fig. S4(a), the adsorption rate of MPs steadily rises during the initial ten-minute interval. With an extended contact time, the adsorption rate notably decelerates and stabilizes at 40 min, reaching an equilibrium state. Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption rates of microplastics (MPs) on the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel follow the order of K$_{i1}$ > K$_{i2}$, with a rapid initial adsorption phase followed by a significant decrease in intra-particle diffusion rate as the concentration of MPs and available adsorption sites diminish.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption dynamics of microplastics on a composite aerogel

Claim_set.text: The main mechanisms include the following: (i) The introduction of P doped bacterial cellulose-derived carbon fibers with abundant defects improved the overall electrical conductivity of the catalysts, reduced the aggregation of PBAs-derived nanoparticles, constructed electrocatalysts with a three-dimensional network structure, and increased the number of active sites exposed by the electrocatalysts. (ii) Elemental doping induced more electrons transferred from Mn sites to Ni or Fe sites, optimized their electronic structure, and accelerated electron transfer. (iii) In addition, the synergistic effect of electron modulation and structure engineering further optimized the electronic structure of the surface interface of the electrocatalysts, which resulted in the MNFP-PNC/PCBC exhibiting excellent HER, OER, GCR, and overall water splitting electrocatalytic activity and stability (Fig. 8).

Claim_set.text: Benefiting from the optimized charge carrier kinetics and the broadened spectral response range compared to Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$, the photodegradation rate of tetracycline hydrochloride by Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/3BiOBr reached 0.0228 min GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, which was 6.5 and 1.5 times that of Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9 }$and BiOBr, respectively. Furthermore, the heterojunction has also shown satisfactory recycling stability and degradation universality for common organic pollutions including dyes and antibiotics.
Claim_set.Claim: Bi3TiNbO9/3BiOBr exhibits enhanced photodegradation rates for tetracycline hydrochloride, outperforming both Bi3TiNbO9 and BiOBr.
Claim_set.Topic: Photodegradation efficiency of Bi3TiNbO9/3BiOBr for tetracycline hydrochloride.
