## 4. Conclusion

A typical 2D/2D Z-scheme Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/BiOBr heterojunction was constructed by combining molten salt and hydrothermal methods. An intimate (001)/(010) face-to-face BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction was confirmed by HRTEM and XPS. BTNO/3BiOBr showed a significantly enhanced photodegradation rate of 0.0228 min GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$for TC, which was 6.5

and 1.5 times that of Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9 }$and BiOBr, respectively.
Claim_set.Claim: "BTNO/3BiOBr showed a significantly enhanced photodegradation rate of 0.0228 min^-1 for TC, which was 6.5 and 1.5 times that of Bi3TiNbO9 and BiOBr, respectively."
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced Photodegradation Performance

Claim_set.text: BiOBr was chosen to be combined with BTNO in view of its narrow bandgap and a similar bismuth-based layered crystal structure, which may be conducive to a well-matched interface with BTNO [19]. The microstructure of the BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction was studied and its photocatalytic degradation activity against organic pollutants was assessed under visible-light irradiation. Combining theoretical calculations and experimental characterization, the working mechanisms of the BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction were discussed. It was found that the close face-to-face bonding between BTNO and BiOBr provides sufficient contact and high-quality channels for charge transfer.
Claim_set.Claim: The BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction, combining BTNO and BiOBr due to their similar crystal structures, exhibits enhanced photocatalytic degradation activity under visible light, with its efficiency attributed to the well-matched interface and efficient charge transfer channels.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic degradation efficiency under visible light.

Claim_set.text: Therefore, the role of $^{1}$O$_{2 }$needs to be clarified in the FSBC-800/ PMS system. Furfuryl alcohol (FFA) was employed as a scavenger of $^{1}$O$_{2 }$ in the system, owing to its highly reactivity for $^{1}$O$_{2 }$[15]. As shown in Fig. 6a, the addition of 10 mM FFA led to a notable reduction in TC degradation, and the TC degradation decreased from the initial 94.1 % to 59.7 %. However, it has been reported that FFA can react directly with PMS, leading to the consumption of PMS in the system, which may cause false-positive results [69]. Therefore, in order to address this concern, the consumption of PMS by FFA was carefully monitored.
Claim_set.Claim: Furfuryl alcohol (FFA) significantly reduced TC degradation in the FSBC-800/PMS system, indicating its role as a scavenger of singlet oxygen (1O2).
Claim_set.Topic: Scavenging of singlet oxygen (1O2) in the FSBC-800/PMS system

Claim_set.text:
Interfacial polymerization (IP), coupling reaction and diffusion with complex regulation, is a rapid-reactive and self-inhibiting membrane preparation process that has been widely applied in manufacturing reverse osmosis and nanofiltration membranes [22 -24]. The inherent

characteristics of this process give it natural advantages in preparing gas separation membranes. On the one hand, it is relatively easy to obtain a thin and defect-free separation layer with stable separation performance at higher pressures under the broad tolerance of the equipment accuracy [25,26]. On the other hand, the interfacial polymerization processes can take full use of the multiple kinds of monomers to tailor the membrane properties specifically according to different application scenarios by adopting the interfacial engineering strategy [27].
Claim_set.Claim: Interfacial polymerization (IP) is a rapid-reactive and self-inhibiting membrane preparation process widely applied in manufacturing reverse osmosis and nanofiltration membranes, with inherent advantages in preparing gas separation membranes.Entity: Interfacial polymerizationTopic: Membrane preparation for gas separation
Claim_set.Entity: Interfacial polymerizationTopic: Membrane preparation for gas separation
Claim_set.Topic: Membrane preparation for gas separation

Claim_set.text: According to the traditional IP process, uniform and dense composite membranes are achieved by processing the polysulfone substrate successively through an aqueous phase containing amine monomers and reacting in an organic phase containing acid chloride [28]. The separation layer is firmly bonded to the substrate through the amide grown deep into the pores and maintains high permeability when fully swollen with water. Unfortunately, this situation is reversed when treating mixed gases. The infiltrated separation layer provides additional diffusion resistance greatly, attenuating the gas permeability and selectivity [29]. Therefore, due to the difficulty in removing the aqueous amine monomer in the pores of the polysulfone substrate, the IP method has rarely been reported for gas separation membranes.
Claim_set.Claim: The traditional interfacial polymerization (IP) process, involving the reaction of amine monomers in an aqueous phase with acid chloride in an organic phase, results in uniform and dense composite membranes that are firmly bonded to the polysulfone substrate. However, this method leads to reduced gas permeability and selectivity when treating mixed gases due to the additional diffusion resistance provided by the infiltrated separation layer.Entity: Polysulfone substrateTopic: Interfacial polymerization (IP) for composite membrane fabrication
Claim_set.Entity: Polysulfone substrateTopic: Interfacial polymerization (IP) for composite membrane fabrication
Claim_set.Topic: Interfacial polymerization (IP) for composite membrane fabrication

Claim_set.text: To completely solve the above problems, our team developed a new type of IP process for gas separation membranes, that is, in the membrane-preparing process, the pre-modified polysulfone substrate coated with the cross-linked silicone rubber as the gutter layer is first impregnated on one side through an organic phase containing acid chloride, and then polymerizing in the aqueous solution containing amine monomers, referred to as the " oil before water " process [30 -32]. The silicone rubber that can be swollen in the organic phase is capable of maintaining enough acid chloride on the surface and providing a diffusion domain of sufficient thickness to meet the needs of separation layer growth, avoiding the pore penetration of amidation [33 -35].
Claim_set.Claim: The "oil before water" process, a new type of IP process for gas separation membranes, involves the impregnation of a pre-modified polysulfone substrate coated with cross-linked silicone rubber in an organic phase containing acid chloride, followed by polymerization in an aqueous solution containing amine monomers. This process allows for the maintenance of sufficient acid chloride on the surface and provides a diffusion domain of adequate thickness for the growth of the separation layer, preventing pore penetration of amidation.
Claim_set.Topic: Gas separation membranes via interfacial polymerization (IP)

The source of oxygen supply during H$_{2}$O$_{2 }$production from the floating system was analyzed. As shown in Fig. 1e, oxygen was supplied through natural air and anodic oxygen evolution. It is worth noting that the unique top and bottom distribution structure of the

floating electrode makes the oxygen flux generated by the anodic oxygen evolution present an aeration-like effect. This phenomenon can not only enables direct involvement in the reaction as gaseous oxygen at the cathode CL interface, but also indirectly enhance the efficiency of H$_{2}$O$_{2 }$ production by elevating the level of dissolved oxygen (DO) in the solution. This was confirmed in subsequent discussions.

Claim_set.Claim: The unique distribution structure of the floating electrode facilitates oxygen supply for H2O2 production, enhancing efficiency by increasing dissolved oxygen levels.

The reduced performance was attributed to the occupation of active sites by organic matter and inorganic anions in the lake water, as well as competition with BPA for free radicals. The results suggest that this system is both sustainable and practical, and has great potential for application in treatment of organic pollutants in water.

## 4. Conclusions

This work presents an innovative EF based on floating electrodes for the degradation of organic pollutants. The floating system can efficiently produce H$_{2}$O$_{2 }$ (1660.39 mg L$^{-1}$) without aeration. Additionally, the unique reaction site of oxygenated graphene catalyst can promote the activation of H$_{2}$O$_{2 }$to produce · OH for high pollutant mineralization.
Claim_set.Claim: The floating electrode system efficiently produces H2O2 without aeration and promotes the activation of H2O2 to produce ·OH for high pollutant mineralization.
Claim_set.Topic: Efficient Production of H2O2 and Pollutant Mineralization

Claim_set.text: The photoluminescence and long afterglow of SrLaAlO$_{4}$:Tb were systematically evaluated, and the mechanism was proposed. The main conclusions are as follows: The substitution of Tb doesn ' t influence the crystal structure of SrLaAlO$_{4}$. The full substitution products of SrTbAlO$_{4 }$were isostructural with its SrLaAlO$_{4 }$counterpart, and its structure parameters were first reported. The bandgap of SrLaAlO$_{4}$:Tb 3 + was narrowed after Tb 3 + doping. Benefiting from the structural characteristics of layered perovskite, the photoluminescence quenching of Tb 3 + in SrLaAlO$_{4 }$ was effectively restrained, and the quenching concentration was as high as 20 at%.

## ABSTRACT

Combining adsorption with photocatalytic reduction may be an ideal emerging strategy for efficient and highly selective gold recovery, but currently reports are rare. In precious metal recovery, cheap and robust covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) offer industrial feasibility, although having selective binding sites while enhancing semiconductor performance is challenging. In this paper, we report a D-A CTF (named TD-TPTA) with abundant thiophene and triazine functional groups, narrow optical band gap, and excellent photocatalytic activity.
Claim_set.Claim: D-A CTF (TD-TPTA) offers efficient and selective gold recovery through combined adsorption and photocatalytic reduction.
Claim_set.Topic: Efficient and selective gold recovery via adsorption and photocatalytic reduction.

Claim_set.text: Benefiting from the strong interaction between [AuCl$_{4}$] GLYPH<0> (soft acid) and the abundant soft base sites (sulfur atom) on the CTF skeleton, TD-TPTA can achieve highly selective gold capture. Meanwhile, the construction of π -conjugated D-A skeleton significantly improving the photocatalytic activity and achieving efficient photocatalytic reduction of gold. Analysis reveals that through a combination of adsorption and photocatalytic reduction, TD-TPTA has high gold adsorption capacity (1123.8 mg g GLYPH<0> $^{1}$) and fast kinetics even under ultra-low pH conditions (pH = 2). In addition, TD-TPTA can selectively recover 99.45 % of gold from e-waste wastewater.
Claim_set.Claim: TD-TPTA achieves highly selective gold capture and efficient photocatalytic reduction of gold due to its strong interaction with [AuCl₄]⁻ and its π-conjugated D-A skeleton.
Claim_set.Topic: Selective gold capture and photocatalytic reduction by TD-TPTA

Claim_set.text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully constructed a CTF with strong affinity for gold. Unlike previous porous materials, our CTF has a robust covalent triazine framework, a π -conjugated D-A structure, and an abundance of soft base sites (sulfur atom). With these advantages, TDTPTA enables efficient and selective photocatalytic reduction of Au (III) from e-waste leachate, making the recovery of gold from e-waste a proven practical application.
Claim_set.Claim: TDTPTA, a CTF with a robust covalent triazine framework and an abundance of soft base sites, enables efficient and selective photocatalytic reduction of Au (III) from e-waste leachate, making gold recovery from e-waste a proven practical application.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic reduction of gold from e-waste

Therefore, the construction of a stable SEI should not be obsessed with the pursuit of high hardness and rigidity but should consider the compatibility between the SEI and zinc anode. Additionally, these studies also lack the pertinent characterization of SEI mechanical properties, thereby rendering it inaccurate to solely substantiate the exceptional electrochemical properties of SEI as evidence for its outstanding mechanical attributes.

Here, we introduce low-cost L-glutamine (Gln) additives into a 2 mol L - 1 ZnSO$_{4}$ aqueous electrolyte to address the existing knowledge gap by elucidating the regulatory mechanism of the electric double layer (EDL) structure and constructing a compatible SEI with zinc anodes ( Figure 1 b).

More importantly, this strategy is also demonstrated in Zn// NH$_{4}$V$_{4}$O$_{10}$ full cells at low N/P ratios of 5.2, 4.9, 3.5, and 2.4. This strategy of in situ constructing a topologically adaptable SEI by regulating the surface absorption environment of the Zn anode demonstrates that the performance of the SEI depends not on its rigidity and hardness but rather on its ability to withstand permanent deformation, providing a promising direction for future interfacial modulation in aqueous battery chemistry.

Claim_set.text:
Furthermore, the SEI generated in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte displays a rough and uneven morphology ( Figure 4 c), making it susceptible to puncturing the separator and resulting in battery short circuits. Conversely, an SEI formed in the Gln/ ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte with a lower hardness demonstrates improved compatibility with the separator without causing any mechanical damage. As can be seen from the load -

displacement curves ( Figure 4 n - p) of different SEI and pristine Zn, the SEI in the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits 96% irreversible deformation, while pristine Zn shows 91% irreversible deformation. S3 (a). This may be due to

the fact that the excitation at 274 nm belongs to the 4 f -5 d energy level transition, which is allowed to be a transition between group states and is strongly influenced by the surrounding environment. So, with the increase of doping concentration, the excitation shows a red shift. However, the excitation peaks in the range of 320 -380 nm belong to f -f transitions, which are forbidden and less affected by the environment because the 4 f electrons in the inner layers are shielded by the 5 s and 5 p shell electrons. Therefore, the shape and position of the excitation peaks do not change with increasing doping concentration.

## ABSTRACT

Bismuth-based layered ferroelectrics are believed to be promising photocatalysts, but the limited visible-light harvesting and severe charge carrier recombination are still restricting the overall photocatalytic efficiency. Herein, a novel 2D/2D Z-scheme Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/BiOBr heterojunction was constructed combining molten salt and hydrothermal synthesis methods. An intimate conjunction between Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9 }$ and BiOBr nanosheets was confirmed which inhibited charge carrier recombination and promoted carrier mobility in the nanocomposites.
Claim_set.Claim: The novel 2D/2D Z-scheme Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/BiOBr heterojunction, constructed through molten salt and hydrothermal synthesis methods, exhibits inhibited charge carrier recombination and enhanced carrier mobility, making it a promising photocatalyst.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced photocatalytic efficiency through charge carrier dynamics in bismuth-based layered ferroelectrics

Claim_set.text:
According to the density functional theory (DFT) calculations and experimental analysis of active species, a 2D/2D Z-scheme Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/BiOBr heterostructure was demonstrated and the possible working mechanisms were discussed. This work is hoped to add another layer of understanding depth to the design and fabrication of 2D/2D Z-scheme heterojunctions of bismuth-based layered ferroelectric photocatalysts.

## 1. Introduction

Bismuth-based layered (BBL) compounds have been receiving increased attention as efficient photocatalysts applied in energy and environment fields in the past decades [1].
Claim_set.Claim: A 2D/2D Z-scheme Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9}$/BiOBr heterostructure was demonstrated and its possible working mechanisms were discussed.
Claim_set.Topic: Design and fabrication of 2D/2D Z-scheme heterojunctions of bismuth-based layered ferroelectric photocatalysts

Claim_set.text:
Based on the above considerations, construction of a typical Z-scheme 2D/2D heterojunction is expected to optimize the charge carrier kinetics of BTNO, thereby elevating its photocatalytic efficiency. However, studies of BTNO-based Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts are still rare at present, and a deeper understanding of the effect of microstructure regulation and the working mechanisms are urgently required.

In this work we fabricated a 2D/2D Z-scheme BTNO/BiOBr heterojunction for the first time by combining the molten salt synthesis method with hydrothermal synthesis to optimize photocatalytic performance.
Claim_set.Claim: Construction of a typical Z-scheme 2D/2D heterojunction is expected to optimize the charge carrier kinetics of BTNO, thereby elevating its photocatalytic efficiency.
Claim_set.Topic: Optimization of photocatalytic efficiency through Z-scheme 2D/2D heterojunction construction

Claim_set.text:
On the basis of the experimental results, the mechanism of long afterglow luminescence of SrLaAlO$_{4}$: Tb 3 + is elaborated and discussed.

## 1. Introduction

Long afterglow luminescence is a special optical phenomenon. Corresponding products can continue to emit light for some time after excitation has ceased, due to electrons being excited and stored in the trap and subsequently released slowly by thermal energy at room temperature [1 -4]. Long afterglow phosphor has been widely used in emergency lighting and displays, decoration, optical information storage, in vivo bio-imaging night vision monitoring, etc [5 -8]. For long afterglow phosphors, emitting centers and traps are two decisive factors worth considering [9,10]. Usually, the emitting center serves as the destination of the release carrier that generates the emission.
Claim_set.Claim: SrLaAlO$_{4}$: Tb$^{3+}$ exhibits long afterglow luminescence due to the mechanism of electron excitation, storage in traps, and subsequent slow release at room temperature.
Claim_set.Topic: Long afterglow luminescence mechanism

Claim_set.text:
Novel long afterglow luminescence was observed in SrLaAlO$_{4}$:Tb due to the presence of oxygen vacancy in the host, and the afterglow time is over 1 h. The afterglow luminescence mechanism was proposed, and can well explain the observed phenomenon.

Claim_set.Claim: Afterglow luminescence in SrLaAlO$_{4}$:Tb is facilitated by oxygen vacancies, enabling a duration exceeding 1 hour.
Claim_set.Topic: Long afterglow luminescence mechanism

It can be found that the average decay time obtained under 274 nm excitation for the main emission of the same sample is longer than that obtained under 370 nm excitation. This may be because the sample produces afterglow emission under 274 nm excitation, and as a result, prolongs the average decay time for the main emission.

Claim_set.Topic: Fluorescence decay time under different excitations

Claim_set.text: Piezocatalytic H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ synthesis offers a promising alternative to traditional methods but faces challenges like sacrificial reagents, harsh conditions, and low activity. In this study, we introduce a cobalt -loaded ZnO (CZO) piezocatalyst that efficiently generates H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ from H$_{2}$O and O$_{2}$ under ultrasonic (US) treatment in ambient aqueous conditions. The catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance with ~ 50.9% TOC removal of phenol and in situ generation of 1.3 mM H$_{2}$O$_{2}$, significantly outperforming pure ZnO.
Claim_set.Claim: Cobalt-loaded ZnO (CZO) piezocatalyst efficiently generates H2O2 from H2O and O2 under ultrasonic treatment in ambient aqueous conditions, demonstrating exceptional performance with significantly higher TOC removal of phenol and in situ H2O2 generation compared to pure ZnO.
Claim_set.Topic: Piezocatalytic H2O2 synthesis under ambient conditions

Thus, a piezocatalysis -self -Fenton system has been successfully constructed over CZO piezocatalyst. Compared to pristine ZnO, the CZO piezocatalyst significantly enhanced the H$_{2}$O$_{2}$ production and the purification efficiency for refractory pollutants. This study pro­ vides insights into the design of piezocatalysts and their applica­ tions in energy conversion and environmental remediation.

## 3.3. Kinetics analysis

The differences in the electrochemical performance of S@EGO cathodes were investigated by CV at 1.6 -2.8 V and a scan rate of 0.1 mV s GLYPH<0> $^{1}$. In a typical CV curve, two reduction peaks appear at around 2.2 and 2.0 V, indicating that the reduction of sulfur to lithium sulfide occurs in two major steps. The first peak is at a higher potential corresponding to the reduction of S$_{8 }$to higher-order soluble long-chain polysulfide (Li$_{2}$S$_{n}$, 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), being a solid-phase to the liquid-phase conversion process.
Claim_set.Claim: The reduction of sulfur to lithium sulfide occurs in two major steps, with the first peak at a higher potential corresponding to the reduction of S$_{8 }$to higher-order soluble long-chain polysulfide (Li$_{2}$S$_{n}$, 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), being a solid-phase to the liquid-phase conversion process.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical performance of S@EGO cathodes

Claim_set.text: The further reduction to low-order insoluble lithium sulfide (Li$_{2}$S$_{n}$, n ≤ 2) was carried out at a lower potential of 1.9 V, corresponding to a liquid-phase to the solid-phase conversion process [45]. As part of the oxidation process, lithium sulfide is converted to sulfur in two steps: in the first step, lithium sulfide converts to an intermediate polysulfide at 2.50 V, followed by further oxidation to sulfur at 2.57 V [46]. It can be observed that the S@EGO obtained a much higher peak current and smaller polarized (Fig. 5a, S4a). In the subsequent cycles (Fig. 5a), the curves overlapped well, demonstrating that the multi-step reaction has high reversibility.
Claim_set.Claim: Lithium sulfide converts to sulfur through a two-step oxidation process, first forming an intermediate polysulfide at 2.50 V and then further oxidizing to sulfur at 2.57 V.
Claim_set.Topic: Conversion of lithium sulfide to sulfur in lithium-sulfur batteries

Claim_set.text:
## 1 Introduction

More than half of the world's known coal reserves are lowrank coal (LRC). LRC, which usually includes lignite and non-stick coal, plays an important role in global energy supply and chemical production [1, 2]. LRC belongs to low metamorphic coal, indicating that it contains abundant hydrophilic functional groups, strong hydrophilicity,

and many surface pores [1]. Therefore, froth flotation is a common beneficiation method for LRC, which uses different surface properties to separate minerals. However, the hydrophobic properties of the mineral of interest affect its separation performance [3].
Claim_set.Claim: Froth flotation is a common beneficiation method for low-rank coal (LRC) due to its ability to utilize differences in surface properties for mineral separation, but the hydrophobic properties of the mineral of interest significantly affect its separation performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Beneficiation of coal via froth flotation

Claim_set.text: However, the hydrophobic properties of the mineral of interest affect its separation performance [3]. In the case of LRC, the surface characteristics favor interactions between water molecules and hydrophilic surface sites, thus forming a hydration layer, preventing coal particles from adhering to bubbles and reducing hydrophobicity [4], and this seriously affects the flotation of LRC. Therefore, in order to obtain better flotation efficiency of LRC, a range of treatment processes have been proposed, such as pyrolysis, flotation pretreatment, and the use of flotation agents [5-7]. For example, the use of microwave radiation successfully increased the fixed carbon content and combustion calorific value of the LRC [7, 8].
Claim_set.Claim: The hydrophobic properties of the mineral of interest affect its separation performance, particularly in the case of Low-Rank Coal (LRC), where the surface characteristics favor interactions between water molecules and hydrophilic surface sites, forming a hydration layer that prevents coal particles from adhering to bubbles and reduces hydrophobicity, thus affecting flotation.Entity: Low-Rank Coal (LRC)Topic: Hydrophobic properties and separation performance in mineral processing
Claim_set.Entity: Low-Rank Coal (LRC)Topic: Hydrophobic properties and separation performance in mineral processing
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrophobic properties and separation performance in mineral processing

Claim_set.text: C-C/C-H functional groups are hydrophobic. The oxygen-containing functional groups are hydrophilic. Thus, hydrophilic groups were easy to interact with water, which increased the surface hydrophilicity of the mineral and deteriorated the flotation effect. By interacting with oxygen-containing functional groups, the hydrophobic collector improves the surface hydrophobicity of coal samples. Therefore, the adsorption effect can be inferred according to the change of the content of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of the sample [51].
Claim_set.Claim: Hydrophobic C-C/C-H functional groups and hydrophilic oxygen-containing functional groups influence the surface properties of minerals and coal samples, affecting flotation and adsorption processes.
Claim_set.Topic: Surface hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity in mineral and coal processing

Claim_set.text: It is noted that in the practical chemical lithiation process we found that the molar ratio of Bp-Li to graphite (C$_{6}$) significantly influenced the degree of lithiation. As shown in Figure 1 f, when the molar ratio was 1:1, corresponding to graphite reacting fully with an equivalent amount of Bp-Li, only a mixed phase of stage-3 Li-GICs and a small amount of original graphite could be obtained. When the ratio increased to 2:1, the products still contained some of the original graphite phase. It was not until Bp-Li was present in 4-fold excess that the phase of the original graphite completely disappeared, presenting perfectly pure stage-2 Li-GICs.
Claim_set.Claim: The molar ratio of Bp-Li to graphite significantly influences the degree of lithiation, with a 4-fold excess of Bp-Li required to obtain perfectly pure stage-2 Li-GICs.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithiation of graphite

Claim_set.text:
However, as the ratio continued to increase to 10:1 and 20:1 ( Figure S5 ), the lithiated products remained in the second stage. Only when the ratio reached 40:1 did a minimal amount of stage-1 Li-GICs appear, but pure-phase LiC$_{6}$ could still not be synthesized. Given the unnecessary expenditure of lithium and chemical reagents, persisting with an increased ratio for producing a limited amount of first-order Li-GICs had no

practical significance. Consequently, the molar ratio of 4:1 was adopted in subsequent experiments to achieve highly efficient chemical lithiation.

Structural Investigation of Stage-2 Li-GICs. The pristine graphite powder was immersed in a Bp-Li solution with mild stirring, where a homogeneous and precise lithiation reaction occurred at room temperature ( eq 2 ).
Claim_set.Claim: A molar ratio of 4:1 was adopted for highly efficient chemical lithiation of graphite to produce stage-2 lithium-graphite intercalation compounds (Li-GICs).
Claim_set.Topic: Chemical lithiation efficiency and stage-2 Li-GICs production

Claim_set.text:
The original graphite started significant lithium intercalation from 0.200 V and then went through a phase transition from stage 4 to stage 3. The stage-2 Li-GICs (LiC$_{12}$) was formed at 0.125 V, which eventually evolved into the final stage 1 at 0.085 V.

This complex Li-intercalation process makes it crucial to explore a suitable lithiation reagent to achieve the chemical lithiation of graphite. In our previous work, we developed a novel solution, biphenyl-lithium/2-methyl tetrahydrofuran (Bp-Li/2-MTHF), to realize the successful prelithiation of a graphite electrode while avoiding solvent co-intercalation.
Claim_set.Claim: The complex Li-intercalation process necessitates the exploration of a suitable lithiation reagent for chemical lithiation of graphite.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithiation process in graphite

Conclusions

In this experiment, the Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP with heterostructure composite electrode was prepared by hydrothermal calcination phosphating. Claim_set.text: Normalization of the discharge and charge times is performed to plot the internal resistance of the two electrodes, which corresponds to the activation process of Li$_{2}$S at a discharge depth of 1.1 and the conversion of Li$_{2}$S$_{2 }$to solid Li$_{2}$S at a discharge depth of ~0.95. Obviously, the S@EGO electrode has a low internal resistance, which indicates that the charge transfer impedance and interfacial resistance of this electrode are smaller during the charge and discharge process. Meanwhile, the internal resistance of the electrode is significantly larger than that of the dissolution and shuttle phases during the nucleation phase at a discharge depth of ~0.35, which represents the need to overcome higher energy barriers during Li$_{2}$S nucleation.

Claim_set.text: The EIS of four materials assembled into a cell is presented in Fig. 7a. All four impedance curves consist of a depressed semicircle in the high-frequency region and a sloping straight line in the low-frequency region, corresponding to the charge transfer impedance (R$_{ct}$) and Warburg impedance (W$_{o}$) [52,53]. Compared with S@GO, the S@EGO-85 · C electrode has the lowest Rct value, indicating it has the lowest charge transfer impedance. The S@EGO-85 · C electrode was tested for cycling, plotting Nyquist plots and equivalent circuit diagrams before and after cycling (Fig. 7b).
Claim_set.Claim: The S@EGO-85 · C electrode exhibits the lowest charge transfer impedance among four materials assembled into a cell, as indicated by its Rct value in the EIS analysis.

## 3.4. Electrical conductivity

The electrical conductivities and Arrhenius plots for PBO, PBCC and PBSCCO are presented in Fig. 4a and b. Between 100 and 850 °C, all samples exhibit a decrease in electrical conductivity as temperature rises, indicating metallic conduction behavior. The electrical conductivity can be described by the small polaron conduction

mechanism, and electrons hop between Co$^{4+}$- O$^{2-}$- Co$^{3+ }$for conduction [18, 48, 49].
Claim_set.Claim: Electrical conductivity of PBO, PBCC, and PBSCCO decreases with increasing temperature from 100 to 850 °C, indicating metallic conduction behavior.

Claim_set.text: At 700 °C, the conductivity values of PBC, PBCC and PBSCCC are 471.6 S cm$^{-1}$, 634.5 S cm$^{-1}$ and 935.5 S cm$^{-1}$, respectively, significantly surpassing the required threshold (100 S cm$^{-1}$) for application in SOFCs [50]. All samples show linear relationships in the low temperature region of the Arrhenius plots, and the activation energies for PBC, PBCC and PBSCCC are calculated as 3.01, 2.97 and 2.74 kJ mol$^{-1}$, respectively (Fig. 4b).
Claim_set.Claim: The conductivity values of PBC, PBCC, and PBSCCC at 700 °C significantly surpass the required threshold for application in SOFCs, with PBSCCC exhibiting the highest conductivity of 935.5 S cm$^{-1}$.
Claim_set.Topic: Conductivity of materials for application in Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs)

Claim_set.text:
## 3. Conclusion

This work proposes a novel active site in situ refreshing strategy of electro-catalytic materials to greatly enhance the durability of electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution by water splitting. Briefly, a composite catalyst of Ni(PO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ being embedded in an amorphous molybdenum compound matrix was fabricated, which will expose the inside Ni(PO$_{3}$)$_{2}$ andinsituformedNi$_{2}$P active sites by the matrix dissolution into the electrolyte without the losses of these active sites. Importantly, the following dissolutiondeposition dynamic equilibrium of the amorphous matrix during the electrochemical HER ensures the effective and long-lasting activation of the catalyst without noticeable activity degradation.
Claim_set.Claim: A composite catalyst of Ni(PO3)2 embedded in an amorphous molybdenum compound matrix exhibits enhanced durability for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution by water splitting, due to the in situ refreshing of active sites.
Claim_set.Topic: Active site refreshing strategy for electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution

Thus, the optimized NiCoDH-Mo0.50 electrode has a high specific capacity of 160.5 mAh g GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$at a current density of 1 A g GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$and can maintain a high specific capacity of 115.3 mAh g GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$when the current density increases by 20 times.

## 4. Conclusions

In summary, Mo-doped nickel cobalt double hydroxide (NiCoDHMo) with hierarchical cauliflower-like microspheres consisting of nanosheets was successfully synthesized using a rapid microwaveassistant hydrothermal method in tens of minutes. The effect of Mo doping on the microstructure, crystal structure, porosity, and electrochemical performance of NiCoDH was investigated. The NiCoDHMo0.50 shows a high specific surface area of 91.7 m 2 g GLYPH<0> 1 and an improved electrical conductivity of 0.0233 μ S cm GLYPH<0> $^{1}$.
Claim_set.Claim: Mo-doped nickel cobalt double hydroxide (NiCoDHMo0.50) demonstrates excellent cycling stability, maintaining 84% of its initial capacity after 8000 charge-discharge cycles, with a Coulombic efficiency over 99%.
Claim_set.Topic: Cycling stability and Coulombic efficiency of Mo-doped nickel cobalt double hydroxide

Claim_set.text:
Herein, a rapid microwave-assistant hydrothermal method was utilized to prepare molybdenum-doped nickel-cobalt double hydroxides (NiCoDH-Mo). By adjusting the molybdenum doping amount, the changes in the physicochemical properties and electrochemical performance of NiCoDH-Mo were investigated. The optimized NiCoDHMo0.50 electrode shows excellent specific capacitance, rate capability, and cycling stability. Moreover, a hybrid supercapacitor assembled with NiCoDH-Mo0.50 cathode and mango seed-derived activated carbon anode exhibits excellent energy density, power density, and cycling stability.

reconfiguration at the active sites of metal, which in turn can change the adsorption strength of adsorbates [30 -33]. For example, Wang et al. reported a catalyst with iron clusters to modify individual FeN$_{4 }$ sites. The introduction of iron clusters changed the electronic structure of FeN$_{4 }$in the active site, which changed the d-band centers of Fe in FeN$_{4 }$ and decreased the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediate OH* to accelerate the ORR, so that these changes together considerably enhanced the ORR performance [34].

Claim_set.text: Furthermore, the introduction of Mn clusters can disrupt the planar structure of the Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$through axial traction, which can lead to electronic reconfiguration of Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$sites, lowering of the dband center of Mn, and weakening of the adsorption of the oxygencontaining intermediate OH* on the catalyst [31]. These changes improved the ORR performance. This strategy of modifying homonuclear double single-atom sites with metal clusters provides a new insight into the optimization of electronic structures to boost electrocatalytic performance in the future.
Claim_set.Claim: Introduction of Mn clusters disrupts the planar structure of Mn₂-N₆ sites, leading to electronic reconfiguration and improved ORR performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Electronic reconfiguration and ORR performance in modified homonuclear double single-atom sites

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that the total energy barrier of the ORR decreased for the FeN$_{4}$-O-MnN$_{4 }$ moiety, which greatly enhanced the ORR performance [29].

Claim_set.text:
Computational methods

The first principles were used to perform all spin-polarization density functional theory (DFT) calculations within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew-Burke -Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation in the CASTEP code. The geometry optimizations were performed using the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) algorithm. The kinetic cut-off energy of the plane-wave basis was 450 eV. The convergence criteria for the total energy and forces were set as 10 -$^{5 }$eV and 0.01 eV Å -$^{1}$, respectively. The vacuum spacing in the direction perpendicular to the plane of the structure was 12 Å. Brillouin zone integration was performed by 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling for the structure.
Claim_set.Claim: The computational methods employed in the text involve spin-polarization density functional theory (DFT) calculations using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation, with geometry optimizations carried out via the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) algorithm. The plane-wave basis kinetic cut-off energy was set at 450 eV, and convergence criteria for total energy and forces were 10^-5 eV and 0.01 eV Å^-1, respectively. The vacuum spacing for the structure was 12 Å, and Brillouin zone integration was conducted with 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling.
Claim_set.Topic: Computational Methods in Materials Science

Claim_set.text: Computational Methods. First-principles calculations were carried out using Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) software with the projector augmented-wave (PAW) method. 27 The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parametrized by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) was employed to describe the exchangecorrelation potential. 28 The heterojunction structure optimization and electronic structure calculation were carried out using a cutoff energy of 500 eV. A 2 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst - Pack γ -centered k -point grid was employed for Brillouin zone sampling. The convergence threshold of self-consistent filed iterations was set to 10 - 4 eV.

The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parametrized by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) was employed to describe the exchange-correlation potential. The heterojunction structure optimization and electronic structure calculation were carried out using a cutoff energy of 500 eV. A 2 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst - Pack γ -centered k -point grid was employed for Brillouin zone sampling. The convergence threshold of self-consistent field iterations was set to 10 - 4 eV.

The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the projectoraugmented wave (PAW) method were employed to describe the electron-electron and electron-ion interactions, respectively. A cutoff energy of 500 eV was used to achieve maximum valence electron accuracy. The size of the unit cell was set to a 2 × 3 × 1 supercell. The Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid of 12 × 10 × 12 was used. The convergence criterion for atomic forces was set to 0.02 eV Å GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, and the energy convergence criterion for electrons was set to 10 GLYPH<0> $^{5 }$eV. The lattice parameters of all crystal models were fully relaxed.

Claim_set.text: The outstanding electrochemical performance of Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$@C@MoS$_{2}$ can be ascribed to the robust confinement structure, the excellent conductivity provided by the carbon layer, and the local-expanded interlayer spacing. The expanded interlayer spacing and nanovoids promote ion migration for fast and reversible Na storage reactions.

Claim_set.text:
Compared with COF-H, the saturated adsorption capacity of COFBmim, COF-MC$_{4}$trim, and COF-AC$_{4}$trim was significantly increased. It is speculated that the sulfonic acid group should be the adsorption site of COF-H. ILSP replaces the proton of the sulfonic acid group on the COFs with a large volume of imidazolium/triazolium cations, which cannot bind tightly to the sulfonic acid group, resulting in charge separation near the sulfonic acid group. The stronger electrostatic interaction caused by charge separation further activates this adsorption site, which may be the possible reason for the significant increase in saturated adsorption capacity.

## 3. Results and discussion

## 3.1. Preparation and characterization of COFs

Three types of ionic liquids were chosen, BmimBr, MC$_{4}$trimBr, and AC$_{4}$trimBr (the chemical structure shown in Figure S1), with electrophilicity decreasing sequentially. In the ILSP strategy, the protons on COF-H will be replaced with corresponding large-volume electrophilic cations. As shown in Fig. 2a, the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of COF-H revealed strip-like morphology and well-ordered stacking. The clear lattice fringes TEM image (Figure S2) showed the high crystallinity of COF-H.
Claim_set.Claim: The ionic liquid-assisted strategy (ILSP) facilitates the replacement of protons on COF-H with large-volume electrophilic cations, as evidenced by the use of BmimBr, MC$_{4}$trimBr, and AC$_{4}$trimBr with decreasing electrophilicity.
Claim_set.Topic: Ionic liquid-assisted strategy (ILSP) for COF modification

The carbon content of tea residue accounts for about 50 %, in addition, it is rich in carboxyl, hydroxyl, amino and other functional groups, which can be converted into biochar materials by thermochemical means such as pyrolysis[8]. Nano-biochar (NBC) is an emerging environmentally friendly nanocarbon material.
Claim_set.Claim: "Utilizing the structural properties of ErNBC, an electrochemical sensor combined with machine learning was developed for selective detection of Pb^2+ in actual water samples with a satisfactory recovery rate."
Claim_set.Topic: Development of an electrochemical sensor for lead detection in water samples.

Claim_set.text:
## 5. Determination of Pb 2 þ in real water samples

Actual samples were selected from river water (Liuyang River, Changsha, China) and farmland water (Yunyuan Base, Changsha, China). To verify the accuracy of the Nafion/ErNBC/GCE sensor, we compared the detection results with ICP and portable electrochemical detection methods. All the three methods used standard addition method to detect Pb 2 + . The results are shown in Table S4. The recovery rate of lead ions in water samples by the sensor is 97.6 % GLYPH<0> 102.2 %, which is close to the 98.3 %-103.2 % of the traditional method, confirming the reliability and accuracy of the sensor.
Claim_set.Claim: The Nafion/ErNBC/GCE sensor accurately detects Pb^2+ in water samples, with a recovery rate of 97.6%-102.2%, comparable to traditional methods.
Claim_set.Topic: Accurate detection of Pb^2+ in water samples

Claim_set.text:
Both methods calculated detection limits below the World Health Organization ' s maximum level of Pb 2 + in the water environment (10 μ g/L). Therefore, the sensor can effectively detect Pb 2 + in water. The linear range and LOD are better than those reported in most typical Pb 2 + analysis literatures, as listed in Table 1.

Machine learning models of sensor (Fig. 7f and 7 g). The evaluation indexes of each model include the correlation coefficient (R$^{2}$) and root mean square error (RMSE) of the training set and the test set. Both the RMSE and R$^{2 }$measures are based on square error, so there will be some impact if the measurement contains outliers. To avoid this effect, the mean absolute error (MAE) was introduced to better evaluate the model.
Claim_set.Claim: The sensor can effectively detect Pb 2+ in water with detection limits below the World Health Organization's maximum level.
Claim_set.Topic: Water quality monitoring with a sensor for lead detection

## 3. Results and discussion

## 3.1. Synthesis and characterization of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3

The detailed synthetic process for Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1a. In short, ZIF-67 was wrapped in the outer layer of ZnFe-ZIF to obtain ZnFe-ZIF@ZIF-67 with a core -shell structure using the epitaxial growth method. Then, the Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst was obtained by the pyrolysis of ZnFeZIF@ZIF-67.
Claim_set.Claim: Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3 catalyst was synthesized via a pyrolysis process from ZnFeZIF@ZIF-67 precursor.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis and characterization of Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3

Significantly, the morphologies and structures of the spent catalysts remained identical to those of the fresh catalysts based on XRD, SEM, and TEM measurements ( Figures S27 , S28 , and S29 ). Therefore, these results indicate that AB hydrolysis

exhibits greater efficiency and stability over Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ compared to Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC, potentially attributed to SiO$_{2}$ confinement, which effectively mitigated the loss of metals due to dissolution. According to our results and previous reports, [34,35,37] we can deduce that the silica-confined layer, as a protection layer, can stabilize metal nanoparticles/clusters by decreasing surface energy of metal atoms, thus stabilizing the metal NPs.
Claim_set.Claim: Silica-confined layer stabilizes metal nanoparticles/clusters by decreasing surface energy of metal atoms, thus stabilizing the metal NPs.
Claim_set.Topic: Stabilization of metal nanoparticles/clusters

Claim_set.text: Additionally, silica protection layer serves as oxide substrate to interact with metal NPs, which can increase migration energy barrier of metal NPs, thereby preventing their aggregation and loss. To elucidate the interaction between SiO$_{2}$ and metal NPs, force-field molecular dynamics (FFMD) analysis was employed to simulate the migration of CoCu-alloy NPs on the external surface of NC@mSiO$_{2 }$ and NC, respectively ( Figure S30 , Supporting Video S2 , and S3 ). As shown in Figure S31 , the spatial confinement imposed by the mSiO$_{2}$ shell on the Co-Cu-alloy NPs enhanced the interaction between the Co-Cu-alloy NPs and the NC surface.
Claim_set.Claim: Silica protection layer serves as an oxide substrate to interact with metal NPs, increasing migration energy barrier of metal NPs, thereby preventing their aggregation and loss.
Claim_set.Topic: Interaction between silica and metal NPs in preventing aggregation

Claim_set.text: Figure S32 reveals that the interaction between the electronegative oxygen of the SiO$_{2}$ shell and Co-Cu-alloy NPs can prevent the migration of CoCu-alloy to the solution phase. Therefore, as shown in Figure S33 , the mean-square displacement of the Co-Cu-alloy in NC@mSiO$_{2}$ was almost undetectable compared to that in NC, directly illustrating that the mSiO$_{2}$ shell can effectively prevent the loss of Co-Cu-alloy NPs. Furthermore, both Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC and Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2 }$ exhibited excellent magnetic recovery performance, which was beneficial for the separation and reuse of the catalyst ( Figure S34 ).
Claim_set.Claim: The interaction between the electronegative oxygen of the SiO2 shell and Co-Cu-alloy NPs prevents their migration to the solution phase, leading to an almost undetectable mean-square displacement of the Co-Cu-alloy in NC@mSiO2 compared to NC. This illustrates the effective prevention of Co-Cu-alloy NP loss by the mSiO2 shell. Additionally, both Co0.8Cu0.2@NC and Co0.8Cu0.2@NC@mSiO2 exhibit excellent magnetic recovery performance, beneficial for catalyst separation and reuse.
Claim_set.Topic: Interaction and migration prevention of Co-Cu-alloy NPs within SiO2 shells in catalyst systems

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Carbon dots (CDs) as a novel and green nanomaterial exhibit a promising application in enhancing the chloride binding capacity of cement to extend the service life of reinforced concrete (RC) structures. However, their size influence on the enhancement of chloride binding is still a research gap, enormously hindering the further employment of CDs toward cement system. Herein, their size-induced effect on chloride binding actions of cement is comprehensively unveiled using CDs with various sizes for the first time. Specifically, three kinds of CDs with different sizes are controllably prepared through simply altering the calcinating time of citric acid. And the relationship between sizes of CDs and chloride binding capacity of cement is confirmed through the equilibrium tests. More importantly, the mechanism for the effect of CDs sizes on chloride binding is reasonably proposed according to the alteration analyses of phase compositions.
Claim_set.Claim: The size of carbon dots (CDs) significantly influences their ability to enhance the chloride binding capacity of cement, thereby affecting the service life of reinforced concrete (RC) structures.
Claim_set.Topic: Size-induced effect of carbon dots on chloride binding in cement.

Claim_set.text: However, these nanomaterials are subject to poor dispersity and high cost [18 -20], restricting their large-scale application in practical engineering. Fortunately, carbon dots (CDs), as a novel zero-dimensional carbon-based nanomaterial, possess not only distinguished dispersity and low cost, but also benign environmental friendliness, high chemical stability, easily available precursors, tunable surface groups and ultrasmall size, thus attracting intensive attention [21 -26]. For instance, Qu et al. firstly utilized CDs to improve the compressive strength of cement-based composites, and revealed the relevant mechanism [27]. Recently, Li ' s group reported that CDs could endow foams of foam concrete with higher density, viscosity and stability [28].
Claim_set.Claim: Carbon dots (CDs) are a novel zero-dimensional carbon-based nanomaterial that possess distinguished dispersity, low cost, benign environmental friendliness, high chemical stability, easily available precursors, tunable surface groups, and ultrasmall size, making them attractive for various applications including improving the properties of cement-based composites and foam concrete.
Claim_set.Topic: Nanomaterials for engineering applications

Claim_set.text: However, similar to high-Ni cathodes, its development is constrained by its extremely poor air stability. [8] LFO commonly appears to have obvious capacity losses upon the handling and storage processes under an air atmosphere, which may stem from the formation of residual Li species (e.g., Li$_{2}$O, LiOH, or Li$_{2}$CO$_{3}$). These alkaline residuals on the surface of LFO will result in high interfacial resistance and poor kinetic performance.
Claim_set.Claim: LFO cathodes suffer from significant capacity loss due to the formation of alkaline residuals like Li2O, LiOH, and Li2CO3 upon exposure to air, leading to high interfacial resistance and poor kinetic performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Air Stability of LFO Cathodes

Claim_set.text: In this work, LFO was subjected to different gas atmospheres (O$_{2}$,CO$_{2}$,andN$_{2}$; mimicking the major components of air) and 30% humidity air for different times to explore their impacts on Li$_{5}$FeO$_{4}$ and the LFO-air interface chemistry. We found that Li + ions will escape from the LFO crystal lattice to construct Li$_{2}$O and Li$_{2}$CO$_{3}$ impurity phases in contact with air; Fe 3 + ions will be dissolved to form Fe$_{2}$O$_{3}$ on the particle surface. These species serve as an insulating layer and thus lead to an increment of interfacial impedance and an apparent capacity degradation. We also proposed a facile and viable surface coating strategy to improve LFO's air stability.
Claim_set.Claim: Li+ ions escape from the LFO crystal lattice to form Li2O and Li2CO3 impurity phases in contact with air, leading to an insulating layer that increases interfacial impedance and causes capacity degradation.
Claim_set.Topic: Impact of air exposure on LFO's stability and performance

Claim_set.text: Here, we conducted the first longtime cycling experiments on the MXene-containing material of an Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN-150 composite sample (see Figure 7 e), which was exposed to the simulated sunlight for up to 120 h. In addition, the absence of the N -H bond and the formation of the N -Mn bond in PCN-224-Mn in Fig. 1I verified the successful coordination of the porphyrin cavity with Mn 2 + .

The thermal stability result is shown in Fig. 1J. The weight loss in the range of 100 · C~380 · C was due to the dehydration of Zr$_{6 }$nodes. The apparent weightlessness of the second stage in the temperature range from 380 · C~550 · C was attributed to the decomposition of porphyrin in the MOF [35]. When the temperature exceeded 550 · C, the weight of PCN-224-Mn tended to stabilize, possibly owing to that Mn 2 + was connected to the porphyrin center through coordination to form a stable structure.
Claim_set.Claim: The thermal stability of PCN-224-Mn is characterized by weight loss due to dehydration of Zr$_{6}$ nodes up to 380°C, followed by decomposition of porphyrin up to 550°C, and stabilization above 550°C due to the formation of a stable structure through coordination of Mn²⁺ with the porphyrin center.
Claim_set.Topic: Thermal Stability of Metal-Organic Framework (MOF)

Claim_set.text:
The DTG curves in Fig. 1K illustrate that PCN-224-Mn did not exhibit an obvious thermal degradation peak when the temperature exceeded 550 · C, which confirmed that the structure of PCN-224 modified with Mn 2 + was stable.

The optical property was further analyzed. As illustrated in Fig. 1L, PCN-224 exhibited the UV -vis absorption peaks at 432 nm and in the range of 500 ~ 700 nm belonging to the score and Q bands of TCPP, respectively [35]. In contrast, the score band of PCN-224-Mn was significantly redshifted, and the Q-band intensity was weakened, indicating the coordination of Mn 2 + with the porphyrin cavity. The above data fully confirmed the successful preparation of PCN-224-Mn.

Claim_set.text: In this study, porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanospheres supported FeCo alloy nanoparticles (FeCo/PCNs) were prepared by nano-emulsion, impregnation, and high-temperature annealing. After embedding FeCo alloy in a porous carbon nanosphere host, it successfully prevents quick corrosion in the catalytic process, and the N atom in PCNs skeleton effectively changes the charge distribution of carbon carrier, forming a high-active site of Fe//Co-N$_{x}$. The synthesized catalyst demonstrated exceptional bifunctional activity.
Claim_set.Claim: FeCo/PCNs catalysts exhibit exceptional bifunctional activity due to the prevention of quick corrosion and the formation of high-active sites.
Claim_set.Topic: Porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanospheres supported FeCo alloy nanoparticles

It can be seen that FeCo/PCNs have the smallest semicircle diameter among all catalysts, signifying a lower electrochemical impedance. Consequently, the FeCo/PCNs catalyst has a faster charge transfer rate during oxygen reduction catalysis, which also means that it has a faster oxygen reduction Faradaic process [42].

The durability of the catalyst is an important factor that will affect its practical application. The catalytic stability of FeCo/PCNs and Pt/C was measured by chronoamperometry (CA) in Fig. 4h.
Claim_set.Claim: FeCo/PCNs exhibit the lowest electrochemical impedance among the tested catalysts, facilitating a faster charge transfer rate during oxygen reduction catalysis.

## 4. Conclusions

Based on the combination of nano-emulsion method, impregnation method, and high-temperature pyrolysis, FeCo/PCNs bifunctional electrocatalyst was successfully synthesized. The prepared catalyst showed the morphology of porous nanospheres with a diameter of about 200 nm, and the surface of the porous nanospheres was evenly loaded with alloy nanoparticles coated with carbon layers.
Claim_set.Claim: The FeCo/PCNs catalyst can dramatically improve the battery performance of ZAB due to its excellent ORR/OER bifunctional catalytic performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Improvement of ZAB battery performance with a bifunctional electrocatalyst

## 2.3. Synthesis of the foreign element modified NiCoP-based catalysts

In order to synthesize the foreign element modified NiCoP-based catalysts, the precursors prepared as described above and NaH$_{2}$PO$_{2 }$ (1.0 g) were placed downstream and upstream of the ceramic vessel, respectively, and annealed at 300 · C for 2 h by low-temperature phosphating in N$_{2 }$atmosphere at a ramp rate of 2 · C per minute, and then cooled down to 25 · C to get foreign element modified NiCoP-based catalysts. For comparison, a set of non-immersed NiCoP/NF was simultaneously synthesized as a blank control group following the above procedure.

Claim_set.text:
## 1. Introduction

Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in water splitting is a highly promising means of obtaining pure hydrogen, which can be powered by the green electricity such as renewable and intermittent wind and solar energy, and high activity electrocatalysts as well, demonstrating huge potential in future clean energy infrastructure. [1] However, HER electrocatalysts applied for industrial water splitting have to sustain harsh conditions, such as large enough current density, ultra-long working period, elevated ambient pressure, and temperature, [2] which bring about great challenges to the durability of electrodes. The performance degradation of the catalyst at industrial current density is mainly caused by the decrease of active site density and the deactivation of active sites.
Claim_set.Claim: High activity electrocatalysts are crucial for efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in water splitting, which is a key process for obtaining pure hydrogen powered by renewable energy sources, showcasing potential in future clean energy infrastructure.
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) in Water Splitting

Claim_set.text:
## 1. Introduction

Hydrogen evolution from electrochemical water-splitting (HER) has been vigorously pursued as an attractive rout to mitigate the dependence on fossil fuels [1,2]. Nevertheless, owing to the high energy consumption for both water dissociation and hydrogencoupled electron transfer in HER, the total electrolysis efficiency is limited and seriously insufficient [3,4]. In this regard, developing efficient electrocatalysts possessing sufficient water and proton adsorption sites is essential to the substantial advance of HER. Till now, precious platinum-based materials with high activity are still the dominantly used catalysts. However, the finite source and high cost significantly impede their commercial utilization in scalable hydrogen production.
Claim_set.Claim: Developing efficient electrocatalysts possessing sufficient water and proton adsorption sites is essential to the substantial advance of HER.
Claim_set.Topic: Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) Efficiency

Claim_set.text:
In the EIS plot

(Fig. 4c), it can be seen that HER and OER are clearly different and it can be seen that the target catalyst is clearly superior to the rest of the catalysts in the EIS plot of HER. It can be reasonably inferred that the OER reaction that occurs at the anode has an oxidative corrosion effect in alkaline seawater, and the corrosion of the anode electrodes is more severe compared to the hydrogen evolution reaction at the cathode, so it leads to the EIS test results of the OER experimental group to be significantly inferior to that of the HER. It can be observed in the Tafel slope (Fig. 4d) that the slope of the target catalyst is 171.13 mV/dec, which is better than the rest of the experimental group, further suggesting that the catalyst has better reaction kinetics.
Claim_set.Claim: The target catalyst exhibits superior performance in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) compared to other catalysts, as evidenced by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and Tafel slope analyses.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst performance in HER and OER reactions

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

For human health and environment safety, it is of great significance to develop novel materials with high effectiveness for removal of lead from not only aqueous solutions but also human body and traditional Chinese medicines. Here, functional kiwi peel composite, manganese dioxide decorated kiwi peel powder (MKPP), is proposed for the removal of Pb 2 + effectively. The adsorption of Pb 2 + in aqueous solution is a highly selective and endothermic process and kinetically follows a pseudo-second-order model, which can reach equilibrium with the capacity of 192.7 mg/g within 10 min. Comprehensive factors of hydration energy, charge-to-radius ratio and softness of Pb 2 + make a stronger affinity between MKPP and Pb 2 + . The possible adsorption mechanism involves covalent bond, electrostatic force and chelation, etc.
Claim_set.Claim: Manganese dioxide decorated kiwi peel powder (MKPP) is proposed for the effective removal of Pb^2+ from aqueous solutions, human body, and traditional Chinese medicines.
Claim_set.Entity: MKPP (Manganese dioxide decorated kiwi peel powder)
Claim_set.Topic: Removal of lead (Pb^2+) from various media

Claim_set.text:
Thermodynamic study further revealed the details of the adsorption behavior with the change of temperature. Van ' t Hoff plot

Table 1 showed a comparison of Pb + adsorption performance of MKPP with some other MnO$_{2}$-based and peel-based adsorbents. Generally, the adsorption capacity of MKPP was not obviously higher than others due to the existence of kiwi peel matrix with relatively poor ability of adsorption. However, it is precisely because of the presence of kiwi peel matrix that MnO$_{2 }$ nanoparticles can be uniformly dispersed without agglomeration, resulting in faster adsorption kinetics than other MnO$_{2}$-based adsorbents (shorter equilibrium time and larger k$_{2}$ ). Considering adsorption capacity and adsorption rate comprehensively, MKPP showed more promising for the effective removal of Pb 2 + .
Claim_set.Claim: MKPP demonstrates promising performance for the effective removal of Pb^2+ due to its ability to maintain a balance between adsorption capacity and rate, outperforming other MnO2-based and peel-based adsorbents.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption performance of MKPP for Pb^2+ removal

Claim_set.text:
Among them, MnO$_{2 }$ is considered as one of the most effective metal oxides for the adsorption of Pb 2 + due to its structural flexibility, low cost and environmental friendliness (Yang et al., 2021; Li et al., 2018; Lin and Chen, 2020b). Therefore, MnO$_{2 }$ is a good candidate for the modification of kiwi peel to enhance the adsorption of Pb 2 + .

Motivated by the previous findings, we propose a strategy for effective removal of Pb 2 + from aqueous solutions by manganese dioxide decorated kiwi peel powder (MKPP). Specifically, kiwi peel powder (KPP) first interacted with Mn 2 + via multiple functional groups on the surface to form Mn 2 + -loaded kiwi peel powder (KPP -Mn 2 + ).
Claim_set.Claim: MnO2 is considered one of the most effective metal oxides for the adsorption of Pb2+ due to its structural flexibility, low cost, and environmental friendliness.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption of Pb2+ by metal oxides

Overall, the significantly improved Cr tolerance makes ME-GBCO a promising cathode material for IT-SOFC. Our work confirms that configuration entropy engineering is an effective approach for rational design of Crtolerant cathodes for SOFC.

Claim_set.text: We also found that molecular holetransporters bearing a CPA as anchoring group showed enhanced amphiphilicity, and the CPA group serves as an efficient chemical passivation agent for defective lead ions (Pb$^{2+}$) in perovskite.$^{[14]}$ Therefore, to match with FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite, we specifically designed a new CPA-based amphiphilic molecular hole-transporter (PTZ-CPA) using PTZ as the hole-selective moiety. The amphiphilic character of PTZ-CPA was verified by solubility test in different solvents with largely varied polarities (Figure S1).
Claim_set.Claim: Molecular hole transporters with CPA anchoring groups exhibit enhanced amphiphilicity and serve as efficient chemical passivation agents for defective lead ions in perovskite.
Claim_set.Topic: Amphiphilic molecular hole transporters for perovskite materials

Claim_set.text:
## Stability of Thin Films and Devices

The long-term stability of FAPbI$_{3}$-based perovskite is an enormous challenge as it is prone to phase transition at ambient conditions. We found that the application of amphiphilic molecular hole-transporter has a positive effect on stabilizing the black phase of FAPbI$_{3}$. As mentioned above, during wetting and spin-coating process, part of the PTZ-CPA will penetrate into the perovskite layer. These molecules not only contribute to the crystallization of perovskite but also strongly interact with perovskite compositions at the grain boundaries, which have an impact on its stability. The functional group of CPA has been confirmed to chelate with Pb$^{2+}$ in perovskite, which may increase the activation energy of ion migration and phase transition.
Claim_set.Claim: The application of amphiphilic molecular hole-transporter stabilizes the black phase of FAPbI$_{3}$ perovskite by interacting with perovskite compositions at the grain boundaries and increasing the activation energy of ion migration and phase transition.
Claim_set.Topic: Stability of thin films and devices

Claim_set.text: Abstract: Formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI$_{3}$) represents an optimal absorber material in perovskite solar cells (PSCs), while the application of FAPbI$_{3}$ in inverted-structured PSCs has yet to be successful, mainly owing to its inferior film-forming on hydrophobic or defective hole-transporting substrates. Herein, we report a substantial improvement of FAPbI$_{3}$-based inverted PSCs, which is realized by a multifunctional amphiphilic molecular hole-transporter, (2-(4-(10 H -phenothiazin-10-yl)phenyl)-1-cyanovinyl)phosphonic acid (PTZ-CPA).
Claim_set.Claim: Formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI$_{3}$) represents an optimal absorber material in perovskite solar cells (PSCs), but its application in inverted-structured PSCs has been hindered by poor film-forming on hydrophobic or defective hole-transporting substrates. This issue is addressed by the use of a multifunctional amphiphilic molecular hole-transporter, (2-(4-(10 H -phenothiazin-10-yl)phenyl)-1-cyanovinyl)phosphonic acid (PTZ-CPA), leading to a substantial improvement in FAPbI$_{3}$-based inverted PSCs.
Claim_set.Topic: Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) and the use of Formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI$_{3}$) as an absorber material.

Claim_set.text: Here we report a medium entropy GdBa(Mn$_{0.2}$Fe$_{0.2}$Co$_{1.2}$Ni$_{0.2}$Cu$_{0.2}$)O$_{5}$ + δ (ME-GBCO) double perovskite cathode, which exhibits remarkably improved Cr-tolerant ability. The polarization resistance (R$_{p}$) of GBCO increases from ~0.44 to ~0.70 Ω cm$^{2 }$after 20 h exposure to Cr in air at 700 · C. In contrast, R$_{p }$value of ME-GBCO cathode increases from ~0.16 to ~0.24 Ω cm$^{2 }$under the same condition.
Claim_set.Claim: The medium entropy GdBa(Mn$_{0.2}$Fe$_{0.2}$Co$_{1.2}$Ni$_{0.2}$Cu$_{0.2}$)O$_{5}$ + δ (ME-GBCO) double perovskite cathode exhibits remarkably improved Cr-tolerant ability, with a significantly lower increase in polarization resistance (R$_{p}$) after exposure to Cr in air at 700°C compared to the GBCO cathode.
Claim_set.Topic: Cr-tolerant ability of medium entropy double perovskite cathodes

Claim_set.text:
## 4. Conclusion

In summary, the ME-GBCO electrode is successfully synthesized and evaluated as a Cr-tolerant cathode for IT-SOFC. ME-GBCO cathode demonstrates much higher ORR activity and significantly enhanced durability against gaseous Cr contaminants in comparison to GBCO

Ceramics International xxx (xxxx) xxx Yuan et al.

cathode. After testing in the presence of Cr vapor, GBCO degrades significantly with obvious surface change, due to the formation of massive BaCrO$_{4 }$and Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$phases. As for ME-GBCO cathode, only many BCO nanoparticles can be found, which is proved to be very inactive towards Cr vapors.
Claim_set.Claim: ME-GBCO cathode demonstrates significantly enhanced durability against gaseous Cr contaminants compared to GBCO cathode.
Claim_set.Topic: Cr-tolerant cathode for IT-SOFC

The diffraction peaks of BTNO and BiOBr nanosheets coincided with standard orthorhombic BTNO (PDF#73-2180) and tetragonal BiOBr (PDF#78-0348), respectively, demonstrating the successful preparation of pure BTNO and BiOBr. For the XRD patterns of BTNO/BiOBr composites, all the peaks could be attributed to BTNO and BiOBr, and no other impurity phases can be detected. It was found that with the increasing amount of BiOBr, the characteristic peak intensity of BTNO gradually decreased, reflecting the phase composition changes of the BTNO/BiOBr composites.
Claim_set.Claim: The XRD patterns of BTNO and BiOBr nanosheets match their respective standard diffraction patterns, confirming the successful synthesis of pure BTNO and BiOBr. The BTNO/BiOBr composites show characteristic peaks of both components without any impurities, and the peak intensity changes with the amount of BiOBr, indicating phase composition variations.
Claim_set.Topic: XRD analysis of BTNO and BiOBr nanosheets and their composites

Claim_set.text:
## 2. Experimental

Synthesis of NiO@NiS catalyst : 0.2 g of NiO from Ni-MOF calcination, 1.25 mmol Ni(NO$_{3}$)$_{2}$·6H$_{2}$O, and 3.5 mmol thiourea were added to 60 mL of ultra-pure water in an autoclave. After sonication for 10 min, the sealed autoclave was heated at 200 o C for 18 h. Following the cooling down, washing with water and ethanol, filtration, and vacuum dry, the black NiO@NiS nanorod was provided subsequently. The composition flow diagram for NiO@NiS is shown in Figure 1a.

## 3.
Claim_set.Claim: NiO@NiS nanorod catalyst was synthesized by a hydrothermal method using NiO, nickel nitrate, and thiourea.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis of NiO@NiS Catalyst

Claim_set.text:
## 3. Results and Discussion

The morphology of NiO@NiS was depicted by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images. The calcined NiO spheroidal nanoparticles was loaded on NiS nanorods during the synthesis (Figure 1b&c, Figure S1). Additionally, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images revealed lattice fringes corresponding to the (200) crystal faces of NiO (0.2 nm) and the (131) crystal faces of NiS (0.185 nm), further affirming the successful synthesis of hybrid NiO@NiS structure (Figure 1d). Moreover, the uniform distribution of Ni, O, and S was confirmed by the elemental mapping images (Figure 1e).

Figure 1.
Claim_set.Claim: NiO@NiS hybrid structure was successfully synthesized, as evidenced by the presence of NiO spheroidal nanoparticles loaded on NiS nanorods, with HRTEM images showing lattice fringes corresponding to specific crystal faces of NiO and NiS.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis and Characterization of NiO@NiS Hybrid Structure

The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) for NiO and Ni-MOF was illustrated in Figure 2a. The peak at 432.4 cm⁻¹ signified the tensile vibration of Ni-O bond, while peaks between 1662.2-1340.9 cm⁻¹ in Ni-MOF represented asymmetric and symmetrical vibrations of the deprotic form of -COO. Furthermore, the XRD pattern of synthesized Ni-MOF is aligns with the standard sample (Figure 2b).
Claim_set.Claim: The synthesized NiO@NiS composite exhibits a distinct morphology and composition as evidenced by SEM, TEM, and EDS analyses.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis and Characterization of NiO@NiS Composite

Claim_set.text:
Moreover, as the active catalyst, the aforementioned metal will also promote the generation of conducted carbon such as carbon nanotube rather than the carbides, thus reducing the intrinsic activity for HER [17,18].

In contrast, the nonmetallic elements (e.g., N, S, and P) doping is emerging as another suitable option, which may strengthen the p -d hybridization, thereby downshifting the valence band of Mo$_{2}$C, and weakening the Mo-H strength [19]. Meanwhile, considering that the nitrogen atom owns a similar atomic radius with carbon atom, but higher electronegativity [20], N-doping is predicted as the most ideal element to vary the electronic configuration of Mo$_{2}$C.
Claim_set.Claim: Nonmetallic elements doping, particularly nitrogen, is emerging as a suitable option for enhancing the performance of Mo₂C catalysts by strengthening the p-d hybridization, downshifting the valence band, and weakening the Mo-H bond strength.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of Catalyst Performance Through Nonmetallic Doping

Claim_set.text: Additionally, the nitrogen doping can also specifically increase the density of atomic vacancy and disordered lattice of the Mo$_{2}$C to maximize the quantity of exposed active sites to the media, thereby facilitating the intrinsic activity in HER [21,22]. Nevertheless, the previously reported doping strategy is commonly relying on the gas-solid interfacial reaction by direct nitriding of transition metal-based materials using pure NH$_{3}$ or N-contained molecule as N source [23-25], which often leads to the aggregation of active sites and the uncontrolled dopants distribution due to the inhomogeneity of these interfacial reactions. Moreover, the open environment in gas-solid reactions also causes the serious N escape from the lattice.
Claim_set.Claim: Nitrogen doping increases the density of atomic vacancy and disordered lattice of Mo₂C to maximize the quantity of exposed active sites, thereby facilitating the intrinsic activity in HER.
Claim_set.Topic: Nitrogen Doping for Enhancing HER Activity in Mo₂C

Claim_set.text: Zhang et al. doped Mo atoms into NiCoP to increase the adsorption energy and electrical conductivity of the catalysts, which result in the promotion of the catalysts for urea and water electrolysis activities [47]. Dong et al. optimised the electronic structure and absorption/desorption energy of the surface and thus enhanced the catalytic performance by solution impregnation of F-doped TMPs to induce the formation of an active hydroxide layer [48]. However, despite the great efforts of the scientist, both performance and durability need to be further breakthroughs. Based on the above advantages expected, the solution impregnation method was used to rationally modulate the electronic structure of TMPs to enhance the catalytic performance and durability of TMPs.
Claim_set.Claim: Doping Mo atoms into NiCoP catalysts increases adsorption energy and electrical conductivity, enhancing urea and water electrolysis activities.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of catalytic performance and durability through doping and solution impregnation methods.

## 2.5. Calculations

The computational calculations were conducted on the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). The spin-polarized densityfunctional theory (DFT) was carried out within the projectoraugmented wave (PAW) framework. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) was applied to describe the exchange function of electron. Meanwhile, the dispersion interactions were considered by the Grimme's DFTD3 method.
Claim_set.Claim: "The potentials are transformed to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to specific equations in both alkaline and acid solutions."
Claim_set.Topic: "Transformation of Potentials to RHE in Different Solutions"

Claim_set.text: RHE for OER in 1 M KOH, respectively. The measured potentials for OER vs SCE were converted to the RHE with the Nernst equation: E$_{RHE }$ = E$_{SCE }$ + 0.242 + 0.0591 × pH, and the measured potentials for HER vs Ag/AgCl were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) with the Nernst equation: ERHE = E$_{SCE }$ + 0.197 + 0.0591 × pH.
Claim_set.Claim: The potentials for Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER) and Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) can be converted to the Reversible Hydrogen Electrode (RHE) scale using the Nernst equation.
Claim_set.Topic: Conversion of Electrode Potentials to RHE Scale

potential by the Nernst equation (E $_{(RHE) }$ = E $_{(Hg / HgO) }$ + 0.098 + 0.059 × pH) [49]. The non-faradaic potential range of 0.02 -0.12 V was selected to assess the double-layer capacitance (C$_{dl}$) in the scanning rate range of 20 -100 mV s GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$for cyclic voltammetry (CV), and on this basis, ECSA (ECSA = C$_{dl }$/ C$_{s}$, C$_{s }$ = 0.04 mF cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$) [50]was obtained.

Claim_set.text: Based on the above analysis, a catalyst consisting of heterostructured nanoarrays of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP was designed and prepared for efficient seawater splitting for hydrogen production in alkaline seawater. The complexes with nanoarrays are generated by hydrothermal method to produce precursors, and then the final target catalysts are prepared by calcination and phosphatization. This target catalyst synergistically acts to enhance the catalytic performance of OER and HER by introducing oxides and phosphides as a way to establish strong electronic interactions. This hybrid structure can combine nanosheets and nanowires, one-dimensional nanostructures expose more catalytically active sites, and two-dimensional nanostructures allow for rapid electron transfer[44 -47].
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP heterostructured nanoarrays enhance seawater splitting efficiency for hydrogen production.
Claim_set.Topic: Efficient seawater splitting for hydrogen production

Claim_set.text:
It also shows excellent stability in alkaline seawater, and it can be reasonably inferred that the catalyst has a certain ability to resist corrosion oxidation due to phosphating. Based on the above results, it can be concluded that Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP has excellent performance in overall seawater splitting, and can be used as a promising candidate for future industrial seawater electrolysis after further optimization of the process. The drawback is that in the long-term electrocatalytic process, the overall working current density is not high, and industrial applications cannot be achieved for the time being, and further optimization of the process is required.

Claim_set.text: Under the condition of 100 mA/cm$^{2}$, the working potential is only 1.70 V. In the hydrogen evolution reaction, the working potential is only 0.16 V under the condition of current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$, showing excellent bifunctional activity. In addition, the catalyst also showed excellent activity for urea oxidation reaction in alkaline environment, and the working potential was only 1.28 V at a current density of 10 mA/cm$^{2}$. At the same time, in the overall water splitting process, the two-electrode system composed of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP only needs 1.60 V to reach 10 mA/cm$^{2}$.
Claim_set.Claim: Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@CoP catalyst exhibits excellent bifunctional activity, with a working potential of only 1.70 V at 100 mA/cm$^{2}$ for oxygen evolution reaction and 0.16 V at 10 mA/cm$^{2}$ for hydrogen evolution reaction, also showing outstanding activity for urea oxidation at 1.28 V at 10 mA/cm$^{2}$, and achieving 10 mA/cm$^{2}$ in overall water splitting at 1.60 V.
Claim_set.Topic: Bifunctional electrocatalytic activity for water splitting and urea oxidation
