8 , 23 , 25 To validate the aforementioned analysis, SEM and energy dispersive spectroscopy

(EDS) mapping were further employed to characterize the distribution of nucleation on the Cu foil after plating at a current density of 1 mA cm - 2 for 100 s. In the case of the ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte, numerous irregular Zn nuclei were randomly dispersed on the Cu foil, potentially exacerbating dendrite growth during subsequent deposition processes ( Figure 3 i,j). Conversely, in Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolytes, nuclei exhibited a dense and uniform distribution, thereby promoting smooth Zn deposition ( Figure 3 k,l). Claim_set.text: These initial irregular platelets can act as charge centers within the electric field, resulting in continuous charge accumulation due to the tip effect. This disturbance hinders Zn 2+ flux and promotes dendrite growth, exacerbating surface side reactions that ultimately impact the operational lifespan of Zn anodes. Consequently, upon subsequent plating of Zn after 20 and 50 cycles, Figure S10b and Figure 4 a demonstrate the presence of undesired flake-like protrusions with irregular morphology. However, the Zn anode in the Gln/ZnSO$_{4}$ electrolyte exhibits a relatively smooth surface devoid of dendrites both during the initial cycle and after 20/50 cycles ( Figure S10c,d and Figure 4 b). This substantiates that Gln effectively facilitates the formation of a stable interface on the Zn anode surface.
Claim_set.Claim: Gln effectively facilitates the formation of a stable interface on the Zn anode surface, preventing dendrite growth and enhancing the operational lifespan of Zn anodes.
Claim_set.Topic: Dendrite growth prevention and stable interface formation on Zn anodes

Catalyst-mediated electron transfer is a unique non-radical activation pathway for PMS, which has been widely reported to effectively and rapidly degrade some electron-rich organic pollutants [16,71]. Electrochemical characterizations are considered an effective method to identify the catalyst-mediated electron transfer pathway [72]. The chronoamperometry (i-t) curve was utilized to identify the presence of the electron transfer pathway in the system (Fig. 6d). It is observed that upon the addition of PMS, there was a significant negative current in the system, indicating the formation of a complex between the catalyst and PMS. Subsequently, with the introduction of TC, a significant positive current was observed, which is a typical sign of electron transfer between TC and PMS mediated by the catalyst [73].
Claim_set.Claim: Catalyst-mediated electron transfer is a unique non-radical activation pathway for PMS, effectively and rapidly degrading electron-rich organic pollutants.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst-mediated electron transfer for pollutant degradation

Claim_set.text: Specifically, defects on the carbon network are active centers that mediate PMS activation to form complexes for nonradical oxidation. These defect sites can confine the delocalized π system in a " localized state " and exhibit completely different chemical and electronic properties, allowing strong interactions with pollutants [79]. This strong interaction enables PMS molecules to directly oxidize pollutants by extracting electrons from adsorbed pollutants. Therefore, defects in FSBC can serve as active sites for the activation pathway of electron transfer. In addition, the C = O/ O GLYPH<0> C = O content also shows a strong correlation with k$_{obs }$ (R$^{2 $_{=}$}$0.8427). C = O is also widely recognized for its significant role in PMS activation due to its electron-rich nature [80].
Claim_set.Claim: Defects on the carbon network serve as active sites for the activation pathway of electron transfer, enabling PMS molecules to directly oxidize pollutants.
Claim_set.Topic: PMS activation and nonradical oxidation by carbon network defects

The lower electron density of defect sites allowed them to adsorb electron-rich PMS and pollutants, thereby contributing the electron transfer between pollutants and PMS [79]. Based on the aforementioned analysis and discussion, a mechanism for the activation of PMS by FSBC-800 is proposed. FSBC-800 primarily activates PMS through two pathways: (i). PMS interacted with C = O on the surface of FSBC-800, causing its own cleavage to produce $^{1}$O$_{2}$. (ii).

Claim_set.text: Therefore, CZO -2 was selected as the optimal catalyst for subsequent trials. Subsequent research assessed the influence of US power and catalyst dosage on phenol removal and investigated the removal efficiency at different phenol concentrations, with detailed information provided in SI Appendix , Fig. S8. As widely recognized, solution pH was also a major factor affecting the degradation of pollutants. Within the initial pH range of 3 to 9, the degradation rate of phenol was approximately 98.0%, with little variation in the k$_{obs}$ value, initially increasing and then decreasing (Fig. 3 C ). These results indicated that the CZO -2 piezoelectric system effectively degrades phenol over a wide pH range. Besides, tap water, Yangtze River, Huangpu River, and Pearl River had no significant effect on phenol degradation (Fig. 3 D ).
Claim_set.Claim: CZO-2 piezoelectric system effectively degrades phenol over a wide pH range.
Claim_set.Topic: Phenol degradation in water by piezoelectric system

Claim_set.text: In order to study the effect of background material and poten­ tial application of CZO -2 material, the impact of typical anions (Cl$^{-}$, NO$_{3}$$^{-}$, HCO$_{3}$$^{-}$, and SO$_{4}$$^{2-}$) and dissolved organic matter (DOM) on phenol degradation was investigated separately. As depicted in Fig. 6 A , in the presence of Cl$^{-}$, NO$_{3}$$^{-}$, HCO$_{3}$$^{-}$, SO$_{4}$$^{2-}$, and DOM, the oxidation efficiencies of phenol were 88.6%, 97.5%, 97.0%, 91.5%, and 91.4%, respectively (in 180 min).
Claim_set.Claim: The presence of typical anions and dissolved organic matter (DOM) affects the degradation of phenol by CZO-2 material.
Claim_set.Topic: Effect of background material and potential application of CZO-2 in phenol degradation

Claim_set.text: Lastly, the n-hexane/water (Fig. 7(a)) and dichloromethane/water mixtures (Fig. 7(c)) were poured through the funnel. As the aerogel approaches its absorption limit, n-hexane and dichloromethane (red) progressively pour into the beaker, while water (blue) remains in the funnel. After leaving the separated funnel for 5 min, there was no observed seepage of water out of the aerogel.

Furthermore, the adsorption efficiency of Congo red and Methyl orange was 94 % owing to the electrostatic attraction between the anionic dye and PDMS@CZIF67/CS aerogel [46]; whereas, the adsorption effect of Rhodamine B and Methylene blue was relatively low, with removal rates of 44.9 % and 50.2 % respectively, due to the electrostatic repulsion between cationic dyes and PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel [3].

through the collection of solar energy by the PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel. The PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel ' s rapid photothermal conversion is primarily due to the inclusion of CZIF-67, a carbon-based material known for its high thermal conductivity via lattice atom vibrations. Additionally, nitrogen doping induces a Fermi energy level shift towards the conduction band within the carbon framework, enhancing both phonon transfer and thermal conductivity [39]. As a result, the aerogel ' s swift light absorption, coupled with efficient heat dissipation, causes a rapid increase in surface temperature.
Claim_set.Claim: The PDMS@CZIF-67/CS aerogel demonstrates rapid photothermal conversion and enhanced thermal conductivity due to the inclusion of CZIF-67 and nitrogen doping, leading to efficient solar energy collection and a swift increase in surface temperature.
Claim_set.Topic: Photothermal conversion and thermal conductivity enhancement in aerogels for solar energy collection

Claim_set.text: This work develops a low-temperature nitrogen doping method to build a modified graphene sheet layer with both conductivity and hydrophilicity. Ethylenediamine (EDA) is used as a surface modifier to modify the graphene oxide (GO) surface making it negatively charged (Fig. S1a) and form an ion-selective film. PEG is used as a surfactant to change the charge distribution on the surface of sulfur (Fig. S1b), resulting in a positive charge on the treated sulfur-containing solution. When the positively charged singlet sulfur nanoparticle cluster suspension is mixed with the negatively charged GO suspension, the phenomenon of GO covering singlet sulfur nanoparticle cluster is generated due to the electrostatic effect, forming S@EGO encapsulated structure composite. Fig. 1 shows the preparation process of S@EGO, which can be simply and efficiently prepared on a large scale.
Claim_set.Claim: Ethylenediamine (EDA) is used as a surface modifier to modify the graphene oxide (GO) surface, making it negatively charged, and polyethylene glycol (PEG) is used as a surfactant to change the charge distribution on the surface of sulfur, resulting in a positive charge on the treated sulfur-containing solution. This process leads to the formation of a S@EGO encapsulated structure composite through electrostatic effects.
Claim_set.Topic: Low-temperature nitrogen doping method to modify graphene sheets for conductivity and hydrophilicity

Claim_set.text:
## 2.2. Synthesis of S@EGO composite

Firstly, sulfur powder (120 mg) and PEG-4000 (0.638 g) were completely dissolved in 50 mL of ethanol solution at 80 · C. Secondly, GO (5 mL, 2 mg mL GLYPH<0> $^{1}$) was dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water, then a trace amount of EDA (140 μ L) was added, and the modification temperature was maintained at 85 · C for 6 h until the brown GO aqueous solution turned black (labeled as EGO).
Claim_set.Claim: Sulfur powder and PEG-4000 were dissolved in ethanol solution at 80°C, and GO was modified with EDA at 85°C for 6 hours, resulting in a color change from brown to black, producing EGO.
Claim_set.Topic: Synthesis of Sulfur-Graphene Oxide Composite Material

Claim_set.text: Specifically, SiO$_{2 }$is intercalated into and on the surface of the Ti$_{3}$C$_{2 }$ MXene layer by in situ growth and then hybridized with PTFE. The intercalation of SiO$_{2 }$facilitates the transition of the lamellae from sliding friction to rolling friction. In addition, the lubricity of PTFE can further reduce the friction between silica and MXene or reduce the friction between MXene sheets. Hybrids STP was added to the precursor polyamidoacetic acid by solution mixing method, and then thermal imidization to obtain STP/PI composites. The tribological performance of polyimide substrates with STP was mainly investigated.
Claim_set.Claim: The intercalation of SiO$_{2}$ into Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ MXene facilitates a transition from sliding to rolling friction, reducing friction between MXene sheets and enhancing lubricity with PTFE.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing lubricity in MXene composites

Claim_set.text: The wear rate of the composite material was reduced by 43.2 % compared to PI. The interlayer self-lubrication of MXene helps to reduce the coefficient of friction and wear rate, resulting in significantly longer service life and thus improved energy efficiency of the system. Moreover, the structural diversity and large compositional space of MXene provide unlimited research opportunities to optimize the friction and wear behavior of MXene [24]. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) has a low COF (0.20) and a low dielectric constant (2.0~2.1), making it a polymer lubricant with excellent lubricating properties [28,29]. However, PTFE has poor wear resistance and short lubrication aging when used alone [30].
Claim_set.Claim: The wear rate of the composite material was reduced by 43.2% compared to PI, due to the interlayer self-lubrication of MXene, which helps to reduce the coefficient of friction and wear rate, resulting in significantly longer service life and thus improved energy efficiency of the system.
Claim_set.Topic: Wear rate reduction and energy efficiency in composite materials

Claim_set.text:
## 2.3. Characterization methods

The phase compositions of the samples were studied using an X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, MiniFlex600), and the scanning parameters were set to a range of 10 · to 80 · at a rate of 0.1 · /s. The morphologies of samples were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S4800) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher, ESCALAB 250Xi) was employed to assess the chemical composition of the elements in the samples, using a monochromatic Al K α source.
Claim_set.Claim: The phase compositions of the samples were studied using an X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, MiniFlex600), and the morphologies of samples were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S4800) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher, ESCALAB 250Xi) was employed to assess the chemical composition of the elements in the samples.
Claim_set.Topic: Characterization methods

Claim_set.text:
## 2.2. Structure and morphology characterization

The morphologies of the samples were characterized by fieldemission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi SU8010) equipped with X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford XMax$^{N}$) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100F). The crystal structure of the products was measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical Empyrean) and Raman spectroscopy (Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution). The chemical composition and elemental environment of the samples were checked by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo K-Alpha). The exact content of metallic elements in the samples was characterized by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent 5800).
Claim_set.Claim: The morphologies and crystal structures of the samples were characterized using FESEM, TEM, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy.
Claim_set.Topic: Morphology and Structure Characterization

The typical peaks at 1200 -1600 cm - 1 were assigned to C -NorC ] N in unique conjugated heterocycles of the melon frameworks. 37 The sharp peaks at 810 cm - 1 correspond to the out-of-plane bending vibration characteristics of tris -triazine groups.

Claim_set.text:
The above information implied that the chemical frameworks of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ treated with formaldehyde were not destroyed, while the hydroxyl group content was signi  cantly increased. Speci  cally, in the formaldehyde solution, unsaturated carbon atoms in the triazine ring

combined with the aldehyde group to form stable C -O bonds via chemical bonding forces, while the introduction of -OH did not lead to a random stacking on the planar structure, but changed the layer spacing of the conjugate stacking using its stretching vibration mode.

The chemical composition and successful introduction of hydroxyl groups on the triazine ring through the formaldehyde reaction were further veri  ed by XPS measurement and TGA analysis.

Claim_set.text: The stability of the photocatalysts is also an important factor for photocatalytic performance. A  er  ve continuous cycles (total reaction time of 30 h), hydroxylated g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ exhibited excellent stability (3.219 mmol g - $^{1}$). The XRD and FT-IR results of the samples before and a  er use revealed that the anchored hydroxyl groups on the surface of g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ did not decompose under visible light irradiation and still maintained the intact frameworks (Fig. 3D and S6 † ). In addition, the hydroxyl groups within the g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ structure were not induced by the in  uence of adsorbed water.
Claim_set.Claim: Hydroxylated g-C3N4 exhibited excellent stability with a yield of 3.219 mmol g^-1 after five continuous cycles, maintaining its framework integrity as confirmed by XRD and FT-IR analyses.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalyst Stability

Claim_set.text: The Raman spectrum of XC72R ( Figure S3a ) displays two peaks of 1335 and 1589 cm - $^{1}$, corresponding to the D band and G band of carbon, respectively, which suggests that both sp$^{3}$-hybridized C and sp$^{2}$-hybridized C are contained in XC-72R. 33 After reaction with nitric acid, the peak of the G band on Raman spectra moved from 1589 to 1581 cm - 1 ( Figure S3b ). As reported, the groups' functionalization leads to the electronic structure tuning of the carbon substrate, resulting in a peak shift of about 2 - 12 cm - 1 in the G band.
Claim_set.Claim: The Raman spectrum of XC72R shows peaks at 1335 and 1589 cm^-1, indicating the presence of both sp^3- and sp^2-hybridized carbon. After treatment with nitric acid, the G band peak shifts from 1589 to 1581 cm^-1, suggesting electronic structure tuning due to functional group attachment.
Claim_set.Topic: Raman Spectroscopy Analysis of Carbon Hybridization and Functionalization Effects

33 - 38 The changes in the groups in the reactions were detected by Fourier transform infrared

spectroscopy (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). After being treated with nitric acid, the peaks appearing at 1646 and 1559 cm - 1 in the FT-IR spectrum of XC72R - NO$_{2}$/-NO ( Figure S4 ) can be assigned to the vibrations of C  O and N  O, respectively. 39 , 40 Furthermore, the peak related to - NO$_{2}$ (1359 cm - $^{1}$) becomes larger, suggesting that more - NO$_{2}$ generated after nitration.
Claim_set.Claim: The functionalization of XC72R carbon black with nitric acid leads to the introduction of nitro (-NO2) groups, as evidenced by the enhancement of the corresponding peak at 1359 cm^-1 in the FT-IR spectrum.
Claim_set.Topic: Surface functionalization of carbon materials with nitric acid

Claim_set.text:
A range of Aurivillius compounds have been reported to show intriguing photocatalytic performance in water splitting, organic pollutant degradation, carbon dioxide reduction, etc., such as Bi$_{4}$Ti$_{3}$O$_{12 }$ [3,4] and

As an Aurivillius compound, Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9 }$ (BTNO) has been recently explored as a novel photocatalyst due to the above-mentioned features of layered crystalline structure and IEF [7,8]. Researchers have attempted to modify the photocatalytic performance of BTNO through methods such as doping, defect engineering and facet engineering [9 -11]. For instance, Liu et al.
Claim_set.Claim: Bi$_{3}$TiNbO$_{9 }$ (BTNO) has been explored as a novel photocatalyst due to its layered crystalline structure and intrinsic electric field (IEF), with attempts to modify its photocatalytic performance through methods such as doping, defect engineering, and facet engineering.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic Performance Modification of Aurivillius Compounds

Claim_set.text: It can be seen that the full spectrum of the BTNO/3BiOBr composite is composed of five elements: Bi, Br, Nb, Ti and O (Fig. 3a). As for the high-resolution spectra of Bi, the peak at 164.3 eV in BTNO/3BiOBr belongs to Bi 4 f$_{5/2 }$while the peak at 159.0 eV belongs to Bi 4 f$_{7/2 }$ as shown in Fig. 3b. Compared with the double peaks at 164.9 eV and 159.6 eV in BiOBr, the XPS peaks of Bi4f in the composite photocatalysts move towards to a lower binding energy direction, and their locations are more close to that of pure BTNO [8].
Claim_set.Claim: The BTNO/3BiOBr composite photocatalyst is composed of five elements, with the Bi 4f peaks exhibiting a shift towards lower binding energy compared to BiOBr, aligning more closely with pure BTNO.
Claim_set.Topic: Composition and electronic structure of a photocatalyst

Claim_set.text: According to Fig. 6a, the light absorption edge of BTNO is about 400 nm while the absorption edge of BiOBr is located at about 442 nm. As for the BTNO/BiOBr composites, their absorption edge is sitting between the two pure phases. With the increasing content of BiOBr, the absorption edges of the composites showed a slight redshift. It is reasonable that the introduction of narrow-bandgap BiOBr enlarged the spectral response range of BTNO, which may be beneficial for the photocatalytic activity [36]. The bandgap values can be determined using the Kubelka-Munk equation: F ( R ) = (1R )$^{2}$/2 R , hererin R means the diffuse reflectance of samples [9].
Claim_set.Claim: The introduction of narrow-bandgap BiOBr enlarged the spectral response range of BTNO, which may be beneficial for the photocatalytic activity.
Claim_set.Topic: Spectral Response Range Enlargement

Claim_set.text:
As a result, it is reasonable to infer that the sizes of CDs can affect their enhancing effect on chloride binding abilities of cement composites. However, the size-induced influence of CDs on enhancement of chloride binding is still a research gap. To prepare more suitable sizes of CDs for further enhancing the chloride binding, it is highly urgent to investigate their size-induced influence on chloride binding capacity of cement adopting CDs with different sizes.

Benefiting from their less dosage, large specific surface area and high reactivity, nanomaterials have become a research hotspot. Until now, nano Al$_{2}$O$_{3}$, layered double hydroxides, and carbon nanotubes have been substantiated to effectively enhance chloride binding capacity of cement composites [15 -17].

Claim_set.text:
## 2.3. Mixture proportions and preparation method

To detect the modification effect of CDs sizes on chloride binding behavior, four kinds of paste specimens without/with diverse CDs sizes were prepared and named as C, 0.5 H, 1.0 H, and 2.0 H. To obtain an obvious improvement of chloride binding content in cement, the CDs dosage was confirmed as 0.2 wt% (by the weight of cement) based on the previous research [30]. All specimens share a common water-to-cement ratio of 0.5. The detailed mixture proportions of all groups were shown in Table 3. During the preparation of pastes specimens, the CDs with different sizes were dissolved in DI water irrespectively. Then the mixing solution was added into cement. Subsequently, the obtained mixture was stirred using a mixer.
Claim_set.Claim: CDs of different sizes modify chloride binding behavior in cement paste.
Claim_set.Topic: Modification of chloride binding behavior in cement paste

Claim_set.text:
Thus, the smaller the sizes of CDs, the more effective the enhancement of chloride binding.

(1) Three classes of CDs with average sizes of 12.37, 5.79, and 1.73 nm are controllably synthesized by changing the calcination of 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 h, respectively. The sizes of CDs progressively decrease, as the calcination time increases. These as-prepared CDs represent distinct different sizes, while share identical surface functional groups, similar chemical compositions, and crystallinity.

(3) The effect mechanism of CDs sizes on chloride binding behavior of cement is reasonably proposed through the comprehensive phases analyses. CDs with smaller sizes can more effectively accelerate the generation of C -S -H gels and Ms by nucleation effect, thereby significantly promoting the physical adsorption and chemical binding of cement pastes.
Claim_set.Claim: The smaller the sizes of CDs, the more effective the enhancement of chloride binding.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of chloride binding in cement by CDs

Claim_set.text:
On one hand, the presence of M-NPs increases the number and variety of active sites and affects electrocatalytic activity. On the other hand, the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles may seriously block the pore structure of the material, decreasing the speci  c surface area (SSA) and affecting the exposure and catalytic activity of the active sites in M-N-C. The two vastly different viewpoints above demonstrate the uncertainty of the impact of M-NPs on the activity of M-N-C materials.

Several studies have been conducted to demonstrate the role of M-NPs in materials. Some studies have shown that the removal of metal nanoparticles from M-N-C materials by additional acid etching steps is bene  cial to enhance the catalytic performance of M-N-C via increasing the SSA, and these studies maintain a negative attitude towards the presence of M-NPs.
Claim_set.Claim: The presence of M-NPs increases the number and variety of active sites but may also block the pore structure of the material, affecting its specific surface area and catalytic activity.
Claim_set.Topic: Impact of Metal Nanoparticles on Catalytic Activity of Materials

Claim_set.text:
This balance have the following three advantages: (1) the presence of M-NPs will not seriously block the pores of materials and seriously

reduce the SSA of catalysts; (2) the density of active sites containing M-NPs can be increased as much as possible to fully utilize the inherent activity of M-NPs; (3) no unnecessary etching steps are required, and the experimental operation is simple. However, the regulation of this  ne equilibrium state is tough.

Herein, hollow porous N-doped carbon-encapsulated FeCo alloy nanoparticles (Fe$_{x}$Co$_{y}$@N-C-0.3) were fabricated via epitaxial growth and pyrolysis strategies.
Claim_set.Claim: The presence of M-NPs does not significantly block the pores of materials, nor does it drastically reduce the specific surface area (SSA) of catalysts.
Claim_set.Topic: The balance of metal nanoparticles in porous materials for catalysis.

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Effectively designing the coordination environment of metal atoms in single-atom catalysts to enhance the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance is challenging. Herein, a strategy for regulating the electronic structure of double-site Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$ by axial traction of Mn cluster is presented. The atomically dispersed homonuclear double-site Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$was synthesized. Experimental investigations and theoretical calculations revealed that the oxygen adsorption capacity of double-site Mn$_{2}$-N$_{6 }$was stronger than that of Mn-N$_{4}$, which can improve the weak adsorption of oxygen at isolated Mn active sites.
Claim_set.Claim: The oxygen adsorption capacity of double-site Mn₂-N₆ is stronger than that of Mn-N₄, improving the weak adsorption of oxygen at isolated Mn active sites.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance in single-atom catalysts

Claim_set.text:
To summarize, it can be concluded that the oxygen adsorption capacity of Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C was considerably greater than that of Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C due to the unique bridging adsorption mode. After Mn clusters were introduced, due to the disruption of the planar structure of Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C, the electron configuration around the active sites was further altered, and the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates decreased during the ORR process and accelerated the ORR, thus showing excellent ORR performance.

3.2.
Claim_set.Claim: The oxygen adsorption capacity of Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C was considerably greater than that of Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C due to the unique bridging adsorption mode.
Claim_set.Topic: Oxygen adsorption capacity in Mn-doped carbon materials

Claim_set.text: 1f and Table S2. Adsorbing O$_{2 }$molecules and coupling a proton in the first step of the ORR in Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C and Mn$_{cluster}$/ Mn$_{SAC}$-N-C were endothermic processes, suggesting that these reactions cannot occur spontaneously at the catalyst surface, which is detrimental to the overall ORR occurrence. In contrast, for Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C and Mn$_{cluster}$/ Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C, the first step was exothermic because the double-site bridging adsorption facilitated oxygen adsorption. Additionally, the rate-determining step (RDS) of Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C was the second step (OOH* to O*).
Claim_set.Claim: Double-site bridging adsorption facilitates oxygen adsorption in Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C and Mn$_{cluster}$/Mn$_{DAC}$-N-C, making the first step of the ORR exothermic.
Claim_set.Topic: Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) Mechanism in Manganese-Based Catalysts

## 3.2. Photoelectric property studies

To systematically investigate the photophysical and electrochemical properties of TD-TPTA, UV/Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV/Vis DRS), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and transient photocurrent measurements were performed. TD-TPTA has strong light absorption from 300 to 800 nm, while DBA-TPTA only shows significant light absorption from 200 to 350 nm, which indicates that TD-TPTA has

Separation and Purification Technology 345 (2024) 127408 Wu et al.

much better visible light capturing ability than DBA-TPTA (Fig. 3a).
Claim_set.Claim: TD-TPTA exhibits strong light absorption from 300 to 800 nm, demonstrating superior visible light capturing ability compared to DBA-TPTA.
Claim_set.Topic: Photoelectric property studies

Claim_set.text: much better visible light capturing ability than DBA-TPTA (Fig. 3a). Optical bandgap energies derived from the Kubelka-Munk transformed spectra were found to be 1.70 and 2.56 eV for TD-TPTA and DBA-TPTA, respectively (Fig. 3b). The narrow bandgap energies indicates that these CTFs photocatalysts have good photocatalytic activity when driven by visible light. By means of PL spectroscopy, we have characterized the behavior of the photogenerated charge recombination of TD-TPTA and DBA-TPTA. In Fig. 3c, TD-TPTA exhibits a significantly lower emission intensity than DBA-TPTA, indicating its effective suppression of photogenerated charge recombination [32].
Claim_set.Claim: TD-TPTA exhibits significantly lower emission intensity than DBA-TPTA, indicating effective suppression of photogenerated charge recombination.

Electrons are injected into the triazine structure during this process. Notably, the HOMO-LUMO energy level band gap of TD-TPTA is narrower than that of DBA-TPTA. Consequently, the band gap of CTFs can be significantly reduced compared to the model.

## 3.3. Gold capture studies

As a proof-of-concept, a series of photocatalytic experiments were conducted to assess the feasibility of utilizing CTFs for extracting gold from e-waste.

The Mo element is homogeneous distribution through the whole product and the Fe and O elements are mainly in the inner core, confirming the core consists of Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$. The construction of a multiphase integrated heterogeneous structure is regarded as an effective approach for enhancing reaction reversibility, accelerating charge/ion transfer under the influence of the internal electric field, and improving the cycling stability by the unique confinement structure, leading to high-efficiency charge storage.

Claim_set.text: Furthermore, the formation energy of a single oxygen defect over CZO was studied by DFT calculations, as shown in Fig. 5 E . Results indicated that oxygen vacancy on surface of CZO ( E$_{OV}$ = 3.49 eV) was obviously lower than that of ZO ( E$_{OV}$ = 3.94 eV), suggesting that the oxygen vacancies more easily formed on the surface of CZO due to cobalt deposition. Additionally, by introducing additional electrons into the CZO -OV model to bolster the reducing atmosphere, a noteworthy reduction in defect formation energy was observed, decreasing from 3.49 eV to 2.25 eV. This compelling finding unequivocally established the intricate connection between defect formation and electron density.
Claim_set.Claim: Oxygen vacancy formation energy on the surface of cobalt-doped zinc oxide (CZO) is lower than that of undoped zinc oxide (ZO), indicating easier formation of oxygen vacancies on CZO due to cobalt deposition.
Claim_set.Topic: Defect formation energy in cobalt-doped zinc oxide (CZO)

Claim_set.text: Significant findings: The results of the study showed that the STP significantly enhanced the lubrication properties of the composites, the lowest coefficient of friction (0.29) of the composites is 22.81 % lower than that of the polyimide. In addition, the inclusion of hybrids helps to form a transfer film, which effectively improves the abrasion performance of polyimide, and the lowest wear rate (0.18 × 10 GLYPH<0> $^{5 }$mm$^{3}$/(N · m)) was 93.35 % lower than that of polyimide.
Claim_set.Claim: The STP significantly enhanced the lubrication properties of the composites, leading to a lower coefficient of friction and improved abrasion performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Lubrication and abrasion performance of composites

Claim_set.text: The STP/PI composites showed significantly improved tribological properties compared to PI. Specifically, STP4/PI had the best friction performance among all the samples, with an average COF and an average wear rate of 0.29 and 0.18 × 10 GLYPH<0> 5 mm$^{3}$/(N · m), respectively, which were 22.81 % and 93.35 % lower than that of the PI. The excellent friction performance of the STP/PI composites are attributed to the efficient lubrication of the PTFE and Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$@SiO$_{2 }$ intercalation structure.
Claim_set.Claim: STP4/PI composite exhibits superior tribological properties with a COF of 0.29 and wear rate of 0.18 × 10^-5 mm^3/(N · m), outperforming PI by 22.81% and 93.35%, respectively.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced tribological properties of STP/PI composites

Claim_set.text: Methods: Herein, a ternary solid lubricant SiO$_{2}$/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/PTFE (STP) is innovatively prepared by solution dispersion for reducing the friction of polyimide to increase the lubricity. Specifically, SiO$_{2 }$ and PTFE are intercalated accordion-like Ti$_{3}$C$_{2 }$nanosheets, thereby causing the nanosheets to slide relative to each other under external frictional stress. Then, STP was introduced into polyimide to prepare the ultra-wear-resistant and self-lubricating composites by blending.
Claim_set.Claim: SiO$_{2}$/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/PTFE (STP) ternary solid lubricant reduces friction in polyimide, enhancing lubricity and wear resistance.
Claim_set.Topic: Polyimide lubrication and wear resistance

Claim_set.text: The advanced 3D network structure of Fe-PAN was shown in Fig. 1b, which played a key role in decreasing external diffusion resistance of pollutant$^{20}$. The surface and internal structures of the Fe-PAN and C-FePAN were shown in the figures. In Fig. 1d, e, the formation of porous structures can be seen on the surface and in the interior of the Fe-PAN fibers. These unique porous structures effective reduced the internal diffusion resistance during reactions and allowed the reactants to easily penetrate thefibers. Figure 1f suggested that the NZVI particles were successfully incorporated inside the fibers. As a result, the reaction efficiency between the reactants and NZVI was strongly improved by simultaneous strengthening of both internal and external diffusion of the reactants.

Claim_set.Topic: Advanced 3D network structure for enhanced reaction efficiency

Claim_set.text:
(3) -(6) as well as favorable mass transfer property.

The degradation was greatly controlled by the radicals; the diffusion resistance was minimized by the hierarchical nano-mesoporous structure and the advanced network structure of the Fe-PAN film. From the TEM results, the entrapped NZVI dispersed evenly inside the Fe-PAN and provided sufficient active sites. The confining effect provided a high contact efficiency between the reactants and the NZVI. At the same time, the frost crack of the NZVI surface oxide layer that was caused by the cryogenic process ledtoa higher electron transfer efficiency between the NZVI and the reactants.

At low contaminant concentrations, the scavenging reactions occurred according to Eqs. (7) -(9), which led to lower radical utilization. When the initial concentration was increased, the utilization of radicals increased and a high degradation efficiency was maintained.
Claim_set.Claim: The hierarchical nano-mesoporous structure and advanced network structure of the Fe-PAN film minimized diffusion resistance, leading to controlled degradation by radicals.
Claim_set.Topic: Diffusion resistance minimization in degradation by radicals

Claim_set.text:
As a result, the stability and mechanical strength were significantly improved.

The hierarchical porosity of Fe-PAN was determined by the study on the N$_{2}$ adsorption-desorption isotherm with the result given in Fig. 2a. A

typical type II standard isotherm is observed, indicating the existence of macropores in the developed three-dimensional network structure$^{33,34}$. Macropores promoted the transfer of reactants from the bulk solution to the catalysts and the release of byproducts on the surface$^{35,36}$. The catalytic efficiency was therefore improved and surface coke formation was avoided.
Claim_set.Claim: The hierarchical porosity of Fe-PAN, as determined by the study on the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, significantly improved stability, mechanical strength, and catalytic efficiency by facilitating reactant transfer and byproduct release.
Claim_set.Topic: Hierarchical Porosity and Its Impact on Catalytic Performance

Claim_set.text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a crucial type of crystalline porous material constructed by coordinating organic molecules and metal ions, have emerged as promising templates/precursors for creating various porous functional materials, including metals, metal carbides/oxides/phosphides, metals/metal oxide nanoparticles (NPs), and carbon-supported metal nanoparticles catalysts. [17-22] Among these, Co-based catalysts derived from a Co-based zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-67) through pyrolysis have recently shown promise for catalyzing hydrogen evolution from AB hydrolysis because of their controllable micro/nanomorphologies and porous architectures. [23-25] However, the performance of Cobased catalysts obtained via pyrolysis can be compromised by irreversible NPs fusion, aggregation, and structural collapse.
Claim_set.Claim: Co-based catalysts derived from ZIF-67 show promise for catalyzing hydrogen evolution from AB hydrolysis due to their controllable micro/nanomorphologies and porous architectures.
Claim_set.Topic: Metal-organic frameworks for catalysis

Claim_set.text:
[26] Therefore, the construction of high-activity and excellent stability of Co-based catalysts derived from ZIF-67 through a simple and efficient strategy remains highly desirable, yet challenging.

In recent years, one of the most effective methods for enhancing the catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts has been the fabrication of bimetallic Co-based alloy catalysts by introducing other cost-effective and earth-abundant transition metals, such as Cu, Ni, and Fe $^{[27-31]}$. Among these, Co-Cu alloy catalysts have been considered ideal candidates for accelerating hydrogen evolution from AB hydrolysis, owing to the synergistic effects of their Co-Cu bimetallic components.
Claim_set.Claim: Co-Cu alloy catalysts are considered ideal candidates for accelerating hydrogen evolution from AB hydrolysis due to the synergistic effects of their Co-Cu bimetallic components.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing catalytic performance of Co-based catalysts

Claim_set.text:
These results further confirm that Co-Cu NPs can significantly

lower the energy barrier for AB hydrolysis, thereby facilitating hydrogen evolution from AB hydrolysis.

The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed to investigate the crystal structures of the samples. The XRD patterns of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$-ZIF demonstrated characteristic peaks similar to that of ZIF-67 ( Figure S5 ), suggesting minimal

changes in the crystal structure of ZIF-67 after Cu addition.
Claim_set.Claim: Co-Cu NPs significantly lower the energy barrier for AB hydrolysis, facilitating hydrogen evolution.
Claim_set.Topic: AB hydrolysis and hydrogen evolution

Claim_set.text: The peaks of MnO$_{2}$, Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$ and Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$were all observed on MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC, demonstrating the coexistence of Mn and Co oxides on the ACC surface. The functional groups of the ACC were investigated through fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) analysis. As shown in Fig. S4a, it is evident that nitrogencontaining functional groups were successfully incorporated on the surface of the ACC compared with CC. Notably, the strong capture capacity of benzene on the ACC surface can be attributed to the increased surface roughness (Fig. S4b-e).
Claim_set.Claim: MnO$_{2}$, Mn$_{5}$O$_{8}$, and Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ coexist on MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC, with nitrogen-containing functional groups successfully incorporated on the ACC surface, enhancing benzene capture capacity through increased surface roughness.
Claim_set.Topic: Coexistence and functionalization of metal oxides on activated carbon cloth for benzene capture.

Claim_set.text:
After the induction of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$, the UV -vis DRS of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC presented an ultrahigh light absorption across the whole solar spectrum, especially in the infrared region (Fig. S6b). Evidently, the enhanced infrared light absorption of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC was attributed to the incorporation of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$, which benefited the photocatalytic reaction.

## 3.2. Band structure

The energy band structures of MnO$_{2 }$and Mn$_{5}$O$_{8 }$were analyzed by valence band X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (VB-XPS) and MottSchottky plots.
Claim_set.Claim: MnOx/Co3O4@ACC exhibits ultrahigh light absorption across the solar spectrum, particularly in the infrared region, due to the incorporation of Co3O4, which enhances photocatalytic performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced Infrared Light Absorption for Photocatalysis

Claim_set.text: As shown in Fig. S28, the typical peak of DMOP-· OH were not detected in the single MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.1, whereas the peak of DMOP-· O$_{2}$ -was observed, suggesting that MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.1 possessed a higher reduction potential under visible light excitation. However, the characteristic peak of DMOP-· OH was observed but the peak of DMOP-· O$_{2}$ -was not detected in the single MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.7, indicating that MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.7 had strong oxidizing performance instead of reducing ability.
Claim_set.Claim: MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.1 possesses a higher reduction potential under visible light excitation, while MnO$_{x}$@ACC-1.7 exhibits strong oxidizing performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Photocatalytic performance under visible light.

(3) These reagents are cost-effective, offering practical applicability.

Analysis of the lithium content in various fully saturated lithiation reagents (Table S1 online) shows a significant correlation between the maximum storage capacity and the molecular structure of PAHs. Fig. 1b indicates that each independent aromatic benzene ring can store one lithium, resembling the lithium storage mechanism in graphite. Besides, employing the (4 n + 2) rule to calculate the minimum n value corresponding to the number of p electrons in the PAHs molecules correlates with the count of stored lithium. Notably, the anthracene reagent deviates from this trend. This is likely attributed to the most stable configuration when the lithium atom is positioned above the central benzene ring in the anthracene molecule.
Claim_set.Claim: Each independent aromatic benzene ring in PAHs can store one lithium, resembling the lithium storage mechanism in graphite.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithium storage capacity in PAHs

Claim_set.text:
Thus, Pyr is the best choice to balance the redox potential and solubility of PAHs.

The neutral PAHs molecule with p -p * conjugated interactions facilitate the transfer of the Li's delocalized electrons (Li 2s) to their p orbitals, forming stable PAHs radical anions coordinated with Li + cations due to solvent stabilization. This unique structure characterizes, PAHs-Li as the ''solvated electron solution" (Li-SES), where lithium acts as a charge-compensating cation [31]. The planar p -p * conjugated system of PAHs provides varied electronic affinities and redox capabilities. Cyclic voltammograms (Fig.
Claim_set.Claim: PAHs molecule with p -p * conjugated interactions facilitate the transfer of the Li's delocalized electrons to their p orbitals, forming stable PAHs radical anions coordinated with Li + cations due to solvent stabilization.
Claim_set.Topic: Redox Potential and Solubility Balance in PAHs-Li Systems

Besides, the crystal phases of the manganese oxide can be controlled with the different deposition potentials (Fig. S3). Similarly, Co$_{3}$O$_{4 }$in Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC was assigned to the cubic structure (JCPDS 900 -5891).

The FT-IR spectra of MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC also confirmed the co-existence of manganese oxide and cobaltous oxide on the ACC surface (Fig. S5) owing to the presence of Mn -O [25] and Co -O [26] stretching modes. The UV -vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV -vis DRS) was used to study the optical absorption properties of the samples. As shown in Fig. S6a, the light-absorbing ability of black MnO$_{x }$ was significantly expanded from UV to visible light and even to the infrared region after calcination treatment. Therefore, all the synthesized materials in the present work exhibited good light absorption.

Claim_set.text: After the introduction of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$, despite a slight decrease in the proportion of Mn$^{II }$due to the oxidation of photogenerated holes, the fitting peak areas of Mn$^{III }$and Mn$^{IV }$remained stable for the used MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC in the present system (Fig. 2g and Table S4). The fitting peaks position of Co 2p in the used MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC shifted towards higher binding energy compared to that of the fresh MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC, implying a reduction in electron density after cycles.
Claim_set.Claim: The proportion of Mn$^{II}$ decreases slightly due to oxidation by photogenerated holes, while the fitting peak areas of Mn$^{III}$ and Mn$^{IV}$ remain stable in the used MnO$_{x}$/Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$@ACC.
Claim_set.Topic: Stability of Manganese Oxidation States in a Photocatalytic System

Claim_set.text: In contrast, the intensity of this peak was significantly decreased in exfoliated graphene ( Figure S16 ), which suggests that our exfoliation method is highly efficient. Meanwhile, the (002) peak position of graphene remained unchanged after exfoliation, indicating the maintained interlayer spacing and structural integrity of exfoliated graphene. 19 Raman spectroscopy is a powerful tool for characterizing the quality of graphene. 74 The Raman spectrum of pristine graphite ( Figure 4 b,i) gives three typical bands: the defect-induced D band at 1337 cm - $^{1}$, G band at 1580 cm - $^{1}$, and 2D band at 2700 cm - $^{1}$. Among them, the D/G band intensity ratio ( I$_{D}$ / I$_{G}$ ) is an important measure of the defect level in carbon materials.
Claim_set.Claim: The exfoliation method used is highly efficient, as evidenced by the significant decrease in the intensity of the (002) peak in exfoliated graphene, indicating efficient exfoliation. The maintained position of the (002) peak after exfoliation suggests the structural integrity and maintained interlayer spacing of the exfoliated graphene. Raman spectroscopy confirms the quality of the graphene, showing typical bands with an important measure of the defect level in carbon materials being the D/G band intensity ratio.
Claim_set.Topic: Efficiency and structural integrity of graphene exfoliation

Claim_set.text:
In addition, the 291.1 eV peak related to the π - π * transition of the aromatic C - C was still clearly visible in the exfoliated graphene, which is characteristic in high-concentration sp 2 carbon material. 76 Figure 4 h compares the carbon content and I$_{D}$ / I$_{G}$ ratio of graphene prepared by our method and other state-of-the-art methods. It is visually observed that the quality of our exfoliated graphene is much higher than that of GO and RGO and resembles that of EEG, LEG, and CVD graphene, demonstrating the competitive advantage of our approach in the preparation of high-quality graphene. The detailed comparison is available in the Supporting Information ( Table S2 ).

This solution-based method offers the advantage of easy scalability for production.
Claim_set.Claim: The exfoliated graphene produced by our method exhibits a high-concentration of sp^2 carbon material, as evidenced by the clear visibility of the 291.1 eV peak related to the π - π * transition of the aromatic C - C bond, and its quality is much higher than that of GO and RGO, resembling that of EEG, LEG, and CVD graphene.
Claim_set.Topic: High-Quality Graphene Production Method

Raman mappings of D and G bands ( Figure 4 c,d) of an isolated graphene sheet further show the low defect nature of our exfoliated graphene.
Claim_set.Claim: The exfoliated graphene exhibits a low defect nature, as evidenced by its I$_{D}$ / I$_{G}$ ratio of ∼ 0.14, which is comparable to that of pristine graphite.Entity: Exfoliated grapheneTopic: Raman spectroscopy analysis of graphene's defect density

The disappearance of the C = O stretching signal at ca. 1659 cm GLYPH<0> 1 corresponds to the aldehyde group in the monomer. Furthermore, the appearance of characteristic bands at ca. 1507 cm GLYPH<0> 1 and ca. 1402 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$provides evidence of the formation of the triazine group in the CTFs skeleton [23] (Fig. 2a and S1-S2).

Claim_set.Topic: Material Characterization and Formation of Triazines within the Framework

This phenomenon indicates that stronger covalent bonds are formed between Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$ and g-C$_{3}$N$_{4}$ by the formation of Ti - C or Ti - N bonds. This is also the reason the heterojunction structures were quite stable, and it explains to some extent the disappearance of the end-group Ti-X peaks in the ternary composite in Figure 6 c as well.

Claim_set.text:
## 2. Experimental

## 2.1. Synthesis of lithiated FP precursors

Commercial iron phosphate (FP) was added to PAHs-Li reagent to initiate lithiation via spontaneous redox reactions at room temperature. Specifically, pyrene (Pyr, 14 mmol) and lithium metal (battery grade, 14 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of 2methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MeTHF) solvent with equimolar mass. After vigorous stirring for 4 h to complete the reaction, the PyrLi/2-MeTHF lithiation reagent with a concentration of 0.7 mol L - 1 was prepared.
Claim_set.Claim: Commercial iron phosphate (FP) can be lithiated by adding it to a reagent composed of pyrene (Pyr) and lithium metal dissolved in 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MeTHF) solvent, leading to a lithiation reagent with a concentration of 0.7 mol L^-1.
Claim_set.Topic: Lithiation of iron phosphate (FP)

Claim_set.text:
The lithiation reagent can be directly employed to react with FP at room temperature, resulting in the reduction of the majority of FP (Figs. S6-S9 online). The initial molar ratio of Li to Fe in the lithiated FP was determined to be around 1.04:1 (Table S3 online).

W. Liu et al.

Fig. 2. Lithium extraction from lithiated graphite. Effects of the extracted active lithium content from various factors. (a) Different highly soluble PAHs, (b) various combinations of PAHs and solvents, (c) Pyr/2-MeTHF concentration, and (d) diverse lithium leaching processes. (e) X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, and (f) photographs of lithiated graphite after lithium extraction at different times.
Claim_set.Claim: Lithiation reagent directly reacts with FP at room temperature, reducing most of it, with an initial molar ratio of Li to Fe around 1.04:1.
Claim_set.Topic: Reduction of FP by lithiation reagent at room temperature

Claim_set.text:
Then, 2 g of sand milled commercial FP (the molar ratio of n$_{Fe}$ : n$_{Li}$ = 1:1.05) was introduced into the lithiation reagent solution. After reaction for 2 h under stirring conditions, the mixture underwent filtration to effectively separate the lithiated FP from the solution. The lithium utilization rate was determined to be approximately 98.6% by testing the lithium content in the separation solution. The lithiated FP was washed with 2-MeTHF solvent and a small quantity of anhydrous ethanol. Then, the material underwent vacuum drying at 80 ° C for 10 h to obtain precursors.

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

As the kinetic processes of oxygen reduction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in metal-air batteries are slow, developing bifunctional catalysts with high performances is an essential requirement for boosting metal-air battery application. FeCo alloy is considered an excellent bifunctional active material, its weak corrosion resistance precludes its practical use in bifunctional catalysts. In this work, through dipping and annealing operations, FeCo alloy nanoparticles are doped on the porous carbon spheres (FeCo/PCNs). Strong FeCo nanoparticle-nitrogen-doped porous carbon sphere interaction results in a noticeable improvement in electrocatalytic activity and stability.
Claim_set.Claim: FeCo alloy nanoparticles doped on porous carbon spheres exhibit improved electrocatalytic activity and stability for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions.
Claim_set.Entity: FeCo/PCNs (FeCo alloy nanoparticles on porous carbon spheres)
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing bifunctional catalyst performance for metal-air batteries.

Claim_set.text:
For example, by encasing FeNi alloy in nitrogenated porous carbon, Wang et al. [14] prepared a highly efficient bifunctional catalyst that exhibited an E$_{1/2 }$of 0.86 V and an overpotential of 355 mV at 10 mA cm GLYPH<0> $^{2}$. Due to the polarity difference between the two metals in the alloy, the electron cloud in the alloy

is redistributed, the reaction energy barrier is reduced, and the catalytic activity is increased [20,21]. Despite this, alloy nanoparticles are very easy to be corroded in alkaline electrolyte, which seriously hinders their practical application [22,23].
Claim_set.Claim: Encasing FeNi alloy in nitrogenated porous carbon enhances its catalytic activity by redistributing the electron cloud, reducing the reaction energy barrier.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of catalytic activity through material encasement

The addition of PbI$_{2}$ clearly leads to a chemical shift for the protons in PTZ-Ph, while no shift is observed in $^{1}$H NMR spectra of Cz-Et, verifying the presence

of interactions between sulfur atom in PTZ-Ph and Pb$^{2+}$ (Figure 3c-d and Figure S20). Such interactions decrease electron cloud of sulfur atom, resulting in a shift of π electrons of the adjacent phenyl group, thus leading to a downfield shift for protons at a , b and c sites. Claim_set.text:
Science Bulletin xxx (xxxx) xxx

and productivity of lithium recovery [17,18]. Therefore, it is imperative to develop novel, eco-friendly, low-energy-consumption, and economically efficient recycling methodologies.

Recently, the concept of directly extracting lithium from lithiated graphite has attracted considerable interest [19,20]. This approach not only bypasses the separation of various transition metals but also simplifies the recovery process of high-purity lithium. In particular, Guo's group [21] reported employing polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) as carriers of Li$^{+}$, for secure and efficient retrieval of active lithium from lithiated graphite, yielding readily usable lithiation reagents.
Claim_set.Claim: Direct extraction of lithium from lithiated graphite using polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) as carriers simplifies the recovery process and yields high-purity lithium.
Claim_set.Topic: Direct extraction of lithium from lithiated graphite

Claim_set.text:
The extensive applicability of the lithiation reagents, including pre-lithiation and regeneration of electrode materials, has been confirmed in previous studies [22,23] and our recent researches [24,25]. Retrieving lithium resources from the anode represents an innovative and promising approach. Thus, establishing lithium recovery systems at ambient temperature, coupled with a comprehensive understanding of the leaching mechanism and its procedural effects, is essential for facilitating effective lithium recycling. Furthermore, the implementation of the direct recycling technique primarily focuses on refurbishing and regenerating spent electrode materials [26,27]. Achieving more efficient and valuable sustainable utilization of the retrieved lithium resources remains a substantial challenge, pointing toward a promising and eagerly anticipated direction.

Herein, we introduce a facile single-step chemical methodology utilizing PAHs for the direct recycling of active lithium from retired LIBs under ambient temperature conditions.
Claim_set.Claim: Direct recycling of active lithium from retired LIBs is facilitated by a single-step chemical methodology utilizing PAHs under ambient temperature conditions.
Claim_set.Topic: Direct Recycling of Lithium from LIBs

Claim_set.text:
Subsequently, active lithium extraction is achieved through a one-step chemical leaching process, facilitated by a PAHs solution at ambient temperature. The lithiated graphite is immersed in the lithium extraction solution, a mixture of PAHs and ether solvents, while ultrasound helps to accelerate the kinetics of lithium extraction. Once the reaction concludes, the active lithium-rich solution and graphite residue undergo separation, and the lithium within the residue is completely extracted through subsequent waterleaching processes. In a departure from prior methods, we directly use the obtained lithium-rich solution to produce new LFP cathode materials, achieving a cyclical use of lithium resources.

Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst stability in AB hydrolysis technology

Claim_set.text:
Moreover, the slope of ln k plotted

against ln [Catalyst] plot was determined to be 1.07 ( Figure S25 ), implying that AB hydrolysis followed first-order kinetics in terms of catalyst concentration.

The recyclability of Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ was assessed by repeating these experiments. AB hydrolysis was consistently achieved using Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ over 30 cycles at 298 K ( Figures 5c and S26 ).
Claim_set.Claim: AB hydrolysis followed first-order kinetics in terms of catalyst concentration, and Co$_{0.8}$Cu$_{0.2}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$ demonstrated recyclability over 30 cycles.

Claim_set.text:

∼ 87.2 eV correspond to 4f$_{7/2}$ and 4f$_{5/2}$, respectively (see Figure 6 d). 6 The Au 4f spectrum is relatively simple. The Au is mainly coupled directly to CN-150, so the percentages of these two peaks varied very little in 4Au/CN-150 and Au/Ti$_{3}$C$_{2}$/CN150. Based on the position of the two characteristic peaks of Au 4f and the fixed difference of 3.7 eV, it can be determined that the gold has a zero chemical valence.

Claim_set.text: For Mo$_{2}$C, the valence band nearby the Fermi level is primarily composed by the d orbitals of Mo atom [11,12]. Consequently, tunning the local environment around the Mo atom can influence the valence band of catalyst significantly [13,14]. Take the consideration of different d orbitals structure, introducing the secondary metal, such as Ni, Co, and Fe, is feasible to adjust the local environment around the Mo atom, which may reform the band structure and weaken the hydrogen adsorption, thus promoting the HER kinetics of Mo$_{2}$C [15,16]. However, the metal dopants usually suffer from active sites dissolution during electrolysis, especially under acidic condition, leading to the decay of electrolytic efficiency in HER.
Claim_set.Claim: Introducing secondary metals such as Ni, Co, and Fe can adjust the local environment around the Mo atom in Mo2C, potentially reforming the band structure and weakening hydrogen adsorption, thereby promoting HER kinetics.
Claim_set.Topic: Tuning the local environment around the Mo atom in Mo2C for enhanced HER kinetics.

Claim_set.text:
According to the d -band theory, when d band downward shifts away the Fermi level, the affinity of N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C towards hydrogen will be declined [41,42], thus reducing the resistance of hydrogen desorption, and promoting the whole alkaline HER (Fig. 2h).

Fig. 2. (a) Mo 3 d , (b) N 1 s , (c) C 1 s high resolution XPS spectra of N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C and N$_{l}$-Mo$_{2}$C( i$_{Mo-N/Mo-C}$ is suggested as the mole ratio). (d) Normalized XANES spectra at K-edge. Inset: the enlarged XANES spectra.
Claim_set.Claim: The d-band theory predicts that a downward shift of the d band away from the Fermi level in Nₕ-Mo₂C decreases its affinity for hydrogen, reducing hydrogen desorption resistance and enhancing the alkaline HER.
Claim_set.Topic: d-band theory and its impact on hydrogen affinity in alkaline HER

Claim_set.text: According to the previously reported study, we first calculated the D G$_{H*}$ of H atom on the Mo site on the N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C, N$_{l}$-Mo$_{2}$C and N$_{0}$-Mo$_{2}$C (Fig. S28). The results (Fig. 5d) reveal that compared with N$_{l}$Mo$_{2}$C and N$_{0}$-Mo$_{2}$C, the N$_{h}$-Mo$_{2}$C portrays the most satisfactory H adsorption energy due to the downshift of valence band and d band center. This appearance demonstrates that the higher content of N doping efficiently modulates the H coupling and H$_{2}$ release, thus promoting the whole HER process.
Claim_set.Claim: Higher content of N doping efficiently modulates the H coupling and H2 release, thus promoting the whole HER process.
Claim_set.Topic: Modulation of HER process through N doping

Claim_set.text:
## ABSTRACT

Water resources contamination by both oil and microplastics (MPs) stands as a pressing environmental concern. To tackle this challenge, we have devised a superhydrophobic magnetic biomass aerogel, synthesized from PDMS-modified carbonized ZIF-67/chitosan (PDMS@CZIF-67/CS). This aerogel exhibits remarkable capabilities in oil/water separation and adsorption of a wide range of emerging pollutants due to its inherent superhydrophobicity, stability, and self-cleaning capabilities. Furthermore, the aerogel demonstrates efficient absorption of viscous oils and facilitates self-driven oil absorption through the synergistic photothermal conversion and magnetic properties of CZIF-67, respectively.
Claim_set.Claim: The superhydrophobic magnetic biomass aerogel, synthesized from PDMS-modified carbonized ZIF-67/chitosan (PDMS@CZIF-67/CS), exhibits remarkable capabilities in oil/water separation and adsorption of a wide range of emerging pollutants due to its inherent superhydrophobicity, stability, and self-cleaning capabilities. It also demonstrates efficient absorption of viscous oils and facilitates self-driven oil absorption through the synergistic photothermal conversion and magnetic properties of CZIF-67, respectively.
Claim_set.Topic: Oil and microplastics pollution remediation in water resources

Claim_set.text: The aerogel comprises commercial CS substrate, magnetic and photothermal CZIF-67, and low surface-energy PDMS. The homogenized CZIF-67/CS dispersion was poured into a mold (1 × 1 × 1 cm) and transferred to a freezer, which induces an extreme temperature gradient, facilitating swift growth of ice crystals in multiple directions. Consequently, CZIF-67/CS grew on the ice crystals and formed a stable cellular network. Subsequently, a standard freeze-drying process was executed to eliminate the ice crystals and create an initial structure of honeycomb-like aerogel interlaced with CZIF-67 and CS.
Claim_set.Claim: The aerogel is composed of commercial chitosan (CS) substrate, magnetic and photothermal cobalt zinc iron (CZIF-67), and low surface-energy polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS). The homogenized CZIF-67/CS dispersion was poured into a mold and transferred to a freezer, which induces an extreme temperature gradient, facilitating swift growth of ice crystals in multiple directions. Consequently, CZIF-67/CS grew on the ice crystals and formed a stable cellular network. Subsequently, a standard freeze-drying process was executed to eliminate the ice crystals and create an initial structure of honeycomb-like aerogel interlaced with CZIF-67 and CS.
Claim_set.Topic: Fabrication of a multifunctional aerogel via freeze-drying and ice crystal templating.

Claim_set.text: To investigate the detailed impact of different Mo doping concentrations on the crystal structure of NiCoDH, the enlarged XRD patterns of NiCoDH-Mo samples at 5 · - 20 · were conducted. As shown in Fig. 3b, the (001) crystal plane of NiCoDH is slightly shifted negatively after Mo doping. It could be attributed to the higher valence state of Mo 6 + , which induces stronger repulsive forces between the crystal layers, eventually widening the (001) crystal plane spacing. With increased Mo content, the (001) crystal plane of NiCoDH-Mo undergoes a slight positive shift and ultimately remains unchanged.

Claim_set.text:
Given the remarkable selectivity of non-radical pathways, we systematically examined the performance of

Besides incorporating heteroatoms and metal elements into biochar, increasing the defect level is also generally considered an effective means to improve the PMS activation performance of biochar-based materials [38]. It has been confirmed that pyrolyzing biomass in a molten salt medium can significantly increase the level of defects in biochar [39,40]. Furthermore, molten salts, in their liquid state, can easily penetrate the carbon structure of biochar, inhibiting the formation of van der Waals forces and preventing the accumulation of sp$^{2}$coordinated carbon layers [41]. This ultimately promotes the development of a thin-layered structure.
Claim_set.Claim: Pyrolyzing biomass in a molten salt medium significantly increases the level of defects in biochar, promoting the development of a thin-layered structure and improving PMS activation performance.
Claim_set.Topic: Improving PMS activation performance through defect level increase in biochar.

Claim_set.text:
In addition, molten salt, as a high-temperature ionic melt, can enhance mass transfer processes, thereby promoting the rapid and thorough progress of the pyrolysis of biomass [42].

From the practical application standpoint, biochar emerges as a highly promising material due to its exceptional cost-effectiveness and high production yield [26,27]. Usually obtained from industrial, agricultural or household waste materials, biochar is known for its remarkably low production costs and excellent performance [28,29]. What ' s even more significant is that numerous reports have confirmed that biochar can efficiently activate PMS through various non-radical pathways. Nonetheless, the inert conjugated carbon framework of raw biochar restricts its activation performance for PMS, impeding its further application [30].
Claim_set.Claim: Molten salt enhances mass transfer processes, promoting rapid and thorough biomass pyrolysis.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancement of biomass pyrolysis

Remarkably, peaks in O 1s had more obvious shifts after adsorption (Fig. 4D), revealing that there ' re interactions between Pb 2 + and functional groups of kiwi peel, such as -OH, -COOH, C -O, etc. Besides, binding energy of Mn -O in O 1s spectra also decreased after adsorption, ascribing that covalent bond may form between Mn -O and Pb during the adsorption. Claim_set.text:
9 intuitively reflect the charge distribution and charge-related properties of the Wender model of lignite and the collector molecules. Crucially, the electrostatic surface potential affects the interaction between the LRC (lignite model) and collector. Therefore, the ability of the different collectors on the wetting of LRC can be analyzed using the electrostatic surface potential. In Fig. 9, the electrostatic potentials from small to large are shown in blue, white, and red, respectively. Thus, blue areas have a high electrostatic potential and high electron density, whereas red areas have a low electrostatic potential and lower electron density.

Figure 9(a) presents the charge distribution of Wender model lignite. As shown, the negative potential is mostly

around the oxygen-containing functional groups.
Claim_set.Claim: The electrostatic surface potential of the Wender model of lignite and collector molecules significantly influences their interaction, with the potential distribution affecting the wetting ability of collectors on lignite.
Claim_set.Topic: Interaction between Lignite Model and Collector Molecules

Claim_set.text:
As shown, the negative potential is mostly

around the oxygen-containing functional groups. The electrostatic potential of lignite is greater than that of water, which makes water easily adsorbed by lignite, resulting in high wettability. As shown in Fig. 9(b)-(e), dodecane has an evenly distributed electron density and an electrostatic potential neared to zero, resulting in a relatively stable structure that limits intermolecular interactions. However, the presence of double bonds, chloride ions, and oxygencontaining functional groups in the collectors result in negative electrostatic potentials, and the ammonium group results in a positive electrostatic potential. As shown, compared to that of dodecane, the intensity of the colors in collector models is higher, demonstrating their greater electron density.
Claim_set.Claim: The electrostatic potential of lignite is greater than that of water, making it highly wettable.
Claim_set.Topic: Wettability of lignite by water

Claim_set.text: In the initial configuration shown in Fig. 8, the collector molecules are uniformly distributed on the lignite surface in imbalanced and precarious conditions. After the MD simulation, the potential energy, non-bonding energy, kinetic energy, and total energy were stable, indicating that the adsorbed system was at equilibrium. Unlike in the initial structures, the oxygen-containing functional groups of the collector are adsorbed on the polar regions of the LRC surface by hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces, which could significantly enhance the flotation of LRC [52-55]. Thus, the collector forms a layer covering the hydrophilic part of the LRC, which improves its hydrophobicity and floatability. As shown in Fig. 8, the high concentration of dodecane molecules in the equilibrium configuration does not enhance the surface hydrophobicity of LRC.
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption of collector molecules on the lignite surface enhances its flotation properties through hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces, improving hydrophobicity and floatability.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption and flotation enhancement of lignite.

Claim_set.text: The Na storage performance of this material was explored both in etherbased and ester-based electrolytes, and the reasons for the superior performance in the former were discussed by analyzing the composition and thickness of the SEI layer. Moreover, the Na storage mechanism and detailed structural evolution of Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$ were established for the first time by in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations exhibit that the unique structure facilitates internal charge transfer and enhances Na + adsorption ability. As a result, a high reversible specific capacity of 636 mAh g -1 was achieved at 0.1 A g -1 and still remained 301 mAh g -1 at 5.0 A g -$^{1}$.
Claim_set.Claim: The unique structure of Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$ facilitates internal charge transfer and enhances Na + adsorption ability, leading to high reversible specific capacity and superior performance in ether-based electrolytes.
Claim_set.Topic: Sodium Storage Performance in Batteries

Claim_set.text: The dominant charge accumulation around the O atoms forms a negative charge center, thus providing a favorable environment for the adsorption of Na $^{+}$. The interfacial interaction in the Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$@C@MoS$_{2}$ heterojunction leads to fast electron transfer as well as rapid diffusion kinetics of Na $^{+}$. The density of states (DOS) was calculated to explore the electronic structures. The total DOS (TDOS) crossing the Fermi level for Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$ and Fe$_{2}$Mo$_{3}$O$_{8}$@MoS$_{2}$ exhibits no electron density, showing a semiconductor characteristic (Figure 5f,g).
Claim_set.Claim: The interfacial interaction in the Fe2Mo3O8@C@MoS2 heterojunction facilitates fast electron transfer and rapid diffusion kinetics of Na+.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhanced electrochemical properties through interfacial interactions in a heterojunction

Additionally, the E$_{ads}$ of Na + on the three models at different adsorption sites were also discussed (Figure S15, Supporting Information).
Claim_set.Claim: The adsorption energy of Na+ on Fe2Mo3O8@C@MoS2 is lower than that on Fe2Mo3O8@MoS2 and Fe2Mo3O8, indicating superior adsorption capability for Na+ on Fe2Mo3O8@C@MoS2.
Claim_set.Topic: Adsorption Energy of Na+ on Different Materials

Claim_set.text: Abstract: Ammonia borane (AB) with 19.6 wt . % H$_{2}$ content is widely considered a safe and efficient medium for H$_{2}$ storage and release. Co-based nanocatalysts present strong contenders for replacing precious metal-based catalysts in AB hydrolysis due to their high activity and cost-effectiveness. However, precisely adjusting the active centers and surface properties of Co-based nanomaterials to enhance their activity, as well as suppressing the migration and loss of metal atoms to improve their stability, presents many challenges.
Claim_set.Claim: Co-based nanocatalysts are strong contenders for replacing precious metal-based catalysts in ammonia borane hydrolysis due to their high activity and cost-effectiveness, but challenges remain in adjusting their active centers and surface properties to enhance activity and suppress metal atom migration for improved stability.
Claim_set.Topic: Ammonia borane hydrolysis for hydrogen storage

Claim_set.text:
The fabrication of silica-confined CoCu-ZIF-derived into Co-Cu alloy catalysts addresses these challenges by not only preventing the loss of the active component, but also by improving the wettability of the catalyst, ultimately facilitating AB hydrolysis.$^{[34-38] }$

Herein, we report a facile and scalable process for constructing Co$_{x}$Cu$_{1-x}$@nitrogen-doped carbon covered by mesoporous silica layers (Co$_{x}$Cu$_{1-x}$@NC@mSiO$_{2}$, where x represents the molar ratio of Co in the bimetallic Co-Cu) through the pyrolysis of silica-confined CoCu-ZIF.
Claim_set.Claim: Silica-confined CoCu-ZIF-derived Co-Cu alloy catalysts prevent active component loss, improve wettability, and facilitate ammonia borane hydrolysis.
Claim_set.Topic: Catalyst fabrication for ammonia borane hydrolysis

Note: The battery has undergone formation and capacity grading.

Next, the cleaned lithiated graphite electrodes were immersed in the lithium extraction solution (Pyr/2-MeTHF) to directly retrieve active lithium, assisted by ultrasound to promote the kinetics of lithium leaching. It is noteworthy that optimizing the lithium extraction solution (more suitable PAHs and solvents) or the extraction process (heat treatment to accelerate active lithium precipitation [45]) can further facilitate the leaching of active lithium from the graphite. However, in this study, we emphasize the onestep chemical extraction of active lithium under ambient temperature and normal pressure conditions.

Post-reaction, the separation process yielded lithium-rich solutions and graphite containing residual lithium. Since most of the active lithium (with an extraction efficiency exceeding 83%) has already been extracted by PAHs, the reactivity of the graphite residue is prominently reduced.
Claim_set.Claim: Optimizing the lithium extraction solution or the extraction process can further facilitate the leaching of active lithium from the graphite.
Claim_set.Topic: Leaching of active lithium from graphite

## 2.2.2 Flotation Experiments in Inorganic Salt Solutions

Before studying the effect of monovalent cations on LRC flotation, the optimal collector dosage was determined from the flotation results obtained in deionized water (see Section 2.2.1). Specifically, this was the dosage at which the highest flotation yield was obtained. The flotation procedures were performed following the same procedure as that used for deionized water but with solutions of KCl and NaCl (5, 10, 15, and 20 mM).

## 2.3 Bubble-Particle Attachment Experiments

To distinguish the degrees of hydrophobicity of LRC particles pretreated with four kinds of collectors, bubble-particle adhesion tests were conducted. A schematic of the bubble-particle attachment setup is shown in Fig. 1.

Claim_set.text: Similar to ML, for CTAC, the flotation yield increased significantly from 8.50 to 41.24% as the dose increased but then decreased slightly to 31.16% at higher dosages. The highest flotation yield obtained with CTAC (41.24%) was achieved at a dosage of 2.0 kg/t, whereas the lowest flotation performance obtained with ML (46.02%) was achieved at a dosage of 1.0 kg/t. These results indicate that the collection efficiency of ML is much higher than that of CTAC. This may be a result of the formation of hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces between ML and the LRC particle surfaces. These results indicate that the flotation of LRC can be enhanced by ester surfactants.
Claim_set.Claim: The flotation yield of LRC significantly increases with CTAC dose up to 41.24% at 2.0 kg/t but decreases at higher dosages, while ML shows a higher collection efficiency with a lowest flotation performance of 46.02% at 1.0 kg/t, possibly due to hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces.
Claim_set.Topic: Flotation Performance of Ester Surfactants in Coal Processing

Claim_set.text: However, the sensitivity of methods to analyze the target ' s concentration based on the enhancement or attenuation of the color is usually limited and is susceptible to interference from environmental factors (e. g., light intensity), resulting in inaccurate readings [13]. Combining colorimetric signals with other sensing modes to build a multisignal integration platform can provide a more attractive way to effectively improve sensing performance. At present, combining colorimetry with fluorescence [14], electrochemistry [15], or photothermal mode [16] has improved the detection sensitivity. Among these detection modes, the photothermal signal is considered to be a powerful complement to colorimetry [17]. This detection mode has a lower background because the temperature change is mainly caused by the photothermal effect [18]. In addition, detection methods that rely on photothermal signals are not limited by time, place, and professional operators.
Claim_set.Claim: Combining colorimetric signals with other sensing modes, particularly the photothermal mode, can effectively improve sensing performance by providing a powerful complement to colorimetry, reducing background interference, and enhancing detection sensitivity.
Claim_set.Topic: Enhancing sensing performance through multisignal integration platforms

Claim_set.text:
Based on the competition between AA2P hydrolysate and TMB and the inhibition of OPs on ACP activity, the sensitive analysis of OPs ' concentration was realized by monitoring the color signal and photothermal signal. This dual-reading probe added a temperature signal read by a portable thermal imager to the traditional color signal. The detection accuracy of the developed probe was verified by spiked recovery experiments in three real samples, which confirmed the practical application potential in food safety monitoring. It is worth mentioning that the integration of colorimetric and photothermal signals can not only promote the accuracy of detection through mutual verification, but also effectively improve detection sensitivity. Therefore, this study also provides a new strategy for the design of simple, sensitive, and reliable multimodal rapid analytical methods for the detection of other safety hazard factors.
