Claim_set.text:
## 1. Introduction

Journal Pre-proof Due to the increasing depletion of primary energy of fossil fuels, the demand for clean and sustainable energy technologies is continuously increasing. Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are highly efficient and environmentally friendly solid-state devices, which thereby have attracted significant attention [1-5]. To promote the commercialization, it is highly demanded for SOFCs to lower the operation temperature (  800  C), which can broaden the materials selection and reduce the cost. However, at redued temperatures, the cathodes of SOFCs are still the main reason for the efficiency loss of the existing systems and performance degradation [6-8]. It is therefore of significant importance to explore high efficient and durable cathode materials [9-11].
Claim_set.Claim: Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are highly efficient and environmentally friendly solid-state devices that have attracted significant attention due to the increasing depletion of primary energy of fossil fuels. The demand for clean and sustainable energy technologies is continuously increasing, and there is a high demand to lower the operation temperature of SOFCs to broaden the materials selection and reduce the cost, making it necessary to explore high efficient and durable cathode materials.
Claim_set.Topic: Clean and sustainable energy technologies

By tuning the elemental components or microstructure, the CO$_{2 }$tolerance can be significantly enhanced. ## 2.2. Basic characterization

Journal Pre-proof The X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer, Cu-Kα radiation) method was used to study the crystal structures. To check the chemical compatibility, the blended powder of PBSCCC-SDC (7:3 mass ratio) was calcined at 1000 °C for 5 h. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were conducted using a Hitachi SU8010 for microstructure and composition analysis. It has been reported that the doping of Ca and Sr can reduce the tolerance factor and improve the crystal symmetry, thereby affecting the bimodal peak shape of the XRD pattern [39, 40]. Based on Rietveld refinement results, the lattice parameters are obtained in Table S1. In addition, no new peaks were detected after the PBSCCC-SDC admixture was calcined at 1000 °C for 5 h. This suggests that PBSCCC cathode exhibits favorable chemical compatibility with SDC electrolyte.

Claim_set.text: These impedance spectra were also analyzed using DRT technique to gain further insight into the electrochemical process evolution of the cathodes, as shown in Figs. 6d, e and S6b. It is evident that both cathode materials are characterized by the integrated resistance of the P$_{LF}$ and P$_{MF}$ peaks increased continuously with time, while the characteristic frequencies of the peaks move towards the lower frequencies. The above results show that under high concentration of CO$_{2 }$atmosphere, the surface exchange process of cathodes and the mass transport process in the interface vicinity are greatly affected [24]. On the other hand, the integral resistance of PBSCCC increases gently, indicating that it has a great CO$_{2}$ tolerance ability.
Claim_set.Claim: The electrochemical process evolution of cathodes under high concentration of CO2 atmosphere is characterized by an increase in the integrated resistance of the P$_{LF}$ and P$_{MF}$ peaks, with a shift in the characteristic frequencies towards lower frequencies, indicating a significant impact on the surface exchange process and mass transport process in the interface vicinity.
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical Process Evolution Under High CO2 Concentration

Claim_set.text:
The desorption peaks of the strong basic sites essentially correspond to the decomposition of BaCO$_{3}$/SrCO$_{3}$ and the release of adsorbed CO$_{2}$ [58]. The peak area can intuitively reflect the total amount of CO$_{2}$ released by desorption. The amount of CO$_{2}$ desorption of PBSCCC is significantly smaller than PBC, indicating that the reduction of alkaline sites on the surface of the medium-entropy oxide can effectively inhibit CO$_{2}$ adsorption and carbonate production.

Fig. 6. (a) Temperature dependence of R$_{p}$ values for PBC, PBCC and PBSCCC cathodes in 10 % CO$_{2 }$-air at 700 °C.

Claim_set.text: As compared in Fig. 8a and b, it can be vividly observed that the Raman signals of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ and BaCO$_{3}$ on PBC surface are very strong, especially for Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ segregations that spread over the surface. Note that the intensity of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ is higher than that of BaCO$_{3}$. As Raman technique is very surface sensitive, it is reasonable to consider that the segregation amount of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ is more than BaCO$_{3}$. It confirms that PBC cathode is heavily polluted by formation of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ and BaCO$_{3}$.
Claim_set.Claim: The Raman signals of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ and BaCO$_{3}$ on PBC surface are very strong, with Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ exhibiting higher intensity, indicating a greater amount of surface segregation.
Claim_set.Topic: Surface segregation of Co$_{3}$O$_{4}$ and BaCO$_{3}$ on PBC cathode surfaces

Claim_set.text:
## 1 | INTRODUCTION

Sodium -ion batteries (SIBs) have been gaining much attention owing to their potential application in large -scale energy storage systems. 1 -4 Cathode materials are the dominant performance -limiting factors for battery energy and power density. As the cyclable sodium ions' (Na$^{+}$) primary suppliers, O3 -type layer -structured manganese -based transition metal oxides (NaMn$_{x}$Me$_{1}$$_{-}$$_{x}$O$_{2}$, Me: transition metals) have the inherent advantages of great compositional structural chemistry diversity with controllable electrochemical performance and mass production industrial feasibility technology. The high Na + content (near 1.0) can efficiently guarantee the energy density and cycling lifespan, particularly when coupling with nonsodiated anode (such as hard carbon).
Claim_set.Claim: O3-type layer-structured manganese-based transition metal oxides are dominant performance-limiting factors for battery energy and power density, offering inherent advantages for large-scale energy storage systems.
Claim_set.Entity: O3-type layer-structured manganese-based transition metal oxides
Claim_set.Topic: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) for large-scale energy storage systems

Claim_set.text: 5,6 However, it is difficult to cycle O3 -type NaMn$_{x}$Me$_{1}$$_{-}$$_{x}$O$_{2}$ to potential higher than ~4.2 V (vs. Na$^{+}$/Na) resulting from the significant structural instability and severe capacity fade, along with the Jahn -Teller (J -T) effect produced by Mn$^{3+}$/Mn 4+ redox and the slip of MnO$_{2}$ slabs from Na + extraction at high voltages. 5 -7 The worse oxygen loss (O 2 - → O$_{2}$) will cause surface oxygen vacancies, leading to irreversible structural transformations and structural instability. 8 -12 Therefore, optimizing the oxygen local electronic structure becomes a critical pathway for realizing high -voltage cycling while maintaining stability.
Claim_set.Claim: Optimizing the oxygen local electronic structure is critical for realizing high-voltage cycling while maintaining stability in NaMn$_{x}$Me$_{1}$$_{-}$$_{x}$O$_{2}$ materials.
Claim_set.Topic: High-voltage cycling stability in NaMn$_{x}$Me$_{1}$$_{-}$$_{x}$O$_{2}$ materials

La -O chemical bond reveals not only the electrovalent bonding perspective but also the covalent characteristics resulting from La 5d and O 2p orbital

mixing due to O 2p → La 5d charge transfer. The mixed doping ensures the stability of the lattice oxygen framework and the reversibility of oxygen redox simultaneously.
Claim_set.Claim: La-O chemical bond exhibits both ionic and covalent characteristics due to La 5d and O 2p orbital mixing.
Claim_set.Topic: Chemical bonding characteristics of La-O in LaO6.

Claim_set.text:
31,32 To further understand the kinetic properties of the two electrode materials at different redox potentials, we performed in situ EIS measurements at the

peak positions and nearby points of each peak on the CV curves. The results are shown in Figures S9 and S10.The curves exhibit two semicircles in the high -and medium -frequency regions, respectively. The semicircle in the high -frequency region represents interfacial resistance mainly due to the CEI resistance on the surface of the cathode material (denoted as R$_{CEI}$ ), while the semicircle in the medium -frequency region represents the charge transfer impedance in the electrode material (denoted as R$_{ct}$ ), as s h o w ni nF i g u r e3H.
Claim_set.Claim: The in situ EIS measurements at different redox potentials reveal that the curves exhibit two semicircles, representing interfacial resistance and charge transfer impedance in the electrode material.
Claim_set.Topic: Kinetic Properties of Electrode Materials at Different Redox Potentials

Claim_set.text:
33 -35 Upon further charging to 4.25 V, a new phase OP2 gradually emerges, accompanied by the disappearance of the P3 phase in NLMCT -1 and the O3 and P3 phases in NMCT. According to previous reports, 36 -38 this new phase consists of alternating stacking of octahedral and prismatic layers along the c -axis and is more reversible compared to the

traditionally observed monoclinic phase generated at high voltage. As the charging voltage increased to 4.5 V, the (002) peak of the OP2 phase gradually shifted toward higher angles. Compared to the NMCT, the NLMCT -1 phase had a smaller angle deviation around the (00l) crystal plane at about 16° ( Δ = 1.32° in NMCT; Δ = 0.95° in NLMCT -1).
Claim_set.Claim: The new phase OP2, consisting of alternating stacking of octahedral and prismatic layers along the c-axis, is more reversible compared to the traditionally observed monoclinic phase generated at high voltage.
Claim_set.Topic: Phase transition in battery materials

Claim_set.text: This indicated that the c -axis contraction of NLMCT -1 was greatly relieved under high voltage, as clearly demonstrated in the (00l) d -spacing patterns. This phenomenon makes it more conducive to the embedding of Na$^{+}$. There were two possible reasons for this phenomenon. First, the support effect of La might have alleviated the collapse of the structure. Second, the lattice O became stable under high voltage, which resulted in a greater electrostatic repulsion between the O atoms in the Na layers, thereby stabilizing the structure. The structural evolution in NLMCT -1 during the discharge process is opposite to that during charging, with the sequence being OP2 → P3 → O3.
Claim_set.Claim: The c-axis contraction of NLMCT-1 is greatly relieved under high voltage, making it more conducive to the embedding of Na$^{+}$.Entity: NLMCT-1Topic: Structural Evolution of NLMCT-1 under High Voltage
Claim_set.Entity: NLMCT-1Topic: Structural Evolution of NLMCT-1 under High Voltage
Claim_set.Topic: Structural Evolution of NLMCT-1 under High Voltage

Claim_set.text:
41 The change in the ratio of Mn 3+ to Mn 4+ is barely noticeable when charged above 4.0 V, which means that Mn does not compensate for charges between 4.0 and 4.5 V. While for the discharge process, Mn 4+ was continuously reduced to Mn 3+ between 3.5 and 1.5 V. The Mn 4+ content increased at the end of discharge, which is attributed to the distortion and rearrangement of the chemical environment that leads to the residual of inactive Mn species. The increase

of redox inactive Mn 4+ not only suppresses the phrase transformation but also alleviates the J -T effect caused by the Mn 3+ species, leading to a positive effect on cyclability.
Claim_set.Claim: Mn 4+ content increased at the end of discharge, attributed to the distortion and rearrangement of the chemical environment that leads to the residual of inactive Mn species.
Claim_set.Topic: Effect of Mn 4+ on battery cyclability during discharge.

Claim_set.text: 42 The Ni 2p spectra in the NLMCT -1 (Figure 5C) show Ni 2p$_{3/2}$ and Ni 2p$_{1/2}$ initial binding energy located at 854.4 and 871.6 eV, 43 indicating that the valence state of Ni is mainly in the +2 state. Both the Ni 2p$_{3/2}$ and Ni 2p$_{1/2}$ peaks shifted toward higher binding energies when charged to 4 V, indicating the increase of Ni 3+ and the appearance of Ni 4+ states (located at 856.1 and 858.5 eV for trivalent Ni 2p$_{3/2}$ and quadrivalent Ni 2p$_{3/2}$, respectively).
Claim_set.Claim: The Ni 2p spectra of NLMCT-1 indicate a predominantly +2 valence state for Ni, with a shift towards higher binding energies upon charging to 4 V, suggesting an increase in Ni 3+ and the emergence of Ni 4+ states.
Claim_set.Topic: Valence state changes in nickel during battery charging

Claim_set.text: The peaks located at 534, 532, 531.6, and 529.6 eV can be assigned to oxidized electrolytes, 46 the generation of CO$_{3}$ 2 $^{-}$, 45 oxygenated deposited species, 44,46 and lattice oxygen, 22 respectively. The emergence of a new peak around 530.8 at 4.5 V during charging indicated the oxidation of O 2 - with the formation of peroxo -related species (O$_{2}$ 2 $^{-}$)upondesodiation. 26,47 This results in a weakening of the electrostatic repulsion between O and O, thereby leading to a reduction in the interlayer spacing between adjacent TM -O layers. This provides a great explanation for the further contraction of the d -spacing observed by in situ XRD measurements under high voltage.
Claim_set.Claim: The emergence of a new peak around 530.8 eV during charging indicates the formation of peroxo-related species (O2^2-) upon desodiation, leading to a reduction in the interlayer spacing between adjacent TM-O layers.
Claim_set.Topic: Formation of peroxo species in electrolytes during battery charging.

Claim_set.text:
Nano-biochar (NBC) is an emerging environmentally friendly nanocarbon material. The transformed biochar material has developed pore structure, rich functional groups and large specific surface area, and can be used as an efficient biological adsorbent[8] for adsorbing heavy metals[9], organic pollutants[10,11] and other substances. The use of nanobiologic technology based on agricultural waste to construct " closed-loop agriculture " [12], efficient use of biomass, to achieve the effect of " turning waste into treasure " .

Surface engineering is a necessary basic means to change the properties of carbon nanomaterials and expand their application fields [13 -15]. Carbon nanomaterials with desired properties and specified sizes can be customized by introducing specific functional groups or directionally regulating their structures through different means.
Claim_set.Claim: Nano-biochar (NBC) is an efficient biological adsorbent for heavy metals, organic pollutants, and other substances due to its developed pore structure, rich functional groups, and large specific surface area.
Claim_set.Topic: Emerging environmentally friendly nanocarbon material for adsorption of pollutants.

Claim_set.text:
Moreover, excessive temperatures may cause some materials to over-carbonize, resulting in the loss of energy and raw materials[19,20]. Oxidation modification is also a common modification method, which introduces oxygen-containing functional groups to the surface of carbon nanomaterials under the action of strong oxidants to modify the surface[21]. This method will reduce the electrochemical properties of the material, and the uneven oxidation will also increase the instability of the material, making its modification uncontrollable[22,23]. There is still a lack of a simple and universal modification method to effectively regulate various types of carbon nanomaterials.

Herein, a strategy for cutting nanobiochar (NBC) in situ by electroreduction is proposed (Scheme.1).
Claim_set.Claim: Excessive temperatures may cause some materials to over-carbonize, resulting in the loss of energy and raw materials.
Claim_set.Topic: Oxidation modification and in situ cutting of carbon nanomaterials by electroreduction

Claim_set.text: The test procedure mainly consisted of three steps (Fig. S2c) [27]: Preconcentration (step 1), under magnetic stirring conditions, the fabricated Nafion/ErNBC/GCE was immersed into 0.2 M acetate buffer containing metal ions to accumulate and reduce metal ions into metals under preconcentration potential of GLYPH<0> 1.20 V. The preconcentration time was 6 min. The possible REDOX reactions on the electrodes in this step are as follows. Nafion/ErNBC/GCE + Pb 2 + (from solution) + 2e$^{- $_{→ }$}$Nafion/ ErNBC/GCE-Pb$^{0 }$(surface).
Claim_set.Claim: "Nafion/ErNBC/GCE was used to accumulate and reduce metal ions into metals under preconcentration potential of -1.20 V."
Claim_set.Topic: "Electrochemical preconcentration and reduction of metal ions"

It was not difficult to find that NBC and ErNBC exhibit characteristic absorption bands of -OH stretching vibrations at 3433 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, C -H stretching vibrations at 2985 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, C = O stretching vibrations at 1655 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1 }$in the COOH, C -O stretching vibrations at 1327 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, and C -N stretching vibrations at 1418 cm GLYPH<0> $^{1}$, which is consistent with the XPS results[28,33]. Claim_set.Claim: NBC and ErNBC exhibit characteristic absorption bands of -OH stretching vibrations at 3433 cm^-1, C-H stretching vibrations at 2985 cm^-1, C=O stretching vibrations at 1655 cm^-1 in the COOH, C-O stretching vibrations at 1327 cm^-1, and C-N stretching vibrations at 1418 cm^-1, which is consistent with the XPS results.

Claim_set.text: In addition, the material is tested for EIS. Fig. 4c is a Nyquist diagram showing the correlation of the real and imaginary parts of the impedance with frequency. Fig. 4d is a Bode diagram showing the relationship between impedance and phase Angle. As can be seen from the figure, the impedance of Nafion/ErNBC/GCE is smaller than that of Nafion/NBC/GCE. It was consistent with the analysis of CV results. It is speculated that conductive ErNBC can restore the electrode activity to a certain extent, which leads to the increase of peak current and the decrease of interface resistance. These results prove that the NBC are reduced in the CV process. And the conductive ErNBC is conducive to the improvement of Pb 2 + -analysis performance.
Claim_set.Claim: "Conductive ErNBC restores electrode activity, increasing peak current and decreasing interface resistance, thereby improving Pb^2+ analysis performance."
Claim_set.Topic: Electrochemical Analysis Performance Improvement

Claim_set.text: At the same time, this study also provides ideas for the sustainable and green utilization of waste tea residue, and also provides a green and rapid electrochemical surface functionalization method for the preparation of ErNBC. However, there are also some shortcomings that need to be further studied. For example, it is found that the amount of materials prepared by electrochemical reduction method is relatively small, and it is difficult to industrialization and large-scale promotion. And with the rise of portable instruments, once the stability of portable electrodes is guaranteed, glassy carbon electrodes may gradually be replaced by small and easy to carry electrodes such as screen printed electrodes and flexible electrodes. Therefore, the materials prepared in this paper can also be tried to be used by portable instruments to broaden its application field.
Claim_set.Claim: Electrochemical reduction method for ErNBC preparation is sustainable and green but faces challenges in scalability and industrialization.
Claim_set.Topic: Sustainable and green utilization of waste tea residue for ErNBC preparation
